Tess Alexandra Monness. There is always so much I want to say to you each year on your birthday. Yesterday you fell asleep on my lap and I was holding your hand and when I looked down I ached, your hand looked different, like a real person, not a baby. I tried to imagine if I could pick out your hand in a line up of hands, I wasn't sure, you're changing and growing that quickly. 

Each year you're more you, more of a person with opinions, ideas, creations and most of all, emotions. All of it gets bigger and more complicated but that much more incredibly you. And each time I don't quite get it, or don't understand the way I usually always did, I tell myself that's a good thing, you shouldn't just be "figured out" all the time. You are anything but simple and easy, and in the absolute best way. 

As I'm writing this I'm thinking about how I so want to get it all perfect for you. But then I remember how hard I am working on showing you that perfect isn’t the way. How we both work on that. 

I've said this before but you have truly shown me that everything I believe in when it comes to raising thoughtful, caring, empathetic children is real. You are all of those things and more.

Your teachers and I even thought of making you a box for you to go through when all of it feels like too much. When I see how deeply you feel, I relate to it so much and also sometimes worry you feel too much. But then I know that anyone in your life is and will be lucky to know you because of this. When I said happy birthday to you today you said "don't worry mommy, I'm still your baby!" 

This morning you somehow were in our bed and I woke up to you examining my face, touching it and smiling. I would've woken up in a panic that I had fallen asleep without doing the millions of things I had planned to do but instead, I woke up to you accepting and loving me exactly like that. You always know. 

Happy Birthday to the most caring 5 year old I have ever known. I love you my love. #5

Yesterday at a school visit, Tess was painfully shy, wouldn’t even say her name or hello. It took everything in me not to say “I’m sorry, she’s just shy” or “she’s slow to warm up.” ⁣I let her be her, and she did warm up. We talked after about that initial feeling she had.
⁣
One time a a mom wrote to me. She told me that her daughter wouldn’t engage with her great grandmother on FaceTime. She said her husband would said “sorry grandma, she’s just shy!” This mom asked me if this was ok and if not, how to message to him why he shouldn’t do this. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
There’s a few of reasons why labeling our child (and apologizing for it) can turn into our child feeling a certain way about themselves. They’re being told or hearing that they’re shy, that it’s something to be sorry for, so that’s what they’ll believe they are instead of learning things about themselves. Saying about our child “sorry she’s shy” is missing an opportunity to connect more meaningfully “It feels different to talk to great grandma through the phone, and hard to do too!”⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It also comes down to this: when we say “sorry, she’s X” why are we apologizing for who our children are? Why do we make excuses for how they’re feeling? Do we want them to grow up apologizing for being who they are? ⁣⁣
⁣
⁣I personally never want to apologize for my children’s emotions OR behavior. Scroll for some adjustments we can make in a more positive way. Ways we can communicate to our children “be 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 you.” ⁣
⁣
Instead of:⁣
“She’s really shy, we’re working on it.”⁣
⁣
Try:⁣
“You can say hi if you want to, or wave, or high five, whenever you’re ready.”⁣
⁣
Upon leaving after a meltdown and saying 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 your child:⁣
“I’m sorry she’s just really tired/hungry/teething.”⁣
⁣
Try talking 𝐭𝐨 your child. ⁣
“You had a tough time earlier, I think you may be tired.”⁣
⁣
Instead of apologizing 𝐟𝐨𝐫 your child:⁣
“I’m so sorry I don’t know what’s gotten into her!”⁣
⁣
Say 𝐭𝐨 your child:⁣
“You had a hard time earlier, I wonder what you were feeling.”

I wanted matt to video us proudly walking into temple. I feel so proud to be celebrating with my family here this weekend, and show my girls how special it is, now more than ever. 

Also, just a moment for the girls dresses, I think they killed it this weekend with their wardrobe - thanks to @bambinifashion 😍 my code JENNIE gets you 33% off on top of their already discounted mid season sale!

This weekend, we were all running late to one of the family events. Tess was whining trying to figure out her legos and I said “Tess stop whining about toys right now! Please!” Then Tess yelled and threw her legos off the table in anger. Matt or I yelled at her. It doesn’t matter who. Both at Tess and at one another. Basically Matt, Tess and I all raised our voices. One of those moments of high tension and even amidst that my 3 year old Nell shouted back at all of us “Stop it! Stop that! No! Don’t do that!” 

A few minutes later we were on our way and more calm, kind of acting as if nothing happened. One of us offered to help our girls with their Lego set later, and one of us said “you look so pretty in that dress tonight!” 

Before we walked inside, I felt like it wasn’t right to just ignore what happened, I stopped us, I said “hold on we need to have a family meeting!” I said “we all had big feelings just 5 minutes ago. Some of us yelled and lost our patience.”

Nell said “yes! stop yelling!” I looked at her with such pride, thank god she felt comfortable calling us out. I never ever want her to lose that. To lose the security of that in her relationship with us, with anyone she loves.

I said “you’re right Nellie, We shouldn’t pretend that didn’t happen or ignore that, we should talk about it before we move on.” Both Matt and I apologized not only to our girls but to one another too. 

One of the most important parts of any relationship especially the one with our children? Apologizing and repairing. When we fail to apologize, we teach our children that apologies aren’t necessary, that manipulation and ignoring our mistakes is ok. We also create connections in our children’s brain that says “it’s ok for my grown up to yell, they may be nice after or maybe not, I’m not sure.” Which does the opposite of building a secure attachment. It’s a volatile, confusing and toxic dynamic. 

Let’s be the better generation. To raise children who don’t think it’s weak or unheard of to say “I’m sorry.” Scroll and #normalizemistakes and #normalizeapologizingtochildren.

I started really digging into sibling dynamics because of how close in age my girls are and how much they compete every single second. The most liberating reframe of siblings fighting is that it isn’t something that we can prevent or avoid, it’s something we can set boundaries around and help our children navigate. I think the more we think we can just “all get along and be happy” or “why are you fighting? Be nice!” the more we aren’t being productive with helping our children with the very real reality of their world: they are figuring out who they are and what makes them different or unique especially in comparison to the person they are around all. the. time. 

We first need to understand that it’s not about the surface problem of “I wanted to throw away that piece of paper first!” The psychology behind sibling rivalry is a complicated one. It’s about vying for parental attention, always feeling like there’s a threat to that attention, figuring out who they are and what makes them different or similar to their sibling all wrapped up into wanting to throw away a piece of paper before their sibling got to it. So when we just say “who cares about the paper!” we are essentially saying “who cares?!” to so much more than that. Our children deeply care. 

Scroll for what I think we can say to help our children with their reality of sibling jealousy and competition. This is going to be my first in a series of posts this week on sibling dynamics. Today’s is simplified but digestible.

I share this to show just how much I have had to let it go in order to allow Nell to get to a place where she can feel safe on the potty. For those who have been following me, this has been almost a year of learning. I don’t regret doing it any other way. Even now, she is still sometimes nervous to let it go. That’s what we often don’t realize. You can’t train a child through that. You can help a child get acquainted, comfortable and learn to trust their body but you can’t train them to (without controlling them entirely).

Nell had withholding patterns since she was a few months old. I knew and wanted this to be a process that was led by her. Even now, we are working on her getting comfortable with other bathrooms besides the one at home. Somehow, today, she successfully went @pretusa and was cheered by the employees as we walked out (they heard me singing a version of the song in this reel). 

I wish I could tell you exactly what to do but I believe that your child will lead you - just like Nell led me. This process was a labor of love, we got closer, we connected and I spent endless time sitting in her bathroom with her where I wrote this song. Maybe it will help one of you too. (Words change depending on what comes to mind 🤷🏻‍♀️). #letitgo

Having each of my girls choose what feels comfortable on their bodies, instead of picking out their clothes for them, has been an absolute game changer. Together, we went on the Hanna Andersson website and picked out dresses that I felt good about in both price point and material. More importantly, my girls were thrilled with every single thing they picked because of the fun colors, characters and comfort. @happyhannas #HannaPartner

When we go to pick out their clothes each day, getting to pick out something that they remember choosing for themselves helps them express their autonomy while also getting dressed and out the door! It’s also helped their relationship with themselves and one another, as we stand in front of the mirror (whenever I think of it!) and encourage all of us to say what we love about ourselves. This is only possible when they are wearing something that they feel good in!

Use my code JENNIE for 15% off anything on their site (Excluding clearance items) for the next 48 hours and don’t forget to include your child in picking what to get! 

#happyhannas

We are good parents even when our children aren’t happy. 
Our children are safe even if they’re very very sad. 

Sometimes I’ll call my mom when I leave Nell in hysterics. And my mom will often remind me 
“I never left you if you were crying!”
But then she usually follows up with:
“but I’m glad that you sometimes do.” 

Because remember this: 
If we don’t say bye, if we sneak out, or don’t leave altogether in order to make our children seemingly “happy,” what we’re really doing is manipulating - not intentionally, not maliciously, but we’re trying to control their emotions to not feel anything but “happy.”

Ask yourself is it for their sake or ours? Because the guilt would eat us up while we were out? Because we want to feel like a “good parent?” Or because we truly believe they won’t get through it?

We have to believe that our children can get through these goodbyes, and make sure they believe that too. Also, sometimes we have this idea that being a good mom doesn’t count unless we sacrifice more or give up something for ourselves in order to make our children always happy. 

Leaving our child even when they’re upset is ironically one of the most selfless things we can do. One day, when Nell plans a date for her and her spouse and her child isn’t happy about it, I hope she knows she not only deserves to do it but that she should for the sake of her child.

I share all of this to say to any of you in a similar situation, that you must tell yourself this, no matter how hard it feels:⁣
⁣
“I have to leave, not because it’s that important of a dinner or date, but because I need to show us both that 𝐰𝐞 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐠𝐞𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬.” ⁣
I’m not crying writing this or anything 🥹🥰

There’s no doubt about it, Tess has grit. As she gets older, it gets harder sometimes to encourage her to keep going.  I shared this video in the past, but I am sharing an updated one now. This is a reminder to us all. Grit is important.⁣
⁣
This video demonstrates how patience, perseverance and the ability to struggle is evident even in the youngest children. Sometimes, the hardest part is 𝐮𝐬 and 𝐨𝐮𝐫 willingness to let the struggle unfold, to see that young babies, toddlers and children aren’t as helpless as we think they are. Infants and toddlers aren’t suffering just because they are working hard (actually, sometimes that’s what they enjoy!).⁣
⁣
It’s also about more than just struggling in play, but also how we model responding to life’s struggles. I’m often asked, “how do toddlers learn patience? My toddler is so easily frustrated!” The answer is that they learn this when someone is patient with them. I definitely lose my patience sometimes, jump in too soon, distract, redirect vs. allow things to run their course whether it be a tantrum or struggle to reach for a toy. However, when our overall approach is to convey to our children that we can support vs. fix, 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐰𝐞 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞 𝐢𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐫𝐨𝐨𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦, we can really see the bigger picture and “sit on our hands” a moment longer. ⁣
⁣
Disclaimer: it is never too late to work on this.⁣ Share this with family members or caregivers too! #resilientchildren #encouragechildrentodream #buildinggrit

This morning Tess got upset about her tights. I didn’t respond right away because I just couldn’t deal with it during the morning rush. So she escalated in her whine and almost started to cry but I said “Ok but there’s no reason to cry, let's bring an extra pair of tights to put on in the car!” she said “Ok but can I have a hug?” 

I had a rough few days of parenting (when do we not?) My dad came in today to celebrate Hannukah with the girls at their school and when I saw him I just realized how much I needed the hug he gave me. Besides the 30-40 minutes in each of their classes, he and I had a rushed interaction before and a distracted lunch after. He told me I seemed harried and stressed. I was. I am. When he left and we hugged goodbye, I felt like I got a dose of medicine. I realized two things: We need to normalize needing a parent (or any caregiver) for our children. We need to normalize it so that they grow up not afraid to ask for help. I think of how often we muscle through things without asking for help, letting it eat us up inside.. I’m 39 so I was able to break from that hug that felt like medicine but as a 3 or 5 year old? That’s not so easy. Scroll for more normalizing.

Once upon a time I thought making sure my girls held my hand on the street was as serious as motherhood could get…😱 

*Both my girls were “withholders” from an early age. They were born with digestive challenges and reflux. Starting solids caused constipation and withholding. Once they starting using the potty they could comprehend the behavioral component to the vicious and painful cycle of being scared to poop (which causes more withholding and more pain) so I made this “diagram” of their belly and what happens. Some children need the visualization and information to make sense of a really tough process!

Last night I realized we had no brown play dough for this reel, Tess had the genius idea of making our own by mixing colors. But the point is that I use this video for anyone whose watching Nell when I’m not there, to remind her that, in the words of Daniel Tiger “when you have to go potty, stop and go right away!” If you have any resistant potty goers or withholders, maybe you’ll wanna show it to them too (DM me to let me know if you want my full demo on letting go of 💩 wasn’t sure about putting it up in entirety 🤣) 

#pottytrainingtips #withholdnotyourhand #pottylearning #pottytraining #withholding💩

My Winter Break Round Up! None of this is expensive. None of this takes up space. All of this is open ended, great for travel or at home and LASTS. Trust me on every single one and DM me photos if you use any! Toasting you all with a colander and mini flashlight 🔦 this Winter Break (and maybe some 🍷) #travelhacks #travelingwithkids

This audio is just so accurate 🤣 but all jokes aside, I have 3 things to offer you for smoother travel.⁣
⁣
1. Whenever we feel like we’re giving up so much for our children, that we’re self sacrificing, when we exude this, bicker with our spouse in front of them about it, the more likely our children will grow up feeling like a burden. A travel day here and there is different from complaining about how hard it all is all. the. time. ⁣
⁣
2. Have realistic expectations. Travel with young kids won’t be easy. Don’t anticipate lounging and reading a book on the beach. Anticipate getting in the sand with them. The more your expectations match reality the less disappointed and more appreciative you are for the time together on an adventure. ⁣How do you want your children to embrace trips? With anxiety or with excitement for adventure? (Even when things go wrong!) 
⁣
3. Think about when you really have to say no. If your child wants some extra snacks, wants to run around at the gate, wants to touch the escalator railing, it’s. ok. Save your no’s! There’s bound to be a lot. Children hear it a lot. Even if it’s not a blunt “no” just don’t correct and manage as much. Just like we let ourselves indulge more on vacation, instead of saying as many “no’s” just let some of it go. You’ll have more fun, and your kids will too. More fun = less stress.⁣
⁣
If we can really shift our mentality to embrace all three of these things, it can turn into this: no one is a burden, traveling is an adventure and there’s some hard parts but we’re in it together. Doesn’t that mentality feel so much better to start a trip?⁣
⁣
But also, when does the fun start?! 😂⁣

I dont ask my kids to share. And they 𝐝𝐨 share.

Yesterday my 3 year old niece came to our hotel and the girls were SO happy. When we got to the room Tess took out the three costumes we brought. Two Elsa costumes and one Ariel costume. Tess and Nell put on their Elsa costumes and then my niece started to cry that she didn’t have one. Tess then hesitatingly says “ok…i’ll give her mine.” We all showered Tess with “that is SO nice Tess! Wow, what a good girl” type comments. It felt wrong to me. Tess proceeded to take off her dress and the moment my niece put it on, Tess burst out crying. I took Tess aside and said “Tess, I know you wanted Cece to be happy, but you don’t have to take off your dress to make her happy, we can figure out something else. Do you want to give her your dress or do you want to wear it more?” She said “I want to wear it more.” I said “Ok so next time you can think of what you want and if what you want is to give the dress, you do that, if it isn’t, then we can figure out another plan.”

We ended up putting all the Elsa dresses away until the next day when my niece brought her own. The moral of the story is: If we keep asking our children to give up the metaphorical “shirt of their back” for the sake of others happiness, we are essentially raising children to be what we are trying so hard to undo in ourselves, people pleasers who don’t speak up for what they want. 

Also, would we take off our shirt if our friend wanted to wear it?! WTF! This isn’t how we teach sharing - we teach authentic sharing by considering everyone in the scenario and generosity and empathy in an appropriate manner. Because sharing isn’t as simple as just giving up something of yourself for the happiness of others, sharing is personal, nuanced, dependent on circumstances and settings. That happens over time and through modeling it ourselves appropriately. For all the in-between, we have to do our best to support all children involved and start with the question “what can we do in this situation?” Instead of reflexively asking one child to give up something for the sake of another.

There’s these moments in parenting that we can just let pass without thought and we keep going and going. We take for granted that when you don’t let that happen, when you actually let yourself think about and reflect on those moments, it becomes your guide book.

Follow me: Tess wanted plain pasta with butter for lunch yesterday. Nell wanted sauce. So I got buttered pasta with sauce on the side. The pasta came and I split up the pastas. I am a sauce fanatic so I got really excited about the sauce and started having some dipped in sauce. I was loving the sauce with Nell and laughing at how we ate some of it as soup. A few minutes later I ate a bite of Tess’s and there was sauce on my fork. Tess freaked out about the sauce on her pasta and wouldn’t stop “no there’s still some sauce on that one! ahhhh” I said “Tess enough, stop.” She stopped. 

I don’t say this out of guilt, I don’t feel guilt, I feel human. But I essentially slammed her emotional door.

Tess stopped complaining but imagine what it probably felt like. Her warm, loving and comforting mom suddenly turning cold like that. I didn’t yell, I just told her there was a time limit on her discomfort. I thought about what triggered me:

that it wasn’t such a big deal, that she was being that picky child who wasn’t going to eat if there was a morsel of sauce, that she was fixating, that she was obsessing, and being ungrateful. But she wasn’t being any of those things. She probably felt left out of the sauce party that Nell and I were having. Or maybe she took pride in her non sauce pasta and I ruined that. Or maybe she was just really really tired. 

All I know is that if I don’t reflect on those moments, even hours later, it can quickly become normal, habitual, reflexive, to slam that “stop, it’s enough” door. I never want that to happen. Where does all the stuff go behind that slammed door? It re opens years later as someone who doesn’t feel comfortable expressing how they feel in a relationship because “it’s too much” and they’ve been told “to stop” when it’s too much. 

My thoughts and alternatives to this experience are in the scroll above. Share yours!

📸 @michellerosephoto
When being a respectful parent bites you in the butt because I refuse to just disappear to the bathroom without telling them. But whenever I say I’m going, I have these two with me 🤷🏻‍♀️🚽

I remember going to my very first mommy and me class when Tess was 4 mos, I had way too much stuff, I was exasperated, and on the verge of tears. I felt even worse when I saw that no other mom seemed to remotely feel that way. I literally stared at them walk out of class down the street asking myself “how do they have it all figured out?” 

So this feeling right here, in this reel, when you figure something out - you know the one - you feel like an actual super star. It’s not about realizing I can use the Starbucks mobile app to actually get coffee before a flight, or that I have a contraption that fits through the aisles with both girls, it’s about feeling like “you have it down.”

When Nell was born, I would think about how I had just gotten to a stage with Tess where things finally felt manageable. And then I was going to have a newborn and it would be so long til I felt that again. While I don’t know if I’ll ever say I have it “all figured out,” I do feel that if we forgot everything, we’d figure it out - Tess would say something like “don’t worry mommy, we don’t need those things, we can do XYZ!” and she’d come up with some idea that would bring me back to remembering what parenting is about….𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘦𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘪𝘵 even if it feels like all we’re ever doing is putting out fires. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
During a moms groups once, a mom said “Jennie, please tell us, when do we figure it all out?!” and I said, with a smile, “I don’t think we ever do.” I think we have moments but all the in between we should stop trying to figure it all out and accept that humans aren’t meant to “figure out” maybe just the logistics are. But to figure 𝘢𝘯𝘺𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 out, you have to throw yourself into the fire. Even if your figurative fire is something that may seem small - like going to CVS with your baby, something you avoid bc you’re too nervous you’ll forget something or your baby will inconsolably cry. It may be a disaster, it may not. But you have to throw yourself into the fire, because when you do it enough, you’ll find yourself walking down the symbolic motherhood catwalk one day and you’ll think “Ok, I can truly do anything.” I wish for that for all of us for the holidays 🥰

Probably one of my most favorite traditions we created just today. I hope it lasts for generations. 

How you teach empathy is right here: helping your children to think of others in a way that isn’t shaming them or guilting them but supporting them. Happy Holidays everyone! 

Cover photo: @michellerosephoto

Happy Birthday to the dad and husband who reminds us every single day just how valuable and loved we are, and who truly doesn’t have to raise the game on how to show us.

Our girls notice when you get home every day and the first thing you do is give me a kiss and say “how was your day mommy?”

I know they see when you find ways to connect with me, how you put your hand on me when you pass me in the kitchen, hug me from behind for no reason, or just pick me up when I’m in a funk. 

They see how you talk to me, smile at me, listen to me, care about me and love me. 

I couldn’t ask for a more loving father to show our girls how they deserve to be loved.

Words in reel by @johndelony

“But I turned out ok.”⁣
“But you turned out ok.”⁣
⁣
Lines we tell ourselves or that our parents tell us - do you want to know why? Because we learn to put aside, suppress or distract from hard truths. One hard truth is to acknowledge where we didn’t turn out ok. That doesn’t necessarily mean we’re not “normal” or that we are not “sane,” it means we are human. No human is perfect or ok in every single area of their life. There’s always a corner that we struggle in. But so many of us never go to that corner, but that corner is always there and when we never go there, we never grow as a person, but also as a parent. We continue to stay away from that corner and then our children grow up to never go to that corner either. What a lot of people have learned to do, over time, is to suppress or distract from really hard emotions, and that turns into something - something that is actually 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘰𝘬.⁣
⁣
The other day, I had a tough moment with Nell. I can tell the whole story here but I’ll skip to the important part - we were both dysregulated, and in the midst of it, she said “I need help to calm down! I need help to calm down!” ⁣
⁣
It stopped me dead in my dysregulated tracks and I was floored that my child, only on this earth for 3 years, was able to, in the midst of emotional chaos, recognize what she needed. Instead of swallowing, suppressing, muscling through - she said what most of us are unable to say even at 30, 40, 50, 60 years old. 𝗪𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐩 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐦 𝐝𝐨𝐰𝐧. We never learned how to help ourselves to calm down. So we yell, we form bad habits, we have constant anxiety, we distract, we ignore, and we let it all pile up. ⁣
⁣
Next time you or your child is having a tough time, use this line out loud “𝐰𝐞 need help to calm down!” ⁣
⁣
Imagine, just imagine, in those moments that feel so out of control as a person, as a couple or as a family, if you could say “hold on! We need help to calm down!” How. Much. Better. We. All. Would. Be.

I couldn’t end the day without saying thank you to this community. Something I want to leave you with is the importance of your inner voice - this voice we have becomes the voice 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐲 have. 

“Uch I can’t do this anymore! I’m a failure” we all have these thoughts, we all have these doubts, they impact our overall energy, mood and approach to life. But imagine if, instead we thought “uch it 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘭𝘴 like I can’t do this anymore, sometimes it 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘭𝘴 like I’m failing, but I know I can get through it, I always do.” It’s like taking off your doubt goggles and putting on an “I can do this” cape.⁣
⁣
I’ve lived and breathed the difference. Even though I can’t do it all, no one can, I do the best that I can and that’s all I want for my children too, its what I want for all of you. ⁣

Last thing, stop rushing, I’m taking this advice too and scroll for how it transformed an experience for Tess 2 days ago. Here’s to less rushing and more trusting in 2023. Happy new year, thank you all for helping me be the mom that I am.

One of my plans for 2023, is saying “no” to my kids less. We were finally in the car to head back to the city and I was so ready for the girls to fall asleep when they asked to stop at the beach - my reflexive response was an immediate no. But then I <radically> thought “why not?” ⁣⁣

So we went. And when we were there, I whispered to Matt, “let’s just try to say yes more than we would, just try it.” 

So we did. They asked to use a big piece of wood to draw, we safely let them, they asked to climb the rocks, we did that too, they asked to run up the hill, I so badly wanted to say “but you’ll get sandy and there’s ticks!” But then I remembered it’s not tick season and who cares about being sandy! We did give a hard no when Nell asked to go home to get her “bading suit” 

*And Matt said yes to every photo I asked for! 🤣 

Saying "yes" more doesn’t mean you should over do what you have the bandwidth for, it also doesn't mean your child isn’t going to learn limits and boundaries. It also doesn’t mean that you’re giving your child “all the power,” it means that together you get to experience the power of saying “yes” to new things, even when the easier or reflexive response is “no.” 

I’ve shared this in a reel before but here it is again as one of my plans for 2023, thinking more before I dismiss or reflexively just say “no.” Try it!

At a playdate last weekend I gave out these glow tubes for NYE (very cool toy I’ll link in stories). I went to show one of the children how to use it - he is 2 - and he very quickly and strongly said “I do it!” His father looked at me apologetically and said “he really wants to do everything himself.” I quickly said “that’s really great, definitely frustrating, but great that he tells you and me what he wants!”

When Nell and Tess feel comfortable saying things like that, I remind myself how incredible it is. How supporting them appropriately with the process of speaking up for their comfort, preference, opinions and themselves is something that I want to preserve and protect even if it frustrates the hell out of me. It’s hard to remember every single time his son continues to speak up in that little “NO ME!” OR “I DO IT!” voice to appreciate it amidst the impossible frustration of it. (And this father was very patient I just imagine after the last two weeks I had, that it’s hard when it’s all. day. long.)

But there is always a way to help our child know and believe “I should always speak up, I should always ask, I should always say what I want to say.” 

When our child screams “NO STOP I WANT TO DO IT!” 

Instead of “Don’t talk to me like that!” we can say “You really want to do this yourself! I hear you! I am going to help you so that we can get out the door on time and we can do it together.”

I could give examples forever, its nuanced, I can’t tell you how our children will respond each time, the goal is to not fixate on “asking nicely” or “don’t’ talk back” because when that’s the focus, our child learns that asserting themselves and speaking up is not allowed instead of believing that it’s allowed and is the start of learning how to do so appropriately as they grow up. 

And when we forget to support them in those moments and we “lose it” or yell, we must point that out as the “non norm” even when it’s happening so much we’re almost reminding ourselves at the same time. ⁣⁣

Because otherwise, there comes a day when our children stop pushing back, because we’ve spent enough time extinguishing that outspoken voice. #Letthemtalkback

Yesterday morning the girls were drawing. I took Nell to get dressed and when I got back into the living room I looked over and saw Tess scribbling on a paper that I thought was Nell’s drawing. 

So I asked:

“Tess, whose drawing is that?”

She said “Nobody’s. It was no one’s.”

A few minutes later I hear Nell yell “TESSIE RUINED MY PICTURE!”

I was so angry inside. I looked over at Tess, walked over, kneeled down and said:

“You did two things that were very wrong. Do you know what they were?”

She made the face that she makes when she’s trying to be stoic and hold in emotions. 

“No”

I said “you drew on Nellie’s picture and then you lied to me about it. You never have to be scared if you make a mistake or do something wrong, you should always tell me the truth.”

The rest of the conversation doesn’t need to be written here word for word but here’s what was important. 

When I said: “Tess, I really wonder what made you draw on her picture. What were you feeling inside? Why do you think you did that?”

She kept saying she didn’t know, shrugging and from the naked eye it would seem almost as if she didn’t care and was straight up rude. But I knew better. I knew that she was just completely closed off because she was holding it all in. 

So I said:

“Tess you can cry.”

She exploded. It all came out. She kept yelling that she didn’t know why she did it and I said “that’s ok! You don’t need to always know.”

I held her for a few minutes crying and then she stopped and Nellie came in and I waited for Tess to apologize. She didn’t. We ate breakfast, the girls acted normally. I almost forgot the whole thing when about 30 minutes later I saw Tess come up to Nell and whisper something. Nell looked at her and smiled. Tess then said in a soft voice “did you hear what I said Nellie? I said I was sorry.” 

How did we get here? Read the scroll. #letthemlearn

Last night Tess started crying bc I wouldn’t let her have juice before bed. I overheard my mom go into Tess’s room and try to make Tess laugh, and then I heard my mom said “ok now no more crying.” (She meant this in a loving way)

I cringed for a sec, I so much never put a cap on how much they can cry, I never tell them when to stop… then I heard Tess say loudly “don’t say that! why do so many people say that!” and I walked in smiling and said “that’s right Tess! you don’t have to stop crying!” 

𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐥𝐨𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐜𝐞. I want to believe that for the rest of her life when anyone tells her to “stop crying, stop being dramatic, stop being so sensitive” that she’ll have the confidence and trust in her emotions (herself!) to remember that voice.

So many of you ask me “what do I do when I hear someone parenting my child differently than I do? How do I know when I should say something or just let it go?”⁣⁣

My answer: be the louder voice.

Here are some examples of what we can say to our child and some ways we can remind our children that they can assert themselves when they hear some of those reflexive comments from others.

When you hear “don’t make grandma sad, eat your food.”

“Only you know how much your body needs , you eat until your body is full. If anyone tells you how much to eat, you can say you’re going to eat until your body says it’s finished eating!”

When you hear: “give grandpa a hug, that’s not nice.” 

“Only you decide when you’re ready to hug someone. Sometimes you may be ready and other times you may not be. That’s ok. Don’t let anyone tell you when you are ready, only you decide that.” 

When you hear: “Wahh Wahh only babies cry!” 

“I heard X calling you a baby for crying. Do you know I cry sometimes too? I know I’m not a baby and I still cry. Don’t let anyone call you a baby for crying. If they do, you can tell them “Stop it. That’s not true. Everyone cries sometimes!” 

When you hear: “Good girl! You shared your toys” 

“I heard that. I want you to know you’re good if you choose to share and you’re good if you don’t want to share yet! You decide when you’re ready to share something you’re in the middle of using.”

You take away the iPad to get ready for school and your child loses it. Screams “one more game!” 

It’s time for dinner and your child says “no 5 more minutes!” About ten times.

I could keep going but what do these incidents have in common? They are the times we must make ultimate decision countless times per day - Do we just give in or do we hold a boundary?

If we stay strong and hold a boundary what sacrifice are we making for our own “sanity” and how do we hold a boundary that actually “works?”

Here’s the reason we hold the boundary as much as we possibly can: the sooner we hold firm and consistent boundaries the sooner we start a part of life that is not only inevitable but something children need in order to thrive. The more we avoid or forgo boundaries the less we set them up for success. 𝐈𝐭 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐝𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐦𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐧𝐞𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐬𝐚𝐫𝐲 𝐚𝐜𝐭 𝐨𝐟 𝐥𝐨𝐯𝐞. Because when we hold a boundary we set our children up for these crucial things:

1. Feeling safe because they see they possess only enough power that is appropriate.
2. They see that their emotions are not scary and don’t sway us as being our child’s leader. 
3. We set our child up for more success in accepting boundaries for life because they’ve been exposed to, comprehended and thrived from boundaries.
4. 𝐌𝐨𝐬𝐭 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭: 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐬 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐞𝐭 𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐯𝐞𝐬.

One of the ways we show our love to our child is ⁣
setting boundaries when the easier way is “giving in.”⁣
⁣
One of my favorite hacks when it comes to setting boundaries around schedule is using a visual like this. So simple. When it comes to things like snacks, bedtime, playtime, playground, bath, etc. this can really help kick start actually setting boundaries by switching a habit or dynamic where you really haven’t.⁣
⁣
The hardest part about boundaries with this is that our child is desiring something they 𝘣𝘦𝘭𝘪𝘦𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘯𝘦𝘦𝘥, but also having a hard time moving on from something too. So using a visual tool where there is something that can come with them (a photo of the desired thing - playground, snack, friend) can really help. Part of the acceptance is letting go of believing that need something RIGHT NOW in order to be ok. Perhaps this is more for us to believe than them, if we can trust that they can accept a limit, they’ll trust they can too. If we don’t show them this, how will they know? ⁣
⁣
*think of the adults you know who push relentlessly because they can’t accept boundaries - I wonder if they were ever taught this? ⁣

This is why I’m ok being the strict one, how I’ve grown from my “people pleasing” quality and been ok with my kids looking at me sometimes as if I’m the meanest mom they ever saw. I’m modeling one of the most important things - saying “no” and meaning it. 

There’s this impression saying “no” is a bad word to say to kids. But it’s not - It’s necessary!⁣⁣⁣ 
⁣⁣⁣
Saying no 𝘶𝘯𝘯𝘦𝘤𝘦𝘴𝘴𝘢𝘳𝘪𝘭𝘺 is discouraging and can lose its weight if used too frequently or unintentionally. But when a child is potentially hurting someone or they’re putting themselves in an unsafe situation we absolutely should say no! Not only to keep everyone safe in the moment, but to make sure our children learn to say no when 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 feel unsafe or harmed. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
It took me a while to say no with a straight face - I felt mean. But saying no without showing we mean it, isn’t productive and can be confusing. Sometimes my girls protest or cry when I’ve had to say “no” sternly but that doesn’t mean I’m mean or scary, it means I’m setting a limit that they don’t like or that feels hard to accept. ⁣⁣⁣Which is also why I say “I won’t let you” so they comprehend this isn’t a choice. 
⁣⁣
If we don’t say no to our children around safety and hard limits, how will they learn to say no with conviction? If someone hurts them I absolutely want them to say “NO, DON’T DO THAT!” and say it like 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 mean it. Hope this motivates you to do that too.

When something they do makes me question it all, everything I stand for and share here.⁣
⁣
Last night, I scared my girls. Tess pulled Nell down in the bath out of frustration and Nell fell, my reaction was not just about the fear of her safety and getting hurt but it was also a feeling of:

“𝘸𝘩𝘺 𝘥𝘪𝘥 𝘴𝘩𝘦 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘥𝘰 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵? 𝘏𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘐 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘬𝘦𝘥 𝘴𝘰 𝘩𝘢𝘳𝘥 𝘵𝘰 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘦 𝘴𝘶𝘳𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘴𝘩𝘦 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘪𝘴 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘰𝘬?”

My shouts of “boundaries” in that moment scared Tess. They scared us all. Nell cried, and as I talked, Tess’s eyes were just wide, focused on me and she was frozen. It all killed me. I said that there are other ways Tess can express her frustration, and Tess just kept nodding her head as I spoke. I told them I was sorry for scaring them that I was scared Nellie was going to get hurt. I said that if anyone ever hurts them I want them to yell that loud too to protect them. 
⁣
But then something happened -  amidst my babble of repair, I remembered that there were feelings inside of my 5 year old. That there was no way amidst me and Nell’s relative hysterics, that those feelings weren’t there. I said “Tess you’re allowed to show me how you feel right now, you can cry if you need to.” She took a second and then collapsed in me and said “I’m so sorry” and when I told her she doesn’t need to be sorry for my feelings, she said:⁣
⁣
“I know Mama, I understand, it was not safe and that’s your job.” ⁣And she held my face and looked into my eyes with genuine care and empathy, just like I’ve done for her over and over and over. ⁣
⁣
It’s those moments. The ones when we doubt it all, if we look close enough, they can be the same moments we know we don’t need to doubt it ever again.

On Friday night we went to Bryant Park and Tess fell asleep in the car ride there. When she woke up in the stroller she was smiling ear to ear but she said “are we going home soon?!?” I know when she asks like this it’s because she’s anxious that she doesn’t want the experience to end soon. I knew she was asking because she 𝐝𝐢𝐝𝐧’𝐭 want it to be time to go home and bc I have been in a rut of rushing and dictating. This was my reminder.

So this weekend I wanted to try something. Go at their pace instead of asking them to go at mine and to try to stop dictating constant orders. 
⁣
There were moments I found myself all tensed up ready to rush them when I would realize “I don’t really need to rush right now, we have time.” I started moving at their pace, not mine and they spent the weekend 𝘢𝘣𝘴𝘰𝘭𝘶𝘵𝘦𝘭𝘺 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘪𝘯𝘨.⁣

We are all so accustomed to rushing and going place to place. Often we’re doing so on auto pilot. But take a second to imagine how that feels. I have made this joke before about how I cannot go to CVS with Matt - I automatically have anxiety because he’s rushing the second we get there and I like to browse. This must be what it feels like for our kids in a way. ⁣

I know I’ve shared this many many times that we should do our best to put our “to do” lists and agendas aside and just be in the moment with our children. But what I haven’t shared enough is the impact that rushing our children through life can have: they perpetually feel rushed, and when that happens, 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐲 𝐬𝐭𝐨𝐩 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐲𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐦𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨𝐨. ⁣⁣

⁣Don’t roll your eyes at this, try it, ignore that naps may be off by a whopping 30 min and allow those few extra minutes to walk from the store to the car, from playing to getting dressed, from the elevator to the lobby, whatever it is, just walk WITH them. I guarantee if our kids had the vocabulary, next time we rushed them down the street when they were touching every grotesque surface they’d literally want to say “let me live, I’m thriving” but since many of them don’t yet, I’m saying it for them.⁣

When we need a child to give an obligatory “sorry” in order to move on and let go, we’re the ones who need to reassess the importance of a forced word over a lesson in forgiveness. 

You don’t agree? 

Imagine you forgot to pack your child’s lunch one day. Would you want them to be mad at you all day because “you were wrong” or until they saw you for you to say sorry? Or would you want them to think “everyone makes mistakes!” and move on from it? 

When we have a hard time “letting go” of things our children do or mistakes they make, we model that it’s not ok to make mistakes. 

You know the feeling when you get into an argument with someone, maybe your spouse, and the argument ends but you’re still stewing? What does that come from? We want our spouse to suffer? Our ego is wounded? Or are we hurt?

Kids don’t have that. They have an unconditional love and optimism that is so pure and real. One that doesn’t get bogged down by “whose right” or “who said sorry” and an authenticity that surpasses ego. They have an ability to move past things and be led by love. It’s really so beautiful and something I want to preserve, it doesn’t mean they’ll get walked all over, it means they’ll be forgiving, empathetic, and won’t weave their egos into other peoples “stuff.” 

I want to keep their ability to move past things. 

I think the inability to move past something our child does is based on one (or all) of three things. None of these reasons are outlandish. They’re all human nature to a degree, but to what degree? The first step is figuring out, as best we can “why can’t I move on right now, why does my stomach and throat feel this tense and my brain feel this mad?”

This line should be banished. When we get a position we didn’t want, do we just accept that? When we get treated a certain way, do we just accept that? Do we just swallow it and settle? Not my girls. This morning I told Nell “the Elsa costumes are just for at home” she responded “Actually, every people wears Elsa dresses when they’re 3” the argument had zero validity but was just amazing she was trying to make a case. I want to raise my girls to make a case for themselves, especially when it comes to their feelings. 

I told the story in this reel last night during the RIE webinar I co-led because a parent asked what she should do with a situation at her child’s school. She told us that when she asked her child’s teacher how they get the children to cooperate during transitions, the teacher told her that they tell the kids “we’re going to leave without you!” This mom asked us what to do. I said to be the louder voice. Find a way to remind your child that people say different things and sometimes things that don’t make sense. I hope this child responds next time and says “but you won’t leave without me, so why are you saying you will?” 

You want to argue for using these lines? I’ll argue back that there are a thousand other things to say to a child to support them instead of lines like this.

Be. The. Louder. Voice. 
So that THEIR voice is the loudest when it needs to be.

What a morning.

Nell didn’t want to go to school. It took everything in me not to just leave without say bye. Saying bye to our kids is hard and sometimes we’re tempted to ghost them. I very much still get tempted! But that’s easier for us, not them. I have had endless conversations with caregivers, babysitters and family about why I refuse to just leave without saying bye. ⁣
⁣
“Yes yes I know it makes things harder now but I 𝐚𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 say bye.”⁣
⁣
If matt leaves without saying bye I ask him to come back. If a parent uses the bathroom during class I ask them to tell their baby. Or I say “mommy is going to the bathroom and is coming right back.”⁣
⁣
I’m here to say the Irish exit is very overrated. ⁣
⁣
Another thing that seems easier - not telling our kids about tough things. When Tess was 2, I debated if I had to mention that our nanny wasn’t coming back when we parted ways. She seemed so young I just didn’t think it was necessary. Until I reminded myself, “Tess is a person! Am I actually fooling myself into thinking she’d just forget this person. Even if she can’t express it why do I want her to think people just disappear?”⁣
⁣
There’s nothing more rewarding than my girls saying “bye mama! See you later!” Or hearing them rehash something that happened that was tough. Every gut wrenching goodbye and every tough conversation, unsure if they really understood, is worth it because of what they gain: 𝐒𝐞𝐜𝐮𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐲.

Something I learned once I became a mom, was just how much harder it is to be a longer term parent vs a short term fixing parent.

Being the long term parent, is never the easier way. You’ll sometimes feel like the “bad guy” or question “why does this matter? It takes so much longer this way.” But you’ll see it’s worth one day. One of my favorite parenting quotes below 👇

“One day your child will make a mistake or a bad choice and run to you instead of away from you and in that moment you will know the immense value of peaceful, positive, respectful parenting.”
- L.R. Knost

I was inspired to write this because I have found myself using absolute words like this recently. Especially in the morning. “You guys never get dressed in time!” or “We’re always late!” Maybe because I’m feeling more weight and things are just feeling more extreme and intense but really? No human is always or nothing of anything. We shouldn’t make our children feel like they’re never or always anything. 

When we use terms like “you’re always this” or “you’re never that”

We create a dynamic of defensiveness and resistance. 
We close doors to openness and learning. 
We corner children into feeling they are always or never of something. 
Eventually, they may even stop trying to be anything else because they’re convinced that we truly believe they’re always or never doing something anyway. 

It’s important to try to figure out the ways to make it feel like something isn’t “always” or “never.” Figure this out with your child  when you’re not in the heat of the moment. 

Also, brainstorm! If you realize that every morning is so hard for your child to “listen” , put a plan in place. One thing I do is I put out some different toys each night so that my girls spend less time searching for something to play with while I make breakfast. I also have the most magical toothbrush for resistant tooth brushers that I found when I heard myself wanting to say “you always do this when its time to brush your teeth!”

Remember that if it feels like we’re always struggling with something then it means our child is too.

This morning as I dropped off the girls at school, one of the parents asked if I had seen the journal entry from the week. The teachers send out journal entries emailing us about wonderful things our kids do, it’s so thoughtful with photos and documentation. It’s one of the reasons I chose this nursery school. I realized I hadn’t even looked in weeks. Then I remembered how I used to look religiously during Tess’s first year….Then I went down the spiral.

I was going to start this caption listing the things I used to do that seem to have fallen off my parenting radar. I started with how I barely cook, I barely read books to them at night, and then I stopped. It wasn’t productive or rational to pine for mom behaviors of mine that are no longer - especially because I think those behaviors have been filled with even more valuable ones. My children who once were, are now the children that they’ve become. We have all changed and grown together. 

The rest of this caption is a sentiment I have shared before that is worth sharing over and over. 

We’ll sometimes miss the parent we were. Think we should be the parent we were. Feel guilty that we’re not the parent that we once were. 

We compare ourselves to other moms, but even harder, we compare ourselves to the other mom versions of ourselves. 

I’m just not the same mom I was to my first daughter that I am to my two daughters. 

But then I remember this conversation I had with 2 of my mom friends.

I said “It’s funny because if our second child was a better eater, we would think it was because we didn’t get as caught up but if they were a worse eater we’d say it was because we didn’t get to focus as much as we did on our first child.”

Meaning that our child could get the same amount of attention in this area of development and it could go either way, but we’d still think that whatever way it went was a reflection of us. 

I cooked from scratch and ate every meal with my first born, Tess. She was a terrible eater. I barely had time to eat with Nell, she was a better eater. Now? I’m tempted to say there are both good and bad eaters but then I realize - aren’t we all? We’re all humans who are changing and growing.

As I was getting ready to go out tonight I realized how many times I responded to the girls by saying “one second!” 

Once I noticed, I adjusted. 

Here’s how and why. 

Say “I hear you.”

Our children aren’t always looking for us to stop everything for them. They may think they want that but we’d be surprised by how much they can self-regulate when we can’t stop everything for them and we say “I hear you.”

Say “it’s hard to wait.”

This is what I like to say more for those that are observing the discomfort our children are experiencing when we can’t drop everything. 

When other adults try to distract, rescue or rush to end the tough experience of having to wait for us. I’ll say “I know it’s hard to wait.”

It sort of signals “that’s what this is about, waiting is hard! for all of us” and reminds everyone that the world cannot and should not always stop for our children.

Actually saying what you’re doing.
“I’m just finishing putting on Nellie’s dress and then I will be there.”
“I have 5 more minutes of this phone call and then I can answer you.”  

Children rely on our responses this way instead of asking over and over because we keep saying “one second” over and over. 

This also helps children to understand why we can’t drop everything for them at any given moment. They see or hear what we are doing.

And furthermore, do we want our children to always have such a hard time when other people can’t just drop everything for them?

Try getting rid of “one second” and you’ll actually be able to breathe.

I had a weekend of me schlepping downstairs at all hours to wash our linens since Nell had a stomach bug. This morning was rough because it was one of those mornings where I was waiting to unload some of it with at least Tess at school and she was just seemingly impossible. 

Do you ever wonder if you should worry when your child laughs or won’t say they’re sorry when they upset someone?

Why they won’t say happy birthday to another child because they’re upset that it’s not their birthday? 

Or when your child pushes your other sick child and calls them stupid and then tells you they don't want to live at home anymore?

Don’t you want to just say “imagine how that feels for him/her/me?”

Here’s why we shouldn’t and why these things do not mean that our child is self centered, ill mannered or unempathetic. 

Our children are developing their own sense of emotions and figuring out how they feel. Until they can really sort through that, they can’t genuinely imagine how others feel. Both are developing at the same time but we often focus so much on how our children impact others with little focus on how they’re grappling with their own feelings simultaneously. 

Sometimes I do this exercise after a rough experience with my girls, where I imagine what my children may have been going through in their mind. Because isn’t that what we want to ask our children to do sometimes? we want to just say “imagine how I feel!!!!” 

Well wanna know how children learn to imagine how others feels? When we imagine how they feel. 

Scroll to read what I imagine was going through Tess’s mind this morning and why I bit my tongue before saying “Tess imagine how I feel! Imagine how Nell feels!” Because taking on the perspective of others is a process that takes years of feeling safe, secure and 𝘴𝘦𝘦𝘯 with a child’s own emotions.

Our children will come to us wanting what their friends have. “I want an Elsa backpack because L has one” or “R has a spiderman lunch box, I want one too.”⁣
⁣
The easier response is to just say “Ok I’ll get that for you.” ⁣
⁣
But here’s why we shouldn’t always lean into that:⁣
⁣
Think of when our children don’t make a sports team even though their best friend does, or someone gets a better grade or lands a job they wanted - all of these things will probably happen. What voice do we want our children to have when these things happen? ⁣
⁣
We want our children to tell themselves something besides “I need what he/she has.” ⁣
⁣
I didn’t have a Barbie dreamhouse growing up and without that I made the most incredible houses that I created myself with materials I found in the house. I feel like those creations have led to my creations I make today at Union Square Play. ⁣
⁣
I didn’t have the body my friends had when I was in intermediate school. I was late to mature. I got padded bras and bikinis and layered my tights to hide my chicken legs in cheerleading. None of those tactics led to anything except feeling “incomplete” without a body I didn’t have. ⁣
⁣
When our child wants something that someone else has we want to help our children feel validated, that we understand their want, but we also want to help our child to feel whole even without the desired “thing.” The more we just try to solve their desire for something by just getting that thing, the more we stay on the treadmill that we eventually won’t be able to keep up with but more so, that our children can’t keep up with. ⁣
⁣
This reel gives examples of responses - 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐲 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥 𝐚𝐰𝐤𝐰𝐚𝐫𝐝 𝐛𝐞𝐜𝐚𝐮𝐬𝐞 𝐰𝐞’𝐫𝐞 𝐬𝐨 𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐟𝐢𝐱𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐝𝐞𝐬𝐢𝐫𝐞, 𝐰𝐞 𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐧’𝐭 𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐭 𝐬𝐢𝐭.⁣
⁣
The goal is letting it sit, getting our child to say to themselves⁣:

“Everyone has different things, everyone is different.”⁣
“Who I am inside doesn’t change with what I have or wear.”⁣
“I only want to be the me I am.  love who I am just as I am and with what I have.”⁣
⁣
and above all else: 𝐚𝐜𝐜𝐞𝐩𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞.⁣

Your child loses. They run to you crying and angry. ⁣
⁣
Most of us try to convince our child out of this, or try to fix it, we try to focus on 𝘯𝘦𝘹𝘵 𝘵𝘪𝘮𝘦. ⁣
⁣
Instead of trying to “fix” a loss - we can just supportively and empathetically say: ⁣
⁣
“You 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 wanted to win, I know you did.” ⁣
⁣
How else can we teach children good sportsmanship - help our child be the one on a losing team who is 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 shaking the other opponents hands at the end of a game? Be one of the people who actually looks each opposing player in the eye and authentically smiles vs looks down while swiping a bunch of hands? ⁣
⁣
𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐞𝐟𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐭.⁣
⁣
”I saw how hard you were working out there!”⁣
⁣
 𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐧 𝐟𝐮𝐧.⁣
⁣
”When you were running I saw how big you smiled! It looked like you were having the best time!” ⁣
⁣
“Besides when you won, what was your favorite part of the game?”⁣
⁣
𝐄𝐱𝐩𝐨𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 𝐭𝐨 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐦𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥 𝐥𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠.⁣
⁣
Rethink some of those head starts. Or if you use them now and then, please let them loose sometimes. And when 𝐲𝐨𝐮 lose, model how to lose by talking out loud:⁣
⁣
”Uch! I worked so hard and still lost! Oh well. I know there will be another time and wow I saw how fast YOU ran!” ⁣
⁣
𝐏𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐛𝐞𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐚 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:⁣
⁣
”Let’s call your friend and wish her good luck!”⁣
⁣
”Let’s talk about how it may feel to win and how it may feel to lose.”⁣
⁣
”I want you to know I’ve seen how hard you’ve been working and I am excited to watch you play.”

I tried something. ⁣
⁣
I’m gonna call it radical parenting:⁣
⁣
We had a week of sickness and non sickness and then sickness again. A long week of trying to balance it all with days of no school and big decision making as a family for next year and life and all of it.⁣
⁣
Let’s just say I was very ready for the weekend. And last nights bedtime couldn’t come soon enough. Matt and I had no plans and we couldn’t wait to finally have time to ourselves. We got home from a birthday party and the girls were off. the. wall. I tried to fight it at first. I was frustrated, bitter, exhausted, and done. But something crossed my mind when I was literally aching and bending down to try to control and pick up my 5 year old to put her in bed, my 5 year old who has the longest body imagineable and who was wiggling and laughing and so frustrating - I thought of myself years from now wishing for and aching for that exact moment.⁣
⁣
I thought “what’s the worst that happens if I meet them where they are right now and be in this happy off-the -wall mood with them?” I reminded myself this isn’t habit forming, this isn’t never ending, this isn’t not holding boundaries, it’s a moment of good that I’m letting my girls be contagious with. I let them infect me with their joy. ⁣
⁣
Maybe I embraced it bc I knew they were going to Matt’s moms today, but isn’t this something we should be doing more often? Like radically do the opposite when we feel ourselves going down an anger spiral? I know it sounds easier said than done, but remember this post next time u feel in that moment of “I’m on fire I’m so frustrated with them!”⁣
⁣
The outcome was one of those night when both girls had separate moments with me where I knew they were almost thinking “𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘪𝘴 𝘵𝘰𝘰 𝘨𝘰𝘰𝘥 𝘵𝘰 𝘣𝘦 𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘦” but that actually was so so true. ⁣
⁣
Today, I have no kids crying for me, I did my favorite workout and have a date night with friends to look forward to, but radically, I miss them.

“The balance is almost impossible because no matter how you look at it, work is always something that’s going to rob you of time with your child. That’s the currency now, that’s where it goes. The magnitude of how much it weighs.” - In the words of @badgalriri in an interview about motherhood.⁣
⁣
But it’s not just work, it’s the balance of 𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘺𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 and motherhood. When do we decide to do something for ourselves without feeling like it’s sacrificing time with our child? A date night instead of a bedtime? A shower instead of an extra bedtime story? Going to use the bathroom and leaving our baby crying for a few minutes?⁣
⁣
It’s a million micro decisions every single day of “should I do X or not do X because of my child.” ⁣
⁣
I almost didn’t make it to this photo shoot last week. My girls were sick and it felt like everything was working against going. ⁣
⁣
I showed up to the shoot a total mess and had forgotten my make up which doesn’t really matter but for a photo shoot - I kind of cared. But I walked into what felt like the best kind of slumber party. These girls were exchanging clothes and accessories and anecdotes of the same kind of morning as me. It was a total of 45 minutes but in those 45 minutes I wasn’t making any micro decisions (besides my lip color, thank you @svenja.ostwald !). I wasn’t with my kids and I wasn’t “working” and for once, I didn’t feel like I had to consider whether or not those 45 minutes were “worth” leaving my kids for. ⁣
⁣
Because I thought about what I would tell Tess and Nell - I’d say “you know how you get so excited for a play date with a friend? Well that’s what I had this morning, a play date, a play date with a lot of mommy friends.” I can’t imagine them not understanding the absolute necessity of an occasional playdate. ⁣
⁣
And it must be said that some of the time without your child 𝐢𝐬𝐧’𝐭 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐫𝐨𝐛𝐛𝐞𝐝 - it’s time that makes you show back up as the mom you want to be, the mom that isn’t robbed of the ability to breathe easier.⁣
⁣
#GalentinesDay with @michellerosephoto @minimelanienyc @esquarednyc ⁣

This is dedicated to my Nell.⁣
⁣
The one who knocks me off my feet 𝘥𝘢𝘺 𝘢𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘥𝘢𝘺. ⁣
⁣
The reason my life feels like it has to stop just to get through each hill of her emotions. ⁣
⁣
The one who holds onto any way she can, to control her uncontrollable world.⁣
⁣
This week feels like a year already mostly because of her. ⁣
⁣
But the highlight, I keep reminding myself, is when she yelled through tears “𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐦𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐲, 𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐦 𝐝𝐨𝐰𝐧!!” ⁣
⁣
and who decided after a week of refusal, to finally use the potty when I said “let’s take our time, let’s just be together and see what happens” - basically 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐰𝐡𝐨 𝐥𝐞𝐭 𝐠𝐨 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐲 𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐝𝐢𝐝 𝐭𝐨𝐨.⁣
⁣
These children, they’re going to change the world, 𝘸𝘦 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘭𝘦𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮.⁣
⁣
My advice: stop trying to control them, they’re seeming desire to resist, control, and anything else is actually them screaming out “𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐝, 𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐬𝐞𝐞𝐧….𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐞𝐱𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐥𝐲 𝐦𝐞.”⁣
⁣
Words by @jessurlichs_writer

This morning at drop off Nell was so excited for school. She always is. As we were waiting for the teachers to come out to walk her friends and her into class and she just started crying 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦. To everyone around us, including her teachers, it just seemed like a sudden outburst of “I don’t want to go to school.” Or one of those “𝘴𝘩𝘦 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘳𝘵𝘦𝘥 𝘤𝘳𝘺𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦.” ⁣
⁣
But Nell has taught and reminded me over and over that no one “𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘴 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦.”⁣
⁣
So I took her aside and kneeled down and said “what’s wrong?” She said “I want to go home, I want to go home.” Again, seemed like she just wanted to go home, right? I said, “I hear you, but what happened, 𝐰𝐡𝐲 do you think you want to go home?” She said “to get my Elsa toy!” I looked up, and sure enough, her best friend was holding a shiny Elsa doll. ⁣
⁣
This seems kind of insignificant right? But the significance occurred to me later on when I was in conversation with someone and realized the tendency for us to sometimes believe that “𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯 𝘤𝘳𝘺 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘯𝘰 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘴𝘰𝘯.” They don’t. If they 𝘴𝘦𝘦𝘮 to “𝘤𝘳𝘺 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦” or “𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘯𝘰 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘴𝘰𝘯” let’s give the time, as much as we can, to kneel down, piece together the puzzle, and try to figure out why. Even if we can’t figure it out, we’ll no longer tend to think or dumb down situations to be “𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘥 𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘯𝘰𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦.”⁣
⁣
The thought process of believing a child cries for no reason, will not allow you to spend the time and energy on “trying to figure it out.” My hope is that once you read this, the next time you, your spouse, a grandparent, a baby sitter, a nanny, a teacher says “and then she just cried for no reason” or “I don’t know what’s wrong, she cried out of nowhere” that you’ll be able to respond and say “well there’s always a reason, but maybe it just wasn’t obvious or is hard to figure out, let’s try!” and together, you start to learn more about your child. ⁣
⁣
It’s not about always knowing why, it’s about believing 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 𝐢𝐬 𝐚 𝐰𝐡𝐲. ⁣
