When our children are faced with a brand new experience we most often resort to one of two mindsets.⁣
⁣
1. Dread: we believe it’s doomed and it’s going to be so hard that we approach it this way. When our child begins to protest or whine we are already ready to throw in the towel because “we knew it would be miserable.” ⁣
2. Unrealistic optimism: we have looked forward to and fantasized about these experiences and often remember them in our own childhoods as such wonderful times, and we’re disappointed, wounded and disheartened when our child doesn’t embrace it the way we remember we did.⁣
⁣
I’m proposing a third mindset. ⁣
⁣
3. Open and Prepared: we try our best to have no expectation other than “let’s see how this goes!” In order to set my child up for success I should prepare them - not overly to cause anxiety, but just ahead of time in a real but positive way. The goal isn’t forcing my child into this experience but 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘰𝘴𝘪𝘯𝘨 them to it.⁣
⁣
Next time you or your spouse is about to bring energy to an experience ask yourselves this: ⁣
⁣
“How do I want to impact the way my child experiences the world?” ⁣

One of my friends wrote to me that her 3.5 year old has been hitting “out of nowhere.” She has three kids, her youngest is 1 and I knew they may have meant a new walker in the house.

One of the things we may not realize when it comes to siblings is the impact one sibling’s development has on another sibling’s emotions. 

Starting with an infant entering the family. Our other child feels confused about this change. Even if they are showing affection towards their sibling, inside they are grappling with “Is my parent still my parent if they are also the parent to this new baby?”

Then the infant starts to crawl one day. What was once a sibling who just stayed in a bassinet, crib, in grown ups arms, and spent time on a floor in one place, now becomes more of a mobile being getting into our other child’s belongings, distracting parents with their mobility. This is when we may see more regressions in our older children. It’s a new birth. 

Then this crawling child starts to take steps. The whole family cheers and celebrates. Our older children now truly see their sibling as an actual human being. This comes with a whole wave of threats and emotions too. 

All this to say, there are many births, transitions, acceptances that our children go through when it comes to siblings. It continues throughout life not just at birth. It’s our job to be attuned to this and to talk about the changes that come with new milestones and developments.

Notice your older child during these new milestones your infant is accomplishing.

Some things we can say:

“Wow, doesn’t it feel different now that your sister is crawling?! We put her down in one spot and then she’s across the room! How does that feel for you?”

And reassuring them with one important reminder:

“You know that I am always your parent and love you very much. I am also your sibling’s parent and love them very much too. I am a parent to both of you. Forever and ever.”

It’s rough out there some nights. Tonight, I tried to skip pages during bedtime. 
⁣
 “No one has more on their to-do list than a toddler at bedtime.” ⁣
⁣
and we can add “no one is more antsy than a parent who just wants to say goodnight.”

It’s funny, sure, but let’s acknowledge that when children are stalling, they may pick up on our rushing them to bed.
⁣
Sleep consultants may skip ahead to the boundary setting around this, which is very important, valuable and necessary, but, before that, we need to make sure we know that the child who is stalling, asking for more books, doing never ending rituals and requests is the child who is saying:⁣
⁣
“I’m anxious, I don’t want to say bye for the night just yet,
can you slow down and help me?”
⁣
I think about when I’m saying bye to someone I don’t want to say bye to, like my family members, I find reasons to keep talking to drag out the goodbye (at least we do this in my family) because it’s hard to say bye!⁣
⁣
When a child is stalling before bedtime we can easily assume it’s them trying to just annoy us and then we respond with a shorter fuse (we’re human, we’re counting down those moments til our relaxed glass of wine!) and then their need to connect becomes 𝘦𝘷𝘦𝘯 𝘨𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘳, and bedtime can easily come crashing down to an utter disaster, and take. even. longer. 🤯😳
⁣
So what can we do instead? Take a deep breath, realize that this will take a lot shorter amount of time if we give our child what they need, and get ready to hunker down, for just a little longer. ⁣
⁣
I used to say to Tess “It sounds like you don’t want to go to bed yet, huh? Should we read an extra book?” I just mentally tell myself to slow down and incorporate connecting moments. ⁣Here’s a glimpse of the reality of that and how even though I preach this, I sometimes try to take short cuts too 🤷🏻‍♀️ #wereallhuman

Sometimes we get so used to correcting our children that we do it without even thinking.

Sometimes we don’t know what else to do or say to our children without reflexively correcting.

I made this reel for this purpose and couldn’t keep a straight face because it felt so inauthentic to respond to my child with a correction when she was telling me she bumped her head. Why do we feel that’s a teaching moment? Why do we put correction before all else sometimes? 

Our children will love us unconditionally, but when they have heard us correcting them endlessly that turns into self correction. That turns into a self deprecation before self acceptance. 

So before you find yourself correcting your child ask yourself “do I really need to correct right now? Do I really need to make this a lesson? Or can I show my child unconditional love first?” 

When we spend our child’s earliest years correcting them, it won’t change their love for us, but it may change their love for themselves.

No one can possibly appreciate and be in every single moment even when we ache because we wish we could. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
This week I’m anxious because I know I am missing bedtimes and school picks ups and that I am spread thinner than most weeks. I know that both the girls and I feel a big difference from last week when they were on school break. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
We all feel some version of this generalized guilt and ache when we have less time or when the time we do have feels more strained. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
So I made a reel on some tools to use when you want to really fill that small amount of time with so much.⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
𝗪𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐥𝐨𝐯𝐞. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
1. I will say out of nowhere “I love listening to your voice.” Whether they’re singing or talking. So often my girls sing and it can become background noise. Or, admittedly, it can become irritating. I can imagine how nice it feels when once in a while during their mindless singing at home during play or in the car, I stop and say “I really love the sound of your voice.” If they’re telling a story, I’ll sometimes say “I love hearing you talk!”⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣
2. I will ask out of nowhere “I wonder what pictures are in your brain right now - can you name some?”⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Sometimes it’s hard to engage with your child, sometimes they don’t respond with  much when you ask them a general question, asking them if there are pictures in their brain helps to connect a child’s thoughts with words. Even if they are just saying words instead of sentences, it gives you a window into their mind. 𝘐𝘵 𝘤𝘰𝘯𝘯𝘦𝘤𝘵𝘴 𝘺𝘰𝘶. ⁣⁣⁣
	⁣⁣⁣
3. Rose and Thorn. This is an exercise you may have heard. “What was your rose today?” My business partner uses it and we use it for our crew meetings. It is so fun to do this using words that your child will love. Sometimes I’ll say to Tess “Ok so tell me, what was your Elsa moment?! Or what felt like a Cruella De Vill moment today?”⁣⁣⁣

4. Just say “It’s the best to watch you play!” 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐣𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐰𝐚𝐭𝐜𝐡.⁣

𝐁𝐞𝐜𝐚𝐮𝐬𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥 𝐥𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐝, 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥 𝐬𝐞𝐞𝐧 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐝 𝐟𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭.⁣⁣⁣

As mentioned, this week has been busy and I’ve had to miss a few bedtimes. This morning, I got to see the girls for the first time in 24 hrs but knew I had to bye again for the day. Nell had nature day at school in the park so she needed to be dressed super warm. I planned for her to wear this new gloriously soft sweater jacket as an extra layer. This sweater is literally a dream, like Nell would have had a hug all day at the park if she had this layer. Basically alll my mom guilt was wrapped into this sweater. 

I could not find it. I couldn’t let it go. I couldn’t leave without looking in “one more place.”

Until I finally had to let it go to get them to school on time. It was hard to do honestly. Tess had hers on but my Nellie didn’t. No one would have understood this need for Nell’s sweater. You may not even understand it reading it. 

I do know what you would understand -  when you’re feeling off, and you have to drag yourself to a dinner and you want to wear your favorite pair of jeans. But you can’t find them. 

That’s what our children feel each time they fixate on something seemingly small. When they can’t leave the house on time. When they can’t get dressed. When their pancake isn’t the right size. It’s the case of the missing jeans. Something feels very necessary and real and urgent about it even if no one understands why. 

I have had 39 years to grapple with this feeling and I can tell you that if anyone said to me this morning “come on we have to go, it’s not a big deal” I would have wanted to cry lol. What I would have wanted was someone to come over and say “I’m not sure why you want this sweater so badly but I see  that something about it feels very important to you. Even if we can’t find it, I want you to know I will help you look when we have more time. I’m here to give you a hug if you want it.”

Before you approach your child with the belief that they’re being “silly” or “dramatic,” try to connect with them instead, and tell yourself:

“This is a big deal to my child, even if I don’t understand why.”

This is for the parents of toddlers to teens. 

We’ve been having some challenges with lying over here.

Without getting in full depth, scroll for what lying is about and what you can say to help your child through it.

No matter how old your child is, no matter what relationship your in, when there’s dishonesty, it’s a sign there’s something to work on, not a sign you need to teach through fear or shame.

This morning Nell spilled syrup on her dress and immediately went from calm to extremely dysregulated. Screaming out of frustration and in tears. She said “I don’t like to eat breakfast! This is why I want a smoothie!” I responded “it feels so frustrating for you right now that you got syrup on your dress! I know that feeling!” To which she said “but you never spill syrup on your dress!”

I could’ve continued and said I have, I spill all the time, I grew up being nicknamed “the spiller” and I have said that before. But want to know what else we can do to help our children feel human in these millions of human moments?

Model when versions of them happen to us.

Our child can’t get the blocks to stack without falling, they scream, they spill a tiny drop of syrup, they can’t put their shoes on, and we often dive in to help as quick as possible. But what about helping our child with these things preemptively. Modeling that they happen to all of us in between them happening to them. 

Our children look to us as their compass in life. When we only show perfection or only show frustration that permeates. Let’s show human. 

*and if you’re someone or married to someone who also needs help with frustration tolerance, use this for them (or you) too. Never forget it. You are your child’s model.

Before I left for dinner tonight, the girls were so engaged in play - completely immersed that they barely felt it when it was time for me to go. I was also miraculously able to get ready on time! Something that hasn’t happened in FOREVER. I attribute all of this to the fact that I have had this rejuvenated interest in their play and what effort I have put into their materials. 

Last night, for the first time in forever, I was organizing their toys and thinking of things to put out for them to play with in the morning. I thought of Tess and how much she loves to build with blocks. Then I thought about how she’s going to kindergarten in the fall. Do Kindergarten classrooms have block sets? Are blocks replaced with smart boards? Do imaginative play nooks become coding corners? 

Will she be playing for much longer? How long until she doesn’t plop on the floor at the sight of something intriguing at any given moment? Will play like this engage her and her imagination for another year? month? …..week? 

I do know that when we stop valuing and treasuring play and imagination, 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘥𝘰 𝘵𝘰𝘰. I don’t think I’ll ever miss their last play because I’m going to do whatever I can to make sure they play forever. 

P.S. Don’t forget to find 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 play too.

If you ever bump into me - you’ll see me with my hands full like you see in many of these photos. But I think these photos/clips also embody who I am as a woman today: so much strength.⁣

I want to show my girls that to be a woman means to be strong. Not only physically strong, but strong enough to show my emotions (not strong enough NOT to) and strong enough to believe in who I really am. 
⁣⁣
I can’t say that I was always confident or quintessentially “strong.” In fact, I was seemingly the opposite, an insecure child, sensitive, unsure, and very shy. ⁣⁣But that takes a certain kind of strength too. To survive and cope with those feelings.
⁣⁣
On international women’s day, I want us to celebrate all women. All versions of ourselves. From our childhood selves to our present selves, how far we’ve come, how far we still have to grow. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I also want to celebrate my daughters. Their assertiveness, their ability to show emotion, their intensity, their passion, and even their difficult-ness. The women they’ll grow up to be, however hard it is to get there. It’s always gonna be hard to be a woman sometimes. Especially deeply feeling, strong women. I get it. I think we all do. 

#internationalwomensday #iwd2023 #raisestrongwomen #raiserealwomen

“You’re not listening to me.” I wanted to say it 800 times tonight before the girls left for a sleepover at grandmas.

But I didn’t because since when did “not obeying” become every parents perception of “not listening?”

Listening means hearing. When our children don’t do what we say that does not equate that they “aren’t listening.” 

Ways to rethink “not listening” include:

Talk about what it means to “listen.” Both to your child and to yourself and other caregivers. Listening is hearing, not following orders. 

every time you reflexively think “my child isn’t listening” remember that you’re really saying “my child isn’t obeying” and it will force you to reapproach the situation more productively. 

Start to adjust your responses when your child is having a hard time cooperating, see your child and tell them you see them “you really want to keep watching tv, i can see that, you have 2 more minutes and then i’m going to turn it off” instead of “come to bed, no more tv” and then saying our child “isnt’ listening” when they don’t just obey that task. 

Think about what it takes to get on the same page with any human when there is a consistent challenge in a relationship - it takes connection and problem solving. When something isn’t working (your child consistently has a hard time cooperating in the morning or before bedtime) change the routine and include your child. Diffuse the prior wiring that your child had. I imagine my child is subconsciously thinking something like “I wake up, this is when mommy orders me to do things and I don’t want to do them because I’m nervous for school and this is when I assert myself and don’t cooperate” and then I think of how that can be replaced with something like: “Mommy and I made a new routine plan last night, I’m gonna wake up and do it with her! We said we’d wake up, pick one of the outfits we laid out together last night and then I’m going to brush my teeth all by myself while she does! This is fun to do this with mommy and to feel like I’m helping us both. I’m such a big girl!”

Some of us have children who are passionate and outspoken. Some of us have children whose minds are running faster than their words can come out. Some of us have children who have a hard time getting our attention because we are overwhelmed, preoccupied and distracted. There are a variety of reasons why children may seem like they are yelling at us but I want to reframe and believe that these children are yelling for us. For us to hear them, see them, and more than anything, help them. These children need help. 
⁣⁣⁣⁣
We can help a child learn how to respect people and to learn not to yell without reflexively responding “ask nicely” which can often further dysregulation. We can set boundaries around tone in a way that still connects us to children. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
What if a 3 yr old came up to you at a party and said “I am nervous in this new place with all of these people and want to feel connected to you. I just want to be taken care of right now.” ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
But we have to ask ourselves, would a 3 year old EVER be able to express all of that? Probably not. It probably would come out like this:⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Nell pulling at me every second I talked to any parent at a playdate on Saturday. Nell screaming “I’M HUNGRY I WANT A CUPCAKE!” 
⁣⁣⁣⁣
There’s two ways we can react to this:⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
“Nell! Shhh! Ask nicely!” which then creates another layer of emotion.⁣⁣⁣⁣

Which she could internalize as:

“Oh no I did something wrong and I’m so dysregulated and I don’t think Mommy heard me because she is just telling me that I’m not asking nicely. I must be feeling something I shouldn’t feel, I must be bad. I want to yell even louder!!⁣⁣⁣”⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Or we can say:⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
“Okay! I hear you! Sounds like you really want some help! You know you can also ask me to help, you can say “will you help me please! I really want help!” ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
Which she could internalize as:

“I feel seen and heard. I am learning to ask for help in a way that is respectful but my emotions are real and are accepted. I am a good child. I’m just having a tough time.⁣⁣⁣”⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
A child who yells doesn’t equate a child who is rude, it equates a child who is in need. ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣

It’s only Tuesday, how many public meltdowns have you had this week?

I put into words the thoughts I try to remember when I’m in the throes of it.

Tune of your choice.

Nell has been afraid of swimming for awhile and I never made the time to do this exercise with her. I finally did yesterday and it helped immensely.

Because just saying “there’s nothing to be scared of!” really doesn’t help a child with their fear. It can create more fear because they feel even more alone and disconnected. Sort of “no one understands” feeling. Instead, we can go through scenarios and join them in their fear. Validate and connect. We want to help them access and explore what’s happening inside but then we also want to help prepare them for those feelings when they happen in the future. 

I learned that Nell’s fear comes from the feeling she gets when water goes up her nose. She expressed it with “it makes me feel sick.” So we prepared her for what she can do when she goes under water to avoid this feeling, we empowered her to blow out of her nose and hold her breath.

Experience helps to lessen fear. If we can prepare our child for what it may feel like to be in their feared experience but equip them with tools when in that experience - that feels more empowering to me than basically saying “don’t be silly - there’s nothing to fear” which I imagine probably adds some version of “what’s wrong with me” in the moment of the actual fear.

My goal when my child is scared of something is to help them access “Ok I went through this before!” or “ok I talked about this feeling with mommy and I have a tool!” 

Remember this: If a child is afraid, then there is something to be afraid of. Yes, even if the fear is monsters in the closet, take out a magic cape that “scares the monsters away!” before night time comes. The goal is tools to equip our child with tools, not to convince them out of a very real feeling. 

This is how we learn about our child. Not how we make them doubt the validity of their feelings.

I went on a journey with Tess after school yesterday.I picked her up from school and as we were reunited, I saw her stop and stare. She saw her two close friends leaving together for a playdate. 

It brought up so much in my heart. One of the first memories I have of social challenges is when my two best friends would “leave me out” as a kid. It was three of us, I was part of the leaving out too, but when I was the odd one out, gosh it sucked. 

So when I saw Tess stare off I wanted to take her heart, pump it up with a magic juice that made her think “That looks fun! I’m going to go home now with my mom but good for them!” but how do we do that? 

I knew asking her directly how she felt would have made her shut down. So I took her with me on an afternoon fill of errands (you don’t need to do this, but the rest is something that matters more) As the situation felt “less fresh” I said “Tess I want to tell you a story” and I told her how my friends had a sleepover one night without me when I was younger and asked her how she thought that felt for me. 

Together we answered some questions that I knew would help her. She reflected on it with me and we figured out that it didn’t mean my friends didn’t love me, it didn’t mean anything was wrong with me, and that sometimes were part of play dates and parties and sometimes we aren’t.

Here’s my takeaways:
Tell your children if you’ve felt what they are feeling in a given moment, not to make the experience about you but to help your child process feelings that are really hard to grapple with. To normalize them. The moment we normalize them, the moment our children start facing them and coming to terms with them. The moment they begin to grow from them. 

Help your child to support themselves in tough situations. Give them questions they can ask and answer themselves “does this mean something is wrong with me? No! Does this mean they don’t love me? No!”

People matter - when our child feels a lack of connection somewhere - fill them with a connection but a human one. Not a toy, not a treat, not a bribe, but real human connection with someone.

I’m not crying, you’re crying.

I know Tess feels more deeply than some children. I know that’s a double edged sword. I also know that she can change the world, all of our kids can. Let’s raise them to change the world, to make wrong things right, to speak up and do something when it feels wrong. Let’s rewrite this book and all come hang with the giving tree K?

I’m one of those parents who has struggled with dinner time. My girls had often refused to sit for dinner. I know that my page is often filled with acknowledging and allowing feelings - and I get many messages that ask (and so many times I ask myself) 

How long is too long for feelings?

How much is too much?

I want to adjust this mindset with a tool that I use but that I also shared with my children this trip.

Think of every hard feeling as a tunnel. We shouldn’t try to skip or go around this tunnel, but ride through it.

When we do this, we will always come out the other side, and will all have experienced something that will help for next time. If you try to go around it, you may avoid this tunnel but there will always be another tunnel. 

What will you or your children do then?

But here’s the real game changer, when I shared this with my girls. They are 3 and 5 and it felt like they could understand and appreciate it. It felt like it would empower them. 

So yesterday I talked about how the nerves and experience of skiing is sort of like that. It can feel really new, different, cold, hard, grueling and uncomfortable at times but then you get through that tunnel of the hard stuff, the hard stuff doesn’t feel so hard, uncomfortable or scary anymore. 

Believe it or not, once you allow the tunnel it turns out being a lot shorter long term, than trying to avoid it all together. I’ll share more in stories how this helped us so much with everything so far - As Tess said “because there’s always a light at the end of a tunnel but you have to go through the tunnel to get there right Mama?”

#theresalwaysalightattheend

The clothes, the cold, the physical experience, the coordination, the logistics, the pep talks, the preparation, the travel, to get to this moment, the list is endless…

I’m crying while taking this video. It’s one of the moments I had imagined having with my kids one day and here it was happening and it was even better than I had imagined it would be. Not because I care about her skill as a skier or her skill in anything, but I care about experiencing life with her in the way feels right to her. 

I care that to get to this moment, it took SO much and that SHE got there. Not because I had a vision and wanted her to live it out but because along the way, every step of the way, it was what she wanted to do. Because of how thoughtfully Matt and I approached this experience - years in the making. Always encouraging our girls to try hard things, and to focus on the hard work, how it all feels, and not the end result of things. 

To get to any point in parenting where you are on the same page as another human being, is very hard work. I can tell you that skiing is just a metaphor for so much more. If one parent is parenting with respect for their child, preparing them, approaching hard experiences thoughtfully and checking in with their child - it matters if the other caregiver or parent is complaining along the way, bringing negative energy, saying “it’s too much” or being too pushy with their child, (or a million other examples). 

Matt and I didn’t agree on her skiing with us today. He thought she’d be too tired and I thought she would want to. We didn’t agree but we didn’t bring that energy to pick her up. It’s like we silently said to each other “we 𝘥𝘰𝘯’𝘵 have to agree on our expectations of pick up but we 𝘤𝘢𝘯 agree to see what Tess’s expectations are.” ⁣
⁣
and we did.⁣
⁣
and she flew :)

Everyone is brought up differently and has their own views. But with time and a lot of “wow this works” moments, it is possible to get on the same page. Not thru incessant nitpicking or calling eachother out in real time, but seeing how children respond in their toughest moments, even when our responses take longer than quick fixes. For us, putting in that effort to overcome our reflexive frustrations, to take the time to connect and figure out what’s underneath the behavior, has helped us 𝐚𝐥𝐥. 2 pieces of advice:⁣ 1. Be proactive instead of reactive. Build in time. We plan date nights right? Or we should. Bc unplugging and focusing entirely on another person is what life is about. Kids react to us, when we’re distracted and stressed, they feel disconnected and insecure. If you build in time for children to connect to their caregivers instead of muscling thru the whining, you help your child find grounding instead of experiencing them being clingy and feeling disconnected all day. It gives us perspective, instead of reacting to tantrums with frustration, you and your spouse start to do this emotional check in “hmmmm we 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 been super busy.” Make it a priority to be proactive 𝘣𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘦 everyone is running on empty. 2. You want everyone to be real: not for them to feel nervous, unsure or as if they can’t do anything right. Everyone should really believe in the approach they are taking. Kids can feel and see right through when our words don’t match our bodies. So when a partner is taking on your way of speaking to your child just to appease you, it may not be effective for anyone. They need to find their own way and we need to accept and be ok with that. We plant seeds but we can’t control the sun, water, and growth right? When I say that responsive parenting is contagious, I mean it with every fiber of my body - 𝘣𝘶𝘵 𝘪𝘵 𝘵𝘢𝘬𝘦𝘴 𝘵𝘪𝘮𝘦.  Lastly, this type of parenting helps you to stop feeling like you’re grasping at straws, putting out fires, nervous for the next tantrum - bc you feel prepared. Everyone needs someone who understands them. 𝗪𝐞 are those people for our children. If we don’t take the time to try to understand them, who will??⁣

The most amazing trip and yet every photo reminds me of a mini disaster that happened 🤣 

You know what’s so crazy to think about?

The amount of things that happen in a day, even in an hour that we get through as parents - things that before we were parents would feel insurmountable. But then we become seasoned in disasters - we realize that not only are they not the end of life but that they are a 𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐯𝐢𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐭 𝐨𝐟 𝐢𝐭. They don’t make us bad parents, I think they show that we are 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥 parents.

We can’t do it all. I don’t even know who invented that we could or made that something to aspire to. Something has always got to give. A ball always dropped somewhere, at least to be the parent I want to be. 

The thing I ask myself when any of these “dropped balls” happen is: “ok that happened and now what’s the worst case scenario as a result of that?” Usually the worst case scenario isn’t so bad and I think there is no worse case scenario than missing life with our kids because we’re so preoccupied with avoiding mistakes and distracted by meticulous planning and “being productive.” So if you forget a bag, forget bathing suits, lose a ski pass, show up late, choose a date night or day party with friends, none of it means you’re a bad parent, it means you’re a real one trying to show up as the parent you want to be. 

A scroll of one the most special weeks ever filled with so many special mini disasters turned magical adventures.

Anything I can do, you can do better….in the kitchen at least. 

So here are my desperate dinner hacks..maybe some will help you!

We just got back from Colorado yesterday which is two hours behind NYC. It may seem minimal but it means my girls think that 8 pm is 6 pm and that they could easily end up going to bed at 10 pm EST if I don’t fix this immediately. 

So I got home before they got back from a play date and thought of how I could get them to bed STAT. I started making their favorite turkey sliders - which requires a cut onion. I hate the smell of onion on my hands and teary eyes so I put on my gloves and sunglasses and took on a whole alter ego (maybe it means I need to spend more time in the kitchen 🤣🤷🏻‍♀️)

But all jokes aside - having dinner earlier and ready for overtired kids is a game changer. Otherwise they get home, they’re wired, they want to play and avoid any semblance of eating. Then they avoid every single bedtime step after that until suddenly they’re so over exhausted that they believe they want dinner and it’s now 8 p.m. 

I believe you have a literal 5 minute window to fit in dinner when you have exhausted children at the helm.

Transitioning them from coming in the door directly to the table ready with food is one thing, but having a smaller amount of food is always more helpful for my girls who get overwhelmed by overflowing plates of food. I use these animal and car picks because it makes the meal more fun. 

You may think that some of this seems overwhelming or as if I’m an over achieving parent but I assure you none of this was hard, I used microwavable pre cut broccoli - proudly. 

I also promise that I did all of this for me. I’m exhausted and it’s only been 24 hours since our family “vacation.” 

So this post is for any of you who feel guilty that bedtime can’t come soon enough. Just put on sunglasses and get lost in your mission. If I can do it, you can do it. 

Proud to say I can write this post all by 7 pm because the girls are fast asleep. 😉 😉

Do you want to know what is the strongest factor in how a child grows up to see themselves?⁣
⁣
How 𝐰𝐞 react to them. How we look up (or don’t) from our phone. When we delight in them. When we show them their worth. When we smile and show acceptance. When we actually see and hear them.  When we give them our time. That’s how it forms. ⁣
⁣
Your child looks 𝐭𝐨 𝐲𝐨𝐮 to know their worth. ⁣

Read that again. ⁣
⁣
Today I walked in the door midday not expecting to see anyone home. Stressed, disheartened by this week, ready to just destress for a second but Nell was home on her way out with my mom. I smiled but there was a sigh behind it. And it’s like Nell knew, knew I needed the reminder. She said:⁣
⁣
“Mama I so happy to see you!” ⁣
⁣
It brought me back to earth. It just felt so good to hear. ⁣
⁣
If we all said this more often to our children, they would know and believe that we feel lucky that we get to see them.  𝐓𝐡𝐞𝐲’𝐝 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐲 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐡𝐲. ⁣
⁣
I don’t even need to get into or talk about how much different the world would be or the importance of raising a child who feels they are worth being alive and that someone is happy to see them. 𝐒𝐚𝐲 𝐲𝐨𝐮’𝐫𝐞 𝐡𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐞𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦. ⁣

Sometimes you guys ask me “how do you not lose it on your kids?” or “do you ever yell?” and yes, I do. But my best advice is taking that time when you realize that you’re 𝐨𝐧 𝐚 𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐰𝐚𝐲 𝐩𝐚𝐭𝐡 𝐭𝐨 𝐲𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐨𝐫 𝐥𝐨𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐭. You don’t need to always jump into the fire if you know it’s there. I mean, yes you do if it’s just you, but when and if it doesn’t always have to be, take the few minutes. Hide in your room. Wait in the lobby. Sit in your car. Do. Not. Feel. Guilty. ⁣
⁣
So often we are made to feel guilty for needing space. That there’s something wrong with us if we decide to take space for ourselves.
⁣
I actually think it is the best lesson we can embody - thinking ahead of who we 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵 to be and not walking into just becoming the people we 𝘥𝘰𝘯’𝘵 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵 to be. If I walked into my apartment today and didn’t take the time to hide, sit and just be, I know I would not have shown up as the mom or person I would want to be. ⁣
⁣
Instead of feeling guilty about this, I actually feel proud, I don’t think you can get more self aware than being aware of who you will be before you are even that person. That’s what I call healing and growing. ⁣

Nothing is wrong with needing space and more people should take it, the world would be so much of a better place. #hidefromyourkids #sometimes

There’s been times that I know that those around me think “𝘸𝘩𝘺 𝘪𝘴 𝘴𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘢𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘪𝘵 𝘴𝘰 𝘴𝘦𝘳𝘪𝘰𝘶𝘴𝘭𝘺?” when it comes to getting down to my child’s level, stopping what I’m doing and focusing entirely on my child and their “whining” or “complaining.” But it’s because I know that these are signs of them 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘭𝘪𝘯𝘨 and no feeling can be taken too seriously. 𝐀𝐥𝐥 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥. ⁣
⁣
This post is to get rid of these ideas:⁣
⁣
Talking about a child:⁣
“Oh she always does this, cries over her cup, wahhh wahhh.”⁣
“Don’t worry, he’s fine, he likes to make a fuss over XYZ.”⁣
“Why is she making such a big deal?”⁣
“Why is he being so dramatic?”⁣
⁣
Or directly to a child:⁣
“It’s really ok, you don’t need to be upset.”⁣
“It’s not the end of the world.”⁣
“You’re ok, you’re ok, stop crying.”⁣
⁣
𝐈𝐭’𝐬 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐬𝐨 𝐦𝐮𝐜𝐡 𝐢𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐬𝐞 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐝𝐬, 𝐢𝐭’𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐢𝐝𝐞𝐚𝐬 𝐛𝐞𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦, that 𝘸𝘦 know better how someone else should be feeling. That we have a right to judge or teach how intensely someone should feel. Feelings and emotions are entirely subjective, different for everyone. That’s how it should be. Let’s keep it that way. Take feelings seriously and scroll for why. ⁣

For whoever needs to hear this today:
⁣
This is why 𝐠𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐥𝐞 parenting should be called 𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐠 parenting….⁣
⁣
I credit the words below (with permission) from @raising_yourself 
⁣
The paradox of gentle parenting is that it sounds easy on the surface.⁣
⁣
After all, it’s “gentle” - how hard can it be?⁣
⁣
Rest assured, parents who respond to their kids in a respectful and gentle (𝘯𝘰, 𝘐 𝘥𝘪𝘥 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘴𝘢𝘺 𝘱𝘦𝘳𝘮𝘪𝘴𝘴𝘪𝘷𝘦) way in the face of being triggered are some of the 𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐠𝐞𝐬𝐭, 𝐟𝐢𝐞𝐫𝐜𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 that I know.⁣
⁣
It takes immense strength, 𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐚𝐠𝐞 and inner discipline to reign in your anger when you want to fly off the handle.⁣
⁣
Discharging your triggers onto your child - 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘯 𝘣𝘭𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥 - has always been the easy way out. ⁣
⁣
And this part is from me: when we 𝘥𝘰 fly off the handle, when we do lose it, let’s not include the word “but” in an apology - if we want to take full accountability for our actions. ⁣

*Also, warning, if you’re feeling emotional about yourself as a parent, don’t watch that scene in Moana when she sings this part to remind Te Fiti that she has a heart 🥹

Childhood is about opportunities and experiences; facing fears, building the ability to stick to things but also learning 𝘸𝘩𝘦𝘯 𝘵𝘰 𝘭𝘦𝘵 𝘨𝘰. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
When we corner children into sticking with an activity bc it’s what everyone else is doing or bc we had an idea in our head of what our child should be doing, 𝘸𝘦 𝘤𝘭𝘰𝘴𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮 𝘰𝘧𝘧 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘵𝘳𝘺𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘯𝘦𝘸 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘴. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Let’s reframe the term “quitting.” Think of it as “experiencing,” trusting that with every “quit” comes learning. Sometimes it’s the right decision and sometimes it isn’t. Don’t be afraid for you or your child to make the wrong decision. Sometimes you figure out what the best decision is by 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘸𝘳𝘰𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘯𝘦 𝘧𝘪𝘳𝘴𝘵. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
It’s about the decision making rather than what the ultimate decision is. Here’s how to help your child make the best decision. ⁣
• Remember this about your child and helping them to make the best decision. We support their growing ability to trust themselves by trusting them too.⁣⁣⁣
• Figure out the why - help your child to figure out what’s really not enjoyable about the activity. We do this by asking questions - bringing them to the experience in their minds to see what it brings up. ⁣⁣⁣
• Is it a habit? Are they giving up on many things? Or did they give something a fair shot?⁣⁣⁣
• Are they always fearful of new things? If so, talk about how trying something new is a tunnel to work through - come up with a timeline together for how long it may take to get through that tunnel.⁣⁣⁣
• Talk about what it means to stop an activity. Sometimes a child isn’t thinking about what that really means. Maybe they just want to adjust something about the activity.⁣⁣⁣
 • 𝐑𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐢𝐬𝐧’𝐭 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐝𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐦𝐬, 𝐛𝐮𝐭 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐩𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐢𝐬𝐜𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫𝐬. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Quitting isn’t the opposite of building grit, sometimes letting your child experience that aftermath is just enough to build the best kind of grit: the kind that comes from 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘪𝘳 𝘰𝘸𝘯 𝘭𝘪𝘧𝘦 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘦𝘳𝘪𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘴, 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘰𝘶𝘳𝘴. ⁣⁣⁣

Admittedly, when I knew I had to fly alone with the girls today I thought “I hope they’re not out of control and difficult, especially knowing I’m on my own.” But once I told them it was just the three of us traveling, and they felt my confidence and trust in them to be my partners vs feeling my doubt, that they could only be “obstacles,” it was just the opposite. They had full reign to do whatever they wanted, I would have had no way to control them, I had way too much stuff as usual and had it all loaded on the stroller while they had to walk beside me the entire security check, terminal, bathroom trips, and boarding.

But what flashed in my mind was the symbolic “leash” they never actually had. All the times some may have thought “I gave an extra inch” physically allowing them to walk on their own, never policing them, and very rarely telling them to “be careful.” All the times I’d invite them to help and empower them to feel like drivers of experiences instead of just passengers. 

Give your kids an extra inch, and if you really live by this, I guarantee one day you’ll think something like “who are these little humans helping me pick up my mobile order iced oat matcha latte and reminding me that when I give them those extra inches, we can go miles together.”

*I know that this can seem eye roll worthy, and believe me, if my children are tired or hungry - they’re absolutely still learning tools on how to handle that. But for the most part, I believe that they don’t necessarily choose to be good, I just believe children are good, 𝘸𝘦 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘯𝘦𝘦𝘥 𝘵𝘰 𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵.

Raise kids who love and respect their bodies, by loving and respecting yours first.

I’m raising girls, and the reality of that comes with the reality of instilling in them the utmost respect for themselves and their bodies even in the face of potential commentary, teasing, or, god forbid, attempts at harrassment in their future. This actually goes for any gender but based on my own experience as a young girl and woman, I personally feel strongly about it because I’m raising girls. 

The other day we were in the jacuzzi and Tess yanked down my bathing suit top. Similar to what you see in this video. She then said something like “your boobies are so small mommy!” 

I laughed, at first. But then I quickly realized this was an opportunity for something important. I said, “I don’t like that. This is my body and I don’t want you pulling down my bathing suit. I won’t let you.” Then I said “You know when I was younger in school, people used to tease me about my boobies.” I said, “but i’m telling you this because no one is allowed to touch or talk about your body in a way that you don’t like. If they do, that means they’re having their own hard time and it has nothing to do with you. Do you love your body?” “Yes!’ “Ok, so remember that if any one ever tries to say anything bad about it.” 

The conversation went on for a bit and since then she’s tested the yanking of my shirt and has asked about the teasing of my boobies. I share all of this to say that we have an opportunity to immunize and strengthen our children’s body and self image before they struggle with it. We can’t control other people, and it is certainly harder to instill these things in our child after they have faced potential bullying, teasing, or worse. 

Some reminders to tell our children:

“If anyone says anything about your body those are their words not your thoughts.”

“Don’t let anyone change the way you feel about yourself.” 

Practice saying what you love about yourself and your body in front of your kids. Right. Now.

The other day I shared in my stories that one of the best pieces of advice I could give you is not to take on the role of your children’s referee. What I meant by this is that we often think that if our children come to us with a conflict (most often between siblings) that we are required to solve it for them. We can respond in one of two general ways:

Hear the conflict and “call” it. 
Hear the conflict and empower them to work through it. 

The latter is what will help everyone long term but the former is what feels necessary. Very rarely will the former not result in protests from one of the siblings and/or its only a matter of time before it does again. You are constantly at your child’s beck and call to solve challenges for them, to be the one to say “he had it first, give it back” or “don’t do that, say sorry” or even worse, you’re required to be your children’s timer and constantly required to resolve things for them. 

This does little to help them with conflicts in their life socially. Even at school, my hope is that educators help to educate our children on how to problem solve through conflicts (that are appropriate) instead of doing that for them. In this reel I show the difference between being a “referee” and being a listener. Sometimes that’s all that children want, someone to hear, see, and validate them to help fuel them up to solve the issue on their own. Other times children need our help not to solve, but to process what happens. 

It’s not about leaving your children high and dry to fend for themselves, it’s about the fact that children learn to respect one another more when they directly interact. The long term goal is to help siblings feel “We can work through this!” instead of immediately thinking “we can’t handle this without mommy.” 

There are a few things you can say instead of “calling it” or “taking a side” that can empower your children to solve these frequent challenges on their own. 

“Hmmm how did that feel?”

“How can you let her know that?” 

“That sounds like a tough situation!”

“What do you think would feel good to everyone?”

We may still have to step in, but we rarely need to initially.

I picked Nell up from school and had an hour and 15 minutes before I had to pick up Tess. Nell asked to go to the grocery store with her Target cart and I knew I had to get flowers for Union Square Play. So we went to Trader Joe’s. As we were checking out, she said she had to pee. I said hold it just a few min and we’ll use the potty right when we get to our building. As we walked back to our building we bumped into someone we knew who was like “you need a photo of this!” so we stopped for a photo. We got to our building with not a moment to spare and rushed Nell to the potty. Nell started resisting and protesting. 

How do I respectfully parent one child when my other child will walk out of school to no one there. Don’t I owe Tess respect too? What does one do???

I lost it. I said “you have to pee pee right now!” She lost it then too. We made it in time but on the way I apologized to Nell. For a moment I thought, “just like we always say there’s emotions behind our children’s behavior, shouldn’t they know there are emotions behind ours?” The answer is yes but that 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐞𝐦𝐨𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐧’𝐭 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝’𝐬 𝐟𝐚𝐮𝐥𝐭. 

Here’s why - Nell is not responsible for the fact that I could have had her use the bathroom before the grocery store, or that I shouldn’t have stopped for the photo or that I should have left us more time. That’s my responsibility. I was the one who left it to the millisecond in which it became about Nell using the potty in order to get to Tess in time. That’s on me. 

So that’s what I said. I said “just like you have feelings and you sometimes do things you wish you didn’t do, I do too. I wish I didn’t yell at you to use the potty. I should have left us more time. I’m sorry.” 

Do you see how this scenario isn’t about Nell obeying using the potty in a rushed way in order to get to Tess in time? This is about 𝐦𝐞 managing time in a way that doesn't come down to that. Every scenario in which we want to blame our children for our behavior, if we become self aware enough to see it, is not about them. It’s. about. us.

It’s not about pretending we’re perfect with no conflict - it’s about showing we’re human and what healthy conflict looks like.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Marriage is hard. Parenting is hard. Marriage AND parenting is 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 hard. I think that this is where Matt and I have grown up the most. We met as kids, our relationship always felt like we were still kids, 𝐮𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐥 𝐰𝐞 𝐡𝐚𝐝 𝐤𝐢𝐝𝐬.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
We bicker, we’re human, and it’s impossible not to have any conflict with one another. Just like it’s impossible not to have conflict with our children. It’s reality. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
But the most crucial thing has been that we absolutely live by and believe that we are modeling what conflict is and what a relationship is. 𝘖𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 𝘶𝘯𝘥𝘦𝘳𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘩𝘦𝘯𝘥 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵, 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘥𝘰 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘬. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
For us, the most important thing has been showing our girls moments of repairing, showing our love - despite an argument, showing that a disagreement does not equate lack of love. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Think about the relationship you want your children to look for and build one day: one that is respectful, where both people aren’t resistant to accountability, where admitting wrongdoing or apologizing is not looked at as a weakness. One that grows stronger and isn’t filled with bitterness and resentment. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Matt used to never let me go to bed mad, now we never leave one another mad. ⁣⁣
⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣
⁣⁣

This video is for every parent who is comparing themselves and their child to those they may see on social media.⁣
⁣
I share ideas, activities and hopefully tactical tools meant to support you. That being said, I know sometimes it is 𝐒𝐎 much easier said than done. I have been there, 𝐈 𝐀𝐌 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞. ⁣
⁣
I also know how it can feel when we see posts on “𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘪𝘴 𝘩𝘰𝘸 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘴𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘭𝘥 𝘥𝘰 𝘪𝘵” or “𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦’𝘴 𝘢 𝘨𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘵 𝘩𝘢𝘤𝘬” and we implement it and it all goes to sh*t, it can feel impossible not to feel like we’re the odd one out. ⁣
⁣
For some reason we believe messy means failure and although this is a comical short snippet, it’s meant to show that neither one of my children is a failure, neither is better, both are creative and incredible in their own way. ⁣
⁣
If I’m one parent and these few seconds highlight the vast difference between my two children, isn’t it safe to say that the messiness and imperfect-ness of all of it isn’t a reflection on me or them and that we’re all just different humans growing and figuring out who we are?⁣
⁣
Embrace the mess. Embrace who your kids are. Embrace who 𝐲𝐨𝐮 are. Accept the gap and beauty between our expectations and reality, that’s what makes us human, that’s what makes life an incredible adventure, and that’s what makes children so unbelievably magical.

If being around young children is new to you, you can feel scared at how delicate they seem, or it can feel daunting because you feel like you can’t trust them with anything. 

So it makes sense that it’s really hard to remain calm and not to evoke stress when we are around babies and children until we become a bit more seasoned. On top of that, all of us have our own stress triggers, some of us can’t handle messy situations, some of us are very safety concerned, some of us are very overwhelmed by big emotions. Just the thought of keeping our nerves at bay when it comes to all of this coupled with babies and children is enough to feel not calm without even interacting directly.

But let me tell you, when we can find our calm in the face of things that used to automatically evoke immediate stress, we are doing something huge for our children. We are expressing trust. Trust not only in our children (that empowers them to trust themselves) but trust in ourselves and our ability to get through any day of parenting (and there are many of them). 

I could go on and on about how our mentality and attitude is contagious for our children one way or the other. But instead I’ll say to scroll for how you can adjust some of your reflexive responses. This adjustment is powerful because instead of responding in ways that just evoke fear we can respond in ways that empower learning.

When people ask me why I recommend saying “I won’t let you do that” when stopping children from doing something harmful or unsafe…⁣
⁣
I always emphasize that it automatically puts us in a more sturdy position - it lets our child know that we are in charge of keeping everyone safe. We aren’t 𝘢𝘴𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 them to stop, or just saying “no” (which often stops holding power when used too often) we are establishing ourselves as someone who will not allow something to happen and saying it with conviction. 𝗪𝐞 𝐦𝐞𝐚𝐧 𝐛𝐮𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬. It’s non negotiable.⁣
⁣
But there’s another reason. It came up the other day with my 5 year old daughter. She was talking about how a friend pushed her and she didn’t like it. I said “what do you say when someone hurts you or something feels unsafe? What does mommy say when that happens?”⁣
⁣
Mic drop. ⁣
⁣
*This is also why I don’t smile when setting a boundary. I don’t want to confuse my children and don’t want them to feel wishy washy when 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐲 𝐬𝐞𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 𝐨𝐰𝐧 𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐬. ⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣

Even if you aren’t fully convinced of what I’m saying in this post, I hope you’ll remember it.

When your children are seeking your attention - please know they are seeking connection. 

Even if you just pause and say “I know it feels like you want me to stop, I want you to know even though we are rushing to get there on time, I am still here.” 
Even if you stop and just braid the Isabella doll while in the elevator. 
Even if you aren’t fixing the hundreds of things they are asking you to fix, even if you aren’t able to quite get them “unlost” you are helping them to feel found. 

Stop for the lost child. 

If you can truly grasp this concept, you know what to do when your child is whining, clinging, and seemingly “being needy.” When you respond with moments of connection, the whining lessens, your child feels more seen, and they grow up more secure.

On Tuesday, Nell had her usual fear in anticipation of her swim lesson. She is just starting to finally let her face get wet. She isn’t swimming yet and has had a lot of lessons. This feels discouraging to her and I think now that she is overcoming fear, she is feeling defeated by “not good enough.”

I honestly said to her “I hear you, you don’t want to swim, but I have to tell you something. Your teacher told me you were a swimming superstar last week. He told me how hard you worked, how hard you tried, how much you have grown as a swimmer. I just wanted you to know that.”

The other day a parent asked me, “Do you believe there are no bad kids?” and I didn’t miss a beat before I said, yes I believe there are no bad kids. 

Here’s why. Children aren’t born with tools. We weren’t born with them either. When you see a child unable to regulate, they are lacking tools. When you see a child who is growing up continuously unable to regulate, this child’s caregivers may be lacking tools to give them (or this child may have specific challenges that continuously make it harder to learn regulation skills). I still don’t believe they’re bad.

This is why I see no reason for yelling at or shaming a child. When we are modeling our inability to regulate (yelling and shaming) how do we possibly expect our children to learn how to regulate?

We’re all human and it sometimes happens but children who are the “most difficult” need the most tools. Children who look at you and laugh as they are seemingly “purposely” not listening, are in the need of the most connection. Their laughter is nervousness and awkwardness in how to ask for it. 

Today we were at brunch and I saw that the louder I got, the louder my girls got. The more dysregulated I got, the more dysregulated they got. The more I was focused elsewhere, the more they ignored me when I asked them to “please listen.”

No matter what you believe - just know that when you believe there are “no bad kids” you will see that your children become “easier” because you are finally understanding what they need. 

Examples of self regulation: taking deep breaths, remembering this reel before responding, closing your eyes and counting to ten, remembering you have an opportunity to model how to handle “hard times.”

Examples of empathy: Remind yourself: “There is always an emotion behind a behavior” or “my child is good and is just having a hard time” or “I am a good parent having a hard time.”

Examples of connection: Humor, a game, saying “it seems like it’s time for us to just be together” or “I’m here” and trusting that you are modeling not enabling. Trust that this exact moment of your child’s dysregulation is not a learning moment.

There’s a reason they say that “old habits die hard.” There’s also a reason we allow “bad” habits and then a reason we avoid breaking them. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
We lack trust. We lack belief in our child. Let me explain. When our child is upset and we don’t trust that they can work through it, we reflexively do whatever we can to get them away from that upset-ness. We distract or try to fix whatever is upsetting them. We mean well. But what we message is “this is so uncomfortable, so hard that I don’t think you can get through it. In order to get through it, we need to distract you from it, leave this upset feeling aside and focus on something else. I also don’t think you can survive without the thing you are needing right now, so I’m going to give that to you.” And we keep the habit going…⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Sometimes we start this way and as our child gets older we have more trust and tolerance for their discomfort but sometimes, we don’t. When we don’t. Our child doesn’t. So that’s why things like pacifiers, screen time, specific treats or habits that aren’t serving our child can feel really daunting and tough to take away the longer we leave it in place. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
𝐔𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐥 𝐰𝐞 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐬𝐮𝐫𝐯𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐝𝐢𝐬𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐨𝐟 𝐛𝐞𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐢𝐭. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
But another crucial piece here is believing that we (and those around us) can survive our child surviving without it. It’s not just about our child when they’re this young. It’s about the places we take them to, the people we are around, the spouses we have, the siblings they have and so many more things. We almost want to wear a sign that says “please give us grace, we are doing some really hard things right now!” ⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Since we can’t really do that, scroll instead. ⁣⁣⁣

I’ve been in a state of comparison. I’m helping my 3.5 year old daughter get rid of her pacifier, something I took away from my first daughter at 18 months. I can’t help but compare the mom I was to Tess to the mom I am to Tess AND Nell. Something I have talked about before. 

We think that the differences indicate a “less than” from before. I think it indicates a growth. A confidence. A “I know who my kid is and I know what I can handle” and even more “I know what’s important.” 

On another note, there’s also a tendency for us, as parents, to compare our children to their siblings. The thing we don’t quite realize is that when we say things like “Look! Your sister is putting on her shoes!” We are immediately creating a tendency for our children to look to compare themselves even more than they already may have. It’s something that we want to build our child out of, not build them into. 

So when Tess has said “I got rid of my pacifier at 18 months Nellie!”

My response: 
“It’s really hard to stop a habit and sometimes even harder the older you are! Nellie is working really hard!”

And to myself:
“I see how hard you’re working at life right now, it sometimes feels a lot harder now than 4 years ago. 
You’re more confident than you used to be. You’re not slacking, you’re growing.”

As we were leaving last night Nell said she had to use the bathroom but was resistant to leave what she was doing. So triggering for me as I was rushing 🤦🏻‍♀️ But it was a combination of she didn’t want me to leave and sometimes the hardest part about using the potty is the transition or separation from what she is immersed in. 
⁣
Recently, Nell has started resisting the potty. I noticed that when she starts squirming as if she  has to go pee, she doesn’t want to stop playing, she’s worried about her play, and she doesn’t want to miss out. 
⁣
So here’s a hack we came up with. We either designate a toy or sign to watch over Nell’s toys/play situation while she uses the potty. I know that bringing an object to the bathroom can help, but not when they want to bring in their entire playroom (boundaries!). It’s also not necessarily something you can do anywhere outside the home but it does help them start to get used to transitioning away from play to potty. I hope it works for you!

Try it and let me know what happens!

“𝐘𝐨𝐮’𝐫𝐞 𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭.” I don’t want to plant this unattainable seed or put my child on this unrealistic pedestal. No need for this. I’ll point out what I love without this line. ⁣
⁣
“𝐒𝐭𝐨𝐩 𝐛𝐞𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐝𝐢𝐟𝐟𝐢𝐜𝐮𝐥𝐭.” No one is “being difficult” for the fun of it. When we train children into thinking this is a possibility they believe their emotions are difficult. Their emotions are too much. Their emotions are inconvenient, and therefore, they are. They will grow up to believe this. ⁣
⁣
“𝐇𝐞/𝐒𝐡𝐞 𝐢𝐬 𝐣𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐣𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐨𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐲𝐨𝐮.” When we plant this seed, we plant jealousy seeds “if mommy says that X is jealous of me for having Y then I should feel jealous of Z for having Y too.” Replace the jealousy reflex with “I wonder.” Have your child wonder and be curious about others and help to emphasize that whatever situation is at hand to have warranted someone being jealous of your child, is that other child’s struggle. ⁣
⁣
“𝐃𝐨 𝐗, 𝐢𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐦𝐚𝐤𝐞 𝐘 𝐬𝐨 𝐡𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐲!” It’s one thing to say “I saw how happy someone was when you went over to her.” But if we are telling our child to get into the habit of doing things for the purpose of just making someone else happy, we simplify that as a linear habit to get into. We aren’t taking into consideration the nuances that are involved in doing X to make Y happy. It’s just not an ideal demand to start making. If we are leaning into this comment, it’s because we’re probably trying to convince our child to do something that they aren’t necessarily keen or comfortable doing in order to make someone 𝘦𝘭𝘴𝘦 happy - you get the point. ⁣
⁣
“𝐋𝐞𝐭 𝐦𝐞 𝐝𝐨 𝐢𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐲𝐨𝐮.” We can help and support our child without doing for them. Instead of “Let me do it for you” say what you can do “I can help you by lifting this up as you tell me where you think it should go” or “It looks like you may need some help. How can I support you?” Instead of just “let me do it for you, I can do it for you, I’ll do it quicker, faster, better” which can take away accomplishments.⁣
⁣
Share your thoughts!⁣
⁣
⁣

Ok, don’t come at me 🙈
⁣
Last night my girls were so overtired and hysterical that I was about to skip dinner altogether until I remembered something I knew would calm them down: feeding them. Showing them “I got you” through this simple parental act that they grew up accustomed to. ⁣
⁣
When our children are born, we spend time supporting them with things like eating and sleeping. We usually rush both processes and celebrate the days they can do things independently. Then, before they know it, we have taken away a large source of how we showed our care and love (through things like feeding and sleeping). Each time our child yearns for or needs the reminder of this love through care we are inclined to say: ⁣
“you know how to do it by yourself!”⁣
⁣
I don’t suggest that we perpetually feed and sleep with our children. I post this to say that we cannot let our fixation on raising “independent children,” get in the way of feeding our children sometimes - figuratively and literally. Even if and when they can feed themselves.⁣
⁣
Here’s why: everyone needs to be taken care of. Everyone deserves care. Even the most independent, “strong” and “tough” people. (you know that scene in the Sex and the City movie when Samantha feeds Carrie in bed after her world has been turned upside down? I cry every time I see that scene.) When we fixate on “do it yourself” or “you know how to, you’re a big girl” when our children are in need of support, we send a message that they shouldn’t need us sometimes. Sometimes, in a child’s village, a child’s source of believing in unconditional love is being able to experience the love their caregiver gave them for the majority of their young life - even when they know how to independently. ⁣
⁣
Don’t associate that 𝘰𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘢 𝘸𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘦 with lack of independence. Don’t bring the fear of “bad habits” into the equation. Once in a while, when our children need it most, let them have a morsel of what it was like before they could “do it all by themselves.”

Some people may think we’re “indulging too much” when we show concern over our child having a hard time with something seemingly quite small. 

Nell is small and when we are rushing out the door, she often gets brushed with a bag, or we bump into her sometimes without even realizing. Sometimes it’s barely a touch other times it’s an accidental harder brush against her. Yet each time she has the same reaction. She’s really upset. 

I’m aware enough to know that this isn’t about how hard or soft the bag or something bumps into her. It’s about the frustration around it. How small she is made to feel during these moments of “I don’t even see you!” and then the “I barely touched you!” that’s typically  the reflexive response. 

Yet there is not one morsel of my body that ever wants to respond with “but I barely touched you!” or “Nell, it was just a tap of my sweater!” Why would I? To teach her what is a big deal and what isn’t? Tell her what should annoy or frustrate her and what shouldn’t?

It’s like we think unless it’s painful and a big smack or big deal to us, then our child shouldn’t be bothered? Who are we to tell our children that they shouldn’t trust their own emotions by demeaning whether or not something is a “big enough deal” to us? 

I know that it can feel like the most frustrating thing ever when I get nudged on a subway or pushed past. I also know that my level of frustration probably depends more on what kind of day I’m having. I would either not be phased if I’m having a good day or be really annoyed if it was a bad day.

But I’ll tell you this, no matter what my reaction, having someone turn around and say “But I barely touched you!” would just make it feel worse or as if I somehow made it up in my head?

Let’s not ignore things just because they seem small to us. If we don’t validate or believe our child with the little stuff when they are little, why will they trust us to take them seriously with the big stuff when they’re big? It’s basically saying “I believe you” to your child. 

The quote in this reel is by C.M. Wallace “because to them all of it has always been big stuff.”

“Feel how you feel first. THEN we’ll figure it out.” 
Game. Changer. 

My captions are usually long. I wanna keep this simple. Try not fixing. The harder it is, the more you and your child need to use this tool (and mentality). Not just with our kids. With everyone. But the most pivotal thing about this was when I realized how much I needed to use this on myself. It’s made me act less out of emotion, be less impulsive, and has made me grow as a parent more than I can put into words. 

Feel it first. Then get through it.

I came to my parents house solo yesterday. It’s been emotional and this morning I got frustrated with the girls when they wouldn’t put on the clothes I brought home for them because neither was an Elsa dress which they usually put on before getting dressed for the day. It was one of those times when I just felt so disrespected.

I said something along the lines of: “I do so much for you, and I’m alone this weekend why can’t you just pick one!” There is so much wrong with this statement and I know that. I knew it as I said it. 

But before we walked in to meet my friends for brunch, I stopped them outside the car and said “family huddle!” and then I said “You’re both allowed to wear what your body feels most comfortable in, sometimes we have a lot of options and sometimes we don’t. Today we only had two options and it’s hard when you want an option that isn’t here.”

Then I said “what you wear has nothing to do with how much mommy does for you, or if I’m here without daddy! How much I do for you is my choice, it was silly of me to say that.”

I felt this was important to say because behind every people pleaser is a child who was told enough times that they should do, act, eat, play, or look a certain way. I’m sure many of them were told they should because an adult in their life “worked so hard.” 

We can set boundaries without guilt. We just need to be here in between cheering each other on because holy sh*t it takes a lot of patience and self reflection. 

*You may be wondering what I could’ve said instead to set this boundary. Scroll for that.

I know that every single time we get home from school, my girls want to play. They’ve missed their toys and being home and just want a second. Today we had their dance recital rehearsal. On our drive home from school, I felt my body tense up in anticipation of the resistance. I don’t know why it takes me like 20 times before I start to use this tool, but when I do, it changes so much. 

Yes, we try to figure out what’s behind the hard time, but sometimes I think this tool works better than the “I know it’s hard to get dressed instead of playing.” 

Here’s the tool: call it. Not during it, but  𝘣𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘦 it

“Uh! We’re almost home and I think I know what you’re going to want to do! You’re going to want to play, am I right?!” with a warm smile. She didn’t really resist that in the car before but once we got home, she threw off her back pack and was about to pick up her toys and I said “Ah wait! Remember what we talked about in the car!” and she sighed and smiled. It wasn’t like she was miraculously thrilled to rush instead of playing but she felt invited vs. demanded of. 

There are a million ways these conversations can go but the best part about it is that it chips away at the resistance by seeing your child and letting them know that you are considering them (often when were in the rut of resistance moment we are just in such a struggle that our child feels unseen and we feel unseen and it’s just the worst.

Try this. It’s sort of like an immunization for the situation.

So much of what we worry about when we raise children is related to helping them form 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡𝐲 𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠. ⁣
⁣
Think about it, if you’ve been to therapy, good therapy doesn’t mean that you’re given direction on exactly what to do in every given challenge but you talk through situations that help you form productive vs destructive ways of thinking.⁣
⁣
𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥𝐬 𝐥𝐢𝐤𝐞 𝐚 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥 𝐞𝐩𝐢𝐩𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐡𝐚𝐫𝐞.⁣
⁣
When our children come to us with almost any problem, being able to have conversations with them to help them form practical ways of thinking instead of us believing we need the “perfect” response, feels really liberating.⁣
⁣
I think about this and apply this when my 5 year old says things like “I bet this friend won’t have a dress like mine!” so innocently, not maliciously, but this. is. when. we. change. ways. of. thinking. When a child doesn’t really know better and isn’t defensive or ingrained in ways of thinking. ⁣
⁣
This is a small snippet of conversations I have with my 5 year old all. the. time. You may start with one and get very little feedback but start these conversations now. ⁣
⁣
𝐈𝐟 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐧𝐨 𝐨𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐬𝐨𝐧 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐧 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐝𝐚𝐲 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐲 𝐝𝐨𝐧’𝐭 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 “𝐣𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐭𝐞𝐥𝐥 𝐦𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨 𝐗𝐘𝐙” 𝐛𝐮𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 𝐭𝐨 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤 “𝐡𝐦𝐦 𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐧𝐚 𝐭𝐚𝐥𝐤 𝐭𝐨 𝐦𝐨𝐦 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬!”⁣

It doesn’t really matter whose right or wrong always but when we absolutely know that our child is right, why not tell them? 

When we left the eye doctor today I told Matt it was good we went. He thought it was silly to go. I was waiting for him to say those three words. You. Were. Right. He didn’t 🤣 (until later) but it just highlights how important it is to say these words more often than we do. To each other. To our kids. 

It’s almost like saying “I believe you now.”

Yesterday I shared a story about Nell and her emotions. Someone messaged me “Oh god such drama.” I know that it affected me because when I get really affected, I become defensive and that was my first plan of response. But then I breathed and wrote “Oh I know. My deeply feeling 3 year old. Love her and all of her feelings so much.” 

But what I didn’t write was that this particular story that she was commenting on was also one of the things I actually said in a group at an event last week was the thing I think I’m succeeding at as a mom. 

Being attuned to my daughters. 

Being attuned is our ability to be aware of and respond to our child’s needs. Not just the obvious needs but the very nuanced itty bitty ones. Each child has a different temperament and personality and on top of that, our young children can’t communicate so clearly because of a few things 1. Some aren’t even verbal yet. 2. They aren’t even aware of some of their needs and 3. We’re overwhelmed, busy, distracted and preoccupied with the 8000 open tabs in our brains. So being attuned is actually really hard. It’s when we feel deeply connected to our child. When we know, without a doubt, what they’re upset about when it seems no one else does. 

I truly want that for every parent and child. It’s like this magical, spiritual connection that you have with your child that allows you to become their expert. It ebbs and flows, naturally, when we feel less connected and less attuned. But being really attuned is like a double edged sword for some of us. It’s also that feeling we have when our spouse lets us “sleep in,’’ and in that half sleep stupor we hear things that we know we can help our children with in a millisecond, its what makes it very hard to turn off, if ever. 

As a pre Mothers Day gift to anyone who feels this, I want to let you know the most important thing about attunement. That as long as a child has that with someone in their lives, it fuels them to be able to navigate in settings where they may not have it. Nell was fine in this moment in this video, more than fine, but there’s no doubt that it feels extra good to be understood.

It can feel daunting to consider that we can parent so intentionally, thoughtfully and respectfully only to feel that it can be undone by forces beyond our control. 

When we think about all the outside influences and people that come into our children’s lives - we realize that it’s about being the louder voice for our child, being the voice that they internalize (in their own way) that empowers them to drown out the external voices that stand in the way of their own. 

But this voice that we want them to internalize can’t be based on us - it’s based on what is best for our child. How do we help them to find that voice?

Scroll for some ways 🫶🏻

My favorite is how often we say “look at me when I’m talking to you” or “look at them when you say XYZ” as we go through times of day when we barely look up from our phone. 

Our children are always watching. We’re the ones showing them what respect looks like. Respect isn’t forcing or demanding our child say or do something, respect is trusting they’ll say and do the “right” things when it means something to them and when we do the “right” things too. The most powerful way to help your child to get there is by getting there yourself. Be friendly, be authentic, be genuine and personable, no one needs a hello or goodbye from your child as desperately as you think they do.

I haven’t seen the girls nearly enough for any of us this week and knew I’d be heading straight into a whine fest when I got home right before dinner tonite. I kid you not none of this was staged or rehearsed, it just works. It helps put them on the same page as someone. Try it and let me know.

The other day I read that a sign your child feels safe with you is that they don’t shut down when they’re upset. I know this is true - but it made me pause reading it because recently Tess sometimes closes off when she’s upset. She’ll shut down, walk away, close the door and then when I finally get to her - she’ll laugh or say nothing is wrong.⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
A few days ago, in a regular moment I said “Hey! Why do you laugh or walk away when you’re upset? You didn’t always do that.” She thought for a moment and then said “you’re always focusing on Nellie.” ⁣⁣⁣⁣
⁣⁣⁣⁣
A few things came to my mind:⁣⁣ “She was using the word “focus” in the right way, where did she learn that word? How is she so old and wise?⁣⁣⁣ How remarkable is it that she’s that 𝘪𝘯 tune with her feelings to even know why she has been responding in this new “shutting down” way. ⁣⁣⁣Wow, I am so happy I said something bc how many times has she retreated to be by herself when I’m focused on Nell that she has now started to cope this way?!⁣⁣⁣”⁣
⁣⁣⁣
Today when we pulled up for us to get Tess her first pair of glasses, I turned around, looked at Nell and Tess and said “this is just gonna be Tessie and I going in for her glasses.” Nell immediately reacted upset, she started crying, Tess said “no mommy it’s ok Nellie can come, she’s gonna scream.” Tess said the same thing this morning when it was time for me to visit Tess’s classroom. I let Nell come to that. But this time I said “Tess, she’s allowed to be upset and you’re allowed to have time where I am only focused on you. Daddy is here with her.⁣⁣⁣⁣”
⁣⁣⁣⁣
We went in, she was nervous, so I said “this is going to be one of the things that makes you who YOU are, pick any pair of glasses you want because it’s just about YOU.” To which she smiled, picked out a blue pair and then insisted on picking out a pair for me too - she said it was to help make me who I am too. I sort of never wanna take them off. ⁣⁣⁣

I’m anti talking in third person about someone, especially children EXCEPT in this context. 

This is something I’ve done for years even as a teacher. When I know or observe a child is feeling a bit discouraged or in need of some extra attention (another word for connection)! ESPECIALLY the seeming “defiant” ones, the “non listeners” the ones who “misbehave.” They often don’t feel noticed for anything besides the negative. So, I’ll talk about them positively. I’ll usually always loop them in because it feels inauthentic not to. I’d say to my co-teacher “Hey Ms. Li, did you see what Henry did earlier with the blocks? He built this unbelievably tall tower, focused so much on each one, and it was really cool to see!” Then I’d look over at Henry laser focused and smiling slightly and say “Henry I saw that creation you made!” 

I’ve been doing this recently after moments that I know have been hard for Tess even if she isn’t expressing it. For instance in a moment when Nell is upset it’s hard for all of us not to get triggered. It’s a lot. Tess used to often get angry about it, and probably still is inside, so I make sure she knows I notice. 

We all want to feel special, we all want to be loved, and
some children need to be noticed for the “good stuff” not just when they’re being disciplined.

So maybe try this if you feel you have a child who is “defiant” maybe all it will take it noticing them in a “good” moment without directly telling them - but telling someone else they love.

“What if my spouse doesn’t find the good?”
