Lol kidding but walk the walk. When you and your children are finding the good, that is contagious. 

“How will my child learn if I’m just finding the good”
if you don’t trust that my five year old on the side of the road wiping down her shirt and looking up at me through tears saying “it’s beautiful like this” about her shirt didn’t learn something about opening up my cosmetics in the car then read it again. I didn’t have to teach anything here besides that this wasn’t the end of the world which, incredibly, my five year old taught 𝐦𝐞.

There were many moments this weekend where it felt like the emotional load was all on me. One of the most triggering things for me is when Matt will come over to me with one of the girls crying about something that isn’t “serious” but is more about his reflex of “I know that Jen can calm her down faster than I can.” 

It’s not even as if he’s doing anything wrong - it’s probably everyone’s reflex - bring the upset child to the person who can calm them down the quickest right? But how does that help the child in times when I am not available? How does that help the child to know that, in fact, they are able to be soothed by someone else like their other parent? How can we help them know they are able to get through discomfort, in general?

Scroll for how “code words” have helped us.  Also watch the video toward the end to see how Tess uses it too! Hope you all had a nice #MDW and that none of it felt like it was all on you. Nothing ever should be.

The most frequent question I get asked is “how do you not lose it on your kids?” or “how do you stay so patient?”

I am not a patient person by nature. In fact, I’m probably hands down the least patient…except when it comes to children. 

Last night I drove to my childhood home basically in the middle of the night because I just can’t comprehend that it will no longer be my parents in a few weeks and my mom needed someone there with her while she went through our memories. 

I was exhausted today. I woke up to one of those disaster days. It ended in me finding out I missed Tess’s gymnastics showcase medal ceremony. She came home telling me how upset she was that I wasn’t there 💔 I know she’s fine but just to give you the gist of the emotional turmoil I was dealing with. And then the groceries came with the ice pops I promised were coming only to see they delivered the wrong order. I almost lost it 100000 times before bed. Each and every time I was going to lose it I thought “what example am I setting? Who do I want to be?” 

I’ll tell you what I dont want to be and what I dont want my kids to be. Someone who goes on a tirade about the wrong grocery order, who yells at the delivery guy or the company. Someone who misplaces guilt over missing their child’s gymnastics show by yelling at their uncooperative kids before bed time. Out of nowhere I just said “let’s dance!” and we did. That’s the mom I wanna be (and trust me I’m not always that mom!)

Here’s the reel, the one I go back to every time I need the reminder “my girls are learning how to be, by watching me.”
Tonight, in celebration of turning 40 (although it’s not until June 26th) I leave you with these 3 words that can transform any “bad day” as a parent and human.

As I was going through the emotions of accepting that soon we won’t have my childhood home - I was trying to really figure out what feels so hard about it. 

I have spent the past few days going through a house filled with 35 years of memories, almost like this huge time capsule - and as I opened each drawer I saw the familiar “organized mess” in each one and I was reminded of something that is so important for us to remember. ⁣

I always looked up to my mom (and still do) but I remember when I realized that other moms had organized drawers and she didn't. I remember going to one friends in particular. Her mom had everything labeled, a shelf with construction paper organized by color and every drawer with organizers. Now that I’m a mom, it makes me love my mom even more that she didn’t have organized drawers. Showing up for us is something she was perfect at. 

The second thing I realized is that this home stands for security.  That’s what feels the hardest, it’s as if I feel I’m going to lose this symbol of security. Something so much more powerful and important than perhaps even love. I have felt secure and safe in this home no matter when or where I have been in my life for the last 35 of my 40 years. It’s a wave that has always come over me every time I’ve walked through that door. But as I was writing this I realize that wave is something that doesn’t depend on a physical space but on the relationships within it, far from perfect, but always secure. That’s the home I was raised in and want for my own children. 
⁣
Doing it perfectly isn’t what anyone wants. Even if that’s the parent you planned to be, it's so much better for our kids that we’re not. They’ll remember it one day when they’re a parent and be relieved that they don’t have to be perfect. ⁣ 

Scroll for what I believe builds a secure home.

It’s not necessarily easy to celebrate yourself.  At least for me. ⁣
⁣
I almost didn’t do any celebration - celebrating myself usually brings up the same feeling I get when someone compliments me - 𝘸𝘩𝘺 𝘮𝘦? 𝘞𝘩𝘢𝘵'𝘴 𝘴𝘰 𝘴𝘱𝘦𝘤𝘪𝘢𝘭 𝘢𝘣𝘰𝘶𝘵 𝘮𝘦? ⁣
⁣
But as I’ve gotten older I’ve reprogrammed that mentality. Whenever I feel that feeling of resisting a compliment or celebration of myself I remind myself that I want my children to be their own best friends and that starts with showing them that 𝐈’𝐦 𝐦𝐲 𝐨𝐰𝐧 𝐛𝐞𝐬𝐭 𝐟𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐝. Wouldn’t I celebrate from the rooftops for my best friends? ⁣
⁣
So that’s what I did - even if the only date I could get was almost a month too early. ⁣

Whining can be one of the most triggering things in parenting. 

Before we can expect whining to diminish, we need to first adjust our mindset about what whining is.

Whining = Feeling unseen

Whining = Lack of tools to express a specific emotion

Once you believe these two things, it will transform your response to your child’s whining and help equip your child 
to eventually access and utilize communication skills in place of whining.

Lastly, if the response in this scroll seems like “too much” take a second to realize it’s actually having a conversation with your child instead of responding with your own version of whining and screaming.

I need to say this. 

On here and in real life -  let’s destroy the idea that in order to look like you’re a good parent, you and your children are perfectly in order. 

Knowing who your child is and embracing that, may mean some extra judgements or looking like life is a bit messy. But I call it strength, strength to not define ourselves by how orderly and “put together” us and our children are. Not to feel like something is wrong with us or our children if it always feels like chaos especially when you’re around others.

One day when our children are more put together, “sitting still,” quiet and calm, we will ache for these days when we should’ve just allowed them to be kids - because I think we can all agree that we should be the parents who accept them entirely, even in public, even around others who believe that “good children” and “good parents” are the ones with everything in order.

Last night the girls went to dinner with Matt and his family that was in town. I knew that it was probably a rough one for Nell once I found out she hadn’t napped after camp and a playdate. When I got back from NJ late I asked Matt how bad it was and he said Nell was a wreck. It’s one of tne of the things that is hard for me to let go of when I can’t be around. Knowing how to get my kids through situations like that - helping them feel unstuck.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I know that when Nell is in that mood, walking into a restaurant for dinner is her worst nightmare. She’s tired, cranky, dysregulated and here she is in a place with a bunch of people around and I know she feels truly trapped. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
There are so many times in a child’s life where they are in a place or situation that they didn’t ask to be in. What do they do? It’s not like they can say “I don’t want to be here, I feel really off, I don’t know the other people here and I don’t feel comfy” so they may cry, kick, scream, we may be embarrassed, angry and stern, and it just explodes from there. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
A child isn’t always able to express, or even understand why they are feeling this way.  Often when they communicate through what looks like a child being “difficult” or “misbehavior,” I imagine it’s the same feeling someone would have feeling trapped in an elevator. ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
So if you get the sense your child seemingly is losing it out of nowhere at a place like someone else’s house, a birthday party, the beach, a restaurant, or anywhere else you may find yourself this summer - try to prepare them, and if not, scroll for some things you can do or say don’t when your child seems “stuck” because it may just mean that they literally feel that way. ⁣⁣

Today as Tess and I walked up to the play date we had, I noticed how Tess 𝘳𝘢𝘯 up to them smiling. 𝐒𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐡𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐮𝐬𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨. She’s always been slow to warm up and I’m not sure when it happened but she’s become less slow to warm up. But this post is about how we need to allow kids to be who they are. 
⁣
I remembered this reel from last summer. How we were meeting friends at the drums on the beach. Something I have loved and couldn’t wait to bring Tess to. It took her more than half the time to warm up. I’m grateful that I didn’t pressure her in this particular instance because I’ve definitely done that - said things like “but we came here to have fun! Look at all the other kids dancing! Come on!” ⁣
⁣
But on this day, I let her experience it how she wanted and at her own pace. I didn’t let my own desire for “fun” overpower respecting my child - exactly as she is. And I truly think I’ve embraced it since this day 👆. Even during kindergarten interviews, even when re-meeting my grandparents, even on play dates, I stopped thinking it was a bad thing that it took her a bit and my confidence in that was pervasive to those we came across. My confidence in her as a 𝐟𝐫𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐥𝐲, 𝐠𝐨𝐨𝐝 person even if others felt she was stand offish was something she felt and it’s one of the reasons why I think she eventually felt safe to come out of her shell. ⁣
⁣
We wanna look back and think “I let my child be who he/she is” so that 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 look back and think “mommy loved me for exactly who I am.”

There’s something about seeing the one you fall in love with as a dad in the trenches with your kids. Will they dive in head first? Will they put their egos aside? Will they fully surrender?

And then there’s falling even harder for that person, when you didn’t think it was possible. Because they dive head first into the trenches every time, and when they crawl out, they’re smiling and never forget to tell you just how lucky they feel for all of it.

That’s literally you Matt. Happy Father’s Day. We love you so so much.

This is a video from last summer but almost the exact same thing happened this weekend. 

The girls were struggling over a beach toy and Nell got upset. When I went to comfort Nell, Tess got angry and tried to hit us. After I set the boundary with Tess and comforted Nell - I took Tess for a walk. I asked Tess what happened in that moment - she said “sometimes it’s like you just love Nellie more than me.” 

We talked about how it feels that way sometimes when there’s one of me and two of them. How when they’re both upset at the same time, showing different ways of being upset, that I do my best to keep everyone safe and comfortable. How it’s hard to wait for me. How Nellie has to wait sometimes too. How none of this means I love Nellie more than her. 

The point here is that had I just shunned Tess into a time out, imagine what that would message to her and imagine what thoughts she’d be alone with. Probably the same thoughts many of us were alone with in our own childhoods that we are 𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐥𝐥. 𝐠𝐫𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠. 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡. 

I know that there will be some of you who disagree here and assume that I mean no “time ins” no “time to rest and recharge” no time to “start over” and I don’t mean that. I mean the “go to your room!” or “you sit here in a time out!” none of that is productive and is just leaving a child alone and isolated with feelings they are grappling with. Isn’t it better to help them grapple with them now vs. them working through it in years from now during therapy?

Give tools not time outs. Give ways to process their feelings and emotions. Their brain scientifically needs that.

I’m getting ready for a trip without kids this Friday. Matt and I have never been away from the girls for this long (a week) and we’ve started to tell the girls about it in preparation. 

Last night when I brought it up to Nell, reminding her that she can do her potty routine with grandma or Nani, she said “I can’t do it without you” and it almost killed me before I replied “but I know you can, it may feel hard, for me too, to be apart from you guys, but I know we all can do it.” 

In these moments where I want to just melt and cancel or give in to whatever it is to make my girls feel “whole” what motivates me is knowing that NOT canceling or giving in is what really helps a child feel whole long term. Like just this morning when I was going to work out and I thought about how any minute away from them this week before I leave, is a minute I feel like I should just “give in” - I dont. Because it’s not me showing “tough love,” it’s just me showing the utmost love - showing them they can get through it (even when I feel like I can’t!)

What do we do in when our spouse “messes up” in parenting?

The shift in this reel is powerful. Not just for the parent/parent relationship, but for every relationship (even with our children!) Because the reality is, when we shame any human or try to teach them during an emotional moment, 𝘯𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘦𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘷𝘦 𝘩𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘦𝘯𝘴. When we support, 𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘩𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘦𝘯𝘴.⁣

I guarantee this way of supporting our child vs. scolding our spouse motivates our partner to apologize to our children more readily than if we had shamed or tried to teach them in that moment.

Even if you think this tool is a bit gimmicky and silly, there’s no denying that familiarity helps with transitions. A photo is certainly not the same thing as a real person but just becoming familiar with, and seeing a new face is helpful. 

Younger children would especially benefit from this exercise of bringing a photo of their new caregiver around with them throughout their routine - about a week prior to starting a new transition. 

You can build on this by asking your child things about their soon-to-be teacher or counselor to bring them to life:

“I wonder what activity is Sadie’s favorite at camp, what do you think?” 
“Do you think Sadie likes to sing? What songs?! Let’s ask her!”

Familiarity breeds comfort. Do this easy activity with your child, there is no downside and, at the least, it helps your child recognize at least one face on the first day of camp. 

We can’t wait to see you Sadie and Diana!

Oh the difference between today and the last 7 days 🫠

There’s a statistic that went viral that said that children are 800x worse when they are with their mothers than with any other caregiver. Even if this isn’t fact or based on a real study, the sentiment is there. The “she never does this with us” or “she was perfectly fine all week!” or “it’s always when you’re around that they are like this.” It’s why we sometimes second guess ourselves because our children are only this impossible when we’re around. 

When I was reunited with the earlier girls, I ran to the car, opened the door smiling and saying “hiiiiii my girls!!!!!” Tess closed her eyes, blocked me and laid down asking me not to come near her. Nellie reached for me but then was confused by Tess’s reaction and quickly started screaming and crying and saying “but don’t leave again, come inside home with us.” While Tess was saying “no get away, I don’t want anyone, I want to be by myself,” as she also started crying. Matt stood outside the car confused but I gave him a gesture to give them time. 

I would be lying if I said that it didn’t bother me that the reunion I fantasized about didn’t happen but I also knew that this was to be expected with my girls. I knew how many emotions they’d have, excited, happy, probably a little angry, feeling wary, and just overwhelmed and confused by all of those things at the same time. I didn’t lean into “but I’m home now and was so excited to see you!” I leaned into “ok take the time you need, I’m here, I’m not going anywhere.”

Think of all the nuanced times our children feel safest with us that they hold inside with others and then imagine that ALL coming out at once after 8 days. Reason number 1 million why we deserve some time apart, why it’s healthy for everyone. Because not everyone in our child’s life is us, and when they learn to navigate without us, they grow, even if it all comes crashing down when they’re back with us again. 

I’m 40 and when I see my mom, I sometimes come crashing down too 🤷🏻‍♀️

We all know those grown ups! Some of us 𝘢𝘳𝘦 those grown ups. 

Yesterday Matt wasn’t feeling well and the girls are still adjusting to us being back and wanting to spend as much time with us as possible (naturally!) they fight for our attention and have a hard time waiting. I get it. 

But waiting is part. of. life. and we all know the grown ups who have a very hard time in traffic, in long lines, when they ask for something and it doesn’t. happen. immediately. It starts right here👆

We can’t possibly never have our child wait - and when we try to avoid it at all costs - we’re not really helping them. Try to find small ways to build in waiting when it’s NOT a heated moment. Don’t just drop everything when you can help it, because that’s not the way the world works. We can say “I hear you!” and “it sometimes feels SO hard to wait!” and we can avoid just saying “one second.” When we reflexively say “one second” to our children, we not only give them an inaccurate answer to how long they need to wait for us, but we perpetually keep them in a state of waiting. They also start to not believe us when we say that and it becomes the same as not responding at all (basically).

Last pointer - be a good waiting model. Sing songs in traffic, play games in lines, model. patience. Say out loud “it feels so hard to wait right now! What can I do to help this feel easier?!” 

I find that saying “I’m just watching Tessie do her hop scotch and then I’ll help you!” is more effective than trying to watch both or instead of “one sec, one sec”  𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐢𝐭’𝐬 𝐣𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐡𝐨𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐭.

This also helps children to understand why we can’t drop everything for them at any given moment. They see or hear what we are doing. 

Because we don’t want our children to always have such a hard time when other people can’t just drop everything for them or to become those grown ups who just can’t tolerate it either.

This morning when I was talking to Nell about camp because she was anxious, I told her things I remember telling myself as a child going to camp. In this scroll. Camp is where I feel like I formed a relationship with myself, by being there for me. I have memories of self talk and saying things to myself to help me get through hard times at camp.⁣

She loved it and told me to write this down on a note for her to bring to camp: 

“I am my own own best friend.”

Can we all promise each other something? 
That we’ll always wonder about our child’s “misbehavior.” 

Here’s what happened today. Sometimes when Tess sings, Nell starts screaming for her to stop. She doesn’t want her to sing because she can’t as well as Tess. She doesn’t know the words like Tess does. It’s so frustrating for us all when Nell screams, that we usually just ask Tess to stop for now.

Whenever Nell cries recently, Tess giggles. It is BEYOND triggering for all of us. The first few times Tess did it, I admittedly snapped “stop it right now!” Then I started to almost expect it and I started to snap less but still would heatedly say “I’m not sure why you’re laughing when your sister cries but we have to figure it out.” After the third time of me saying this today, she blurted out “because you always focus on Nellie and tell me to stop singing or laughing for her but you don’t focus on me or tell her to stop crying for me!” 

It’s so true, the story behind your child’s “misbehavior” won’t make you angry, it will break your heart.

There’s always a moment when we get to choose. Our children do not force us to choose one way or another. We’re in charge of what we choose. Choose what you hope your children will choose in these exact moments one day. 

My favorite part of this is how much my 5.5 year old joined me in this moment when I chose calm over chaos.

It’s so much easier to get stuck with them. Try this instead.

Symbolically, this is deep, to invite your child to listen to the love you have for them, especially in a moment when they may be feeling shame, fear, guilt, all the difficult things that even we, as full adults, have a hard time sitting with. But more simply, this entices a child to stop, gets them out of their head and icky feeling, invites them listen to something and softens them just enough to open up or to get “unstuck.”

Now imagine if this was a tool used in couples therapy, if in a moment of intense frustration you spouse just came and opened their arms and said “listen right here, do you hear that love?” 🥹 

Seriously try this, with a toddler whose stuck in a tantrum, a threenager whose feeling ashamed, a teen whose pushing you away…

It’s called anticipation anxiety for a reason. Anticipate it and do something to 𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘦𝘷𝘪𝘢𝘵𝘦 it.⁣
⁣
If your child is used to crying at drop off and you know that they are cared for, safe, and just in a routine of anticipation anxiety - watch this reel. These are the things I tell myself. ⁣
⁣
In addition to this, we try to switch up the routine so that crying doesn’t just become 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐭 of it (this can happen, children just get “used” to crying at drop off and it becomes part of the routine, switching up the routine may help!) ⁣
⁣
The best thing we can convey to an anxious child is that we are not anxious, we are confident in them, we are confident in their caregivers, we are confident in ourselves as parents and the decision we have made to bring them to wherever it is they’re going. ⁣
⁣
I’ll tell you what doesn’t help an anxious child, an anxious parent whose telling their child not to cry.
⁣
Keep my words in your mind if they help, I know they help me! (and yes, Nell is screaming inside the car as I walk around and tell myself these things but everyday at pick up she assures me how much she loves it!)

Just here to say the parenting struggle is real but you get to a stage where you feel like it’s the best part of life - and not the in between that 𝘬𝘦𝘦𝘱𝘴 you from life. And if you haven’t reached that stage, just know I wish I got there sooner, where I embraced and lived for the chaotic juggle because that’s parenting, and the sooner you live it, the sooner you 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 𝘭𝘪𝘷𝘦. I promise.⁣ 
⁣
Scroll for what it takes to celebrate two friends turning 40 and showing up for them 𝐚𝐧𝐝 my girls. S’mores, baths, outfits changes and all - because you don’t have to choose between parenting and life. (the girls asked me to dress in my mermaid dress for tonight’s white party hence my multiple white outfits 🫠)

There’s that saying:⁣
⁣
𝘉𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘦 𝘺𝘰𝘶 𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘤𝘪𝘻𝘦 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘰𝘯𝘦, 𝘸𝘢𝘭𝘬 𝘢 𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘪𝘳 𝘴𝘩𝘰𝘦𝘴. ⁣
⁣
The same goes for our children. We don’t know what’s going on inside them when they exhibit behaviors over and over again. 𝘚𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 is going on and we jump to judge when we say things like I did this weekend.
⁣
Nell kept pushing Tess. I finally said to Nell “Should Tess push you?!” and “Look how you made her feel!” ⁣
⁣
But when we do that for a child who is still learning empathy, theory of mind and working through their 𝘰𝘸𝘯 feelings and emotions they will 𝐨𝐧𝐥𝐲 𝐟𝐞𝐞𝐥 𝐬𝐡𝐚𝐦𝐞.⁣
⁣
They already see what they did and when we put guilt and shame at the forefront of our response to a child’s behavior, thinking it will build empathy? Well I think we are missing the real opportunity to build empathy, by showing empathy to everyone. Even the child who pushed. ⁣
⁣
We have to explore and think about why they pushed in the first place, which is at the root of all of it. ⁣
⁣
Once we can address the root of it, that’s when empathy builds inside our child - 𝐛𝐞𝐜𝐚𝐮𝐬𝐞 𝐰𝐞 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐬𝐡𝐨𝐰𝐧 𝐞𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐭𝐡𝐲 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦. ⁣Check stories for what was behind the pushing episode!

I had so much going on in my head this morning. I’m parenting solo and just woke up feeling heavy. The girls wouldn’t play nicely on their own while I got everything ready for camp. But then I thought, why would they want to? 

They had been “apart” from me all night and woke up needing to be “fueled up” to be able to separate for camp where they share adult attention with 15 other kids all day. Naturally our children need connection when they need to embark on a day apart and won’t be with us all day. We wonder why they’re so “needy” and “won’t play” but sometimes all it takes is 5 min of whatever they want to do.

Nell’s anticipation anxiety gets the best of all of us as she asks about camp over and over - so 
I stopped my grind and said “ok we have 6 minutes to do whatever you want before we leave for camp!” They asked to dance. With me 🫠🙄

It was hard for me at first - I had so much on my mind and it was the very last thing I wanted to do. But I did, for 7 minutes and we all started our day so. much. smoother. 

No, you don’t need to make up a dance or even play if you don’t like to, just try to give your child a few minutes of focused time when you all need it. Just try saying “let’s do whatever YOU want for 5 minutes, as long as it’s safe and takes 5 minutes! YOU pick!” Give them the power to decide something for once. 

And that feeling that you never have enough time? Just let go of it up, for 5 minutes. The world - and you - will survive.

I’m parenting solo during the week and have found that my level of patience vs. Matt’s is really different on the weekends. He’s coming here on Fridays with a fresh start while I’m almost at the end of my rope. So when I saw Matt react to Nell’s seeming nonsensical tantrum about the car seat with “ok, let’s start from the beginning” I was in awe. Here I was in the front seat and could barely hide my frustration levels, while my husband was moving slowly, calmly and gently talking to Nell amidst her turmoil. 

When I shared this on stories, I got a message that stood out from the rest. It said:

“...what a beautiful moment. These are the moments that embed into our child’s psyche, into the bedrock of their souls. Or at least I believe that.”

This isn’t a belief, it’s a fact - the way we respond to our child’s emotions, feelings, outbursts, tantrums - impacts how they respond to and feel about themselves. Let’s play this out, if it were me buckling Nell, I may have said something that I’ve reflexively said recently:

“WHAT’S WRONG? Why are you crying right now?!”
Filled with judgment and invalidation - something that has caused Nell to get even more upset when I’ve said it without realizing and when dealing with my own triggers. Leaving a child embedded with “something is wrong with me! I’m crying but my grown up is saying there’s no reason or that it’s bothering them!”

Or we can do this - what you see here 👆. Respond with the most generous interpretation of what may be going on for our child. Leaving a child embedded with “who I am is ok, I am deserving of love even when I’m having a hard time.” 

*and let your other kids see that too.

This morning the girls asked to make breakfast. I had in my head that we’d just pick up bagels because i got home late from a friends birthday last night. My reflexive response was an immediate no. But then I <radically> thought “why not?” ⁣⁣Here’s a video from last year showing the same thing.
⁣⁣
There’s been articles stating that children hear no 𝐧𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐥𝐲 𝟒𝟎𝟎 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐚 𝐝𝐚𝐲!⁣⁣
⁣⁣
It’s not even about hearing the actual word “no,” it’s about restricting children from doing things all. the. time. We have to keep children safe and healthy but what about all the other times we reflexively turn down things they want to try, discover, explore? We take away opportunities to learn, to experience life, without even realizing and sometimes without good reason.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
When your child is constantly told no when it comes to learning new things how will they grow up to being open to or trying new experiences?⁣⁣
⁣⁣
I get it, they make messes, they want a lot of treats, they don’t want to sleep, they’re sometimes “out of control” but how do we support them through all of that? By actually letting them learn how to crack an egg, by making a mess and involving them in the clean up, by saying yes when we can handle to stretch a little. 
⁣⁣
And how do we support ourselves with going off schedule once in a while? By saying yes to it sometimes and seeing that not only is everyone ok, but you made some extra memories too.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
*Also, saying yes more doesn’t mean your child isn’t going to learn limits and boundaries. It also doesn’t mean that you’re giving your child “all the power,” it means that together you get to experience the power of saying “yes” to new things, even when the easier response is “no.”

You don’t have to lean into chaos when you can set expectations ahead of time.

When we are there to prepare and lead our children during daily routines, we should make statements instead of asking. Children are asked hundreds of questions per day as is, so when it comes time to do things and invite cooperation, don’t ask it, state it. Children thrive off of knowing what is going to happen ahead of time and being led by grown ups who are sure of themselves. For instance, saying “ok?” at the end of each statement is unnecessary and a reflex I work on myself. 

They need confident leaders to guide and to tell them what is expected of them. It. Makes. A. Difference.
We had a day 💔

The other day I wrote a note and put it in each of the girls backpacks for them to find while they were at camp. Another day I didn’t. They said “but mommy you didn’t put a note today!” and it felt ok to say “you’re right, I didn’t, was that disappointing? Some days you’ll get a note and some days you may not, but that’s what makes the note days extra special!” 

Instead of jumping on the hamster wheel of writing notes every single day, setting us all up for even bigger disappointment when I fall off that wheel. We can’t chase away their disappointments. 

Scroll for how I came to this realization and what we can do instead of avoiding or sugarcoating a disappointment.

What? Waiting? Like it’s hard?

Um yea and it’s definitely a muscle that needs strengthening, and more importantly, needs to be modeled! 

I often can’t handle the 0-100 of everything and how sometimes my girls immediately go to “MOMMYYYYY HELPPPPP” in the most chalkboard scratching whine of all time. ⁣
⁣
I want to just say “you guys really need to learn how to be more patient!” ⁣but I don’t because I remembered this one time when Nell’s nose was running a little and she did the excruciating whine for a wipe and Tess goes “Nell, you have to learn patience!” and I just laughed to myself at how ridiculous it was for me to have ever said that. We are telling a child they have to learn instead of helping them to 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 learn? Instead of modeling what we can do when we have to wait? ⁣
⁣
I said “that is the silliest thing I ever said. how can you learn if I don’t help to teach and show you?!”⁣
⁣
We all laughed and practiced what Nellie can say when she needs a wipe. Watch this reel for what we can ALL do when we have to wait. 
⁣

The goal is to help our child to eventually support themselves, with words like my daughter's, not words like:

"All my friends are out there doing it, what’s wrong with 𝐦𝐞 that I’m not."

Yesterday we had planned to go to the carnival of the summer. Before we even got in car, Tess was upset she was the last to the car and Nell was in tears about her sneakers and how her cousin and Tess were wearing sandals. I just said “Ok, from now on, only smiles!” They looked so wounded. It was kind of ridiculous. Why do they have to only smile? Imagine if someone said that to me - I’d want to slap them. Isn’t it all just about living and experiencing and feeling?⁣
⁣
I feel like I had a reflective moment in the carride after that, on our way there where, I reset myself and my expectations. I said to myself “Jennie, you know that activities like this are a lot for your girls, you know that they get really excited, stimulated and overwhelmed. You also know that there’s three of them to navigate since their cousin is visiting - so you’re also dealing with jealousy and dynamics between the three girls, expect meltdowns, expect chaos, allow it, welcome it, embrace it.” 

Basically, I set 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘪𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘤 expectations.⁣
⁣
When we got out of the car,  I knelt down and said this:⁣
⁣
“Being with you girls is my favorite thing in the world. I was having my own hard time, you were having your own hard time, we all had a hard time! Sometimes we say things we don’t mean to say. So I’m telling you right now, you can feel however you feel and I will always want to be with you.”⁣
⁣
I swear, I believe that these words changed their whole mood for the rest of the night - for the most part. Our children should never be made to feel like a burden for their emotions. And this may be the hardest thing in the entire world to not convey to them. ⁣
⁣
Their emotions don’t ruin plans, 𝐨𝐮𝐫 discomfort with 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 emotions might. ⁣

Real life.⁣
⁣
In all seriousness, when I share how I parent or guide you on what we can do to help our children get through hard feelings, it may seem like I’m suggesting that these tools should just magically take away tough things in their life. Or somehow make it all smooth sailing. It’s not that simple and I realized I don’t show enough of the process and real life of that. These aren’t some magic tricks in the moment (although sometimes, miraculously it actually does feel that way) but more toward a longer term goal of not getting rid of hard things and feelings in life (that’s impossible) 𝘣𝘶𝘵 𝘣𝘦𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘣𝘭𝘦 𝘵𝘰 help our child to 𝘨𝘦𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘶𝘨𝘩 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮.⁣
⁣
Yesterday when we went to get a gift for a friend and I knew that it would be hard for Nell to go into a toy store, pick a toy for someone else and leave without something for herself.⁣
⁣
I prepared her. I respected her. I set and held the boundary. Clearly it didn’t take away the hard feeling of not getting something she wanted, but I believe it perhaps helps make it even a teeny bit better inside her body to accept the difficulty of not getting something for herself even if we got something for someone else. ⁣
⁣
Think of what helps our children get through these real life things long term, for life, instead of giving in to the ease (more for ourselves) of the short term.

So here’s what I did tonight 🦷 🧚‍

Tess lost her first tooth while brushing her teeth before bed. I wasn’t sure if I should tell her the tale of the Tooth Fairy, because it’s not 100% honest, but playing pretend isn’t dishonest. It’s imaginative and magical. I told her: “some people say that if you leave your tooth under your pillow, magic may happen!” She asked what kind of magic, I said let’s see! 

Isn’t your parent putting a surprise under your pillow to acknowledge that you’re growing up, but saying that a fairy came too, some kind of magic?! What do you guys think? 

But also, how is her life happening so fast?!
Scroll for why I was proud of her.

This is last summer but it’s an activity we also did yesterday. It reminded me of how I’m a firm believer in “put them in water or go outside” when my kids are having those moments of incessant whining, fighting, or just being completely hyper - moments that I know are due to needing to get out energy. Whether it be that witching hour before dinner or after a mental depleting TV session, water and fresh air always help. Sometimes you also just need a second and immersing your kids in play is the definitely the way.

Here’s a simple sensory play experience where your children can discover how water and soap create suds, how a wet sponge can be squeezed to release soap and water, and how mixing and scrubbing can help the soap become even more “sudsy.” Also a soap ice cream parlor or cupcake stand is just genius (I even got involved for that!)

A question I love to ask during sensory play is “what happens to X when you do Y?” which helps children to discover how sensory materials change when they use them in certain ways. 

So I’ll ask you: what happens to your stress level when you put sponges, soap and water in front of your kids outside?

It all happened so fast 🤯 😂

Now can I blow 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 mind? When you believe that no sibling is a victim and no sibling is a perpetrator - watch how much that shift fosters a healthier sibling relationship.⁣
⁣
Watch this video and imagine that my older daughter has wanted to be seen in hundreds of mini moments where she feels my younger daughter quickly joins and “steals the show” - I’m not, by any means, saying that either one of them is the “victim” in the family dynamic, I am just saying that when you approach your child with the most generous interpretation, you don’t jump in and scold, punish, reprimand one of them constantly as much as you may have. We so often pit one child against the other, I find that it’s rarely about them being against each other but more about figuring out where they stand in OUR eyes. When a sibling does what Tess does in this video, I don’t feel it was directly about Nell, it was about me, my extra attention I remember giving Nell during a dance they were both doing - it was about feeling noticed by me. ⁣
⁣
If you got this far - this is what I said “Oh, no I won’t let you touch her like that, but looks like something is going on” and gave Tess the opportunity to think and self reflect on that too, she doesn’t respond every time but eventually it creates a routine of thinking about why we do something. Of course make sure your children are safe when they are being harmful to one another, of course jump in when you have to, but when you can, pause, take a second to think “what may this really be about?” Without victimizing one - you say things like “I saw all of that, what was going on for you guys?”⁣
⁣
It can truly change the trajectory of the sibling relationship that we are planting seeds for - sometimes for the rest of their lives. ⁣
⁣
#siblingrivalry #siblingdynamics #sisters #daughters #parentingtips 
⁣

All my life I was the “good” girl. I followed all the rules, I listened, I don’t even remember ever having a tantrum and neither do my parents. 

But here’s the thing with “good” kids - they need an outlet. They need space to “stretch” and to do some things that are “bad” because if they aren’t given this, if they aren’t urged and invited to draw outside societal lines sometimes, they stay in their safe corner until they explode. The exploding may take years or decades but every “good” child cracks at some point in their life - been there! 

My suggestion? For every child? Lead them to “safe - bad” behavior sometimes. Back off when you can, stop reflexively controlling or saying no when it may actually be ok to let it go. Give them a few inches even if your reflex is telling you otherwise. 

One of the main reasons I wanted to offer a messy play class at USP was to give parents and caregivers no choice but to let their children participate in something that was entirely up to them - it forces the grown up to let the child be.

I can guarantee if you don’t allow this, if you don’t laugh with your child blowing bubbles once in awhile instead of scolding and controlling them - if you don’t let them create, explore, climb or run - even when the safer, less annoying option is to tell them not to - they will do it on their own in some shape or form at some point - so why not be part of the exposure to healthy, happy, fun self expression and volition.

#Nellsmiddlefingertho 🙈

I’m without my kids this week and can’t tell you how much I miss taking care of them. Doing the things that often start to feel like chores or tasks - if we let them. 

This may be my favorite reel I have made. When I shared this a year ago it struck a chord with many of you, maybe because having a grandma still is very special - but hope it’s message is something that stays with you far after you watch it. Especially as we head into a new school year. When you’re caught up and treating the parenting journey like it’s a chore, remember this video. I know I need the reminder sometimes too. 

Being a parent is tiring and exhausting. We don’t get a break, we can all agree on that. One thing that we don’t realize is how we let this permeate through our energy and when our children can begin to feel it. We think our children are oblivious to it or won’t realize. We think we can hide it with an over enthusiastic, inauthentic tone, but the rushed hands, the facial expressions when we don’t think they can see, they can see and feel it.
⁣
My grandmother hadn’t seen me in a year, this was a moment we got to have when she put that sweater on me, something she hasn’t done in decades. We have hundreds of those moments every single day, and so its only human that it can become “chore” like. 

So here’s a reminder, which I do every so often. Start the school year off right. 
⁣
Our children are not chores, they shouldn’t feel like they are burdens. When we handle them, let’s take more moments to convey:⁣
⁣
“I see you, you’re worthy of my time. Just you.”⁣
⁣

If you have a child that sounds like mine, the ones who get stuck. The deep feeling ones who know, feel and embody all their feelings - those are the ones who just need to know that we’re not going anywhere. 

#kidswithbigfeelings
Can we all get on the same team?

Yesterday I cracked eggs with Nell and couldn’t fathom doing it any other way, she was already nervous but so excited to crack the egg - it just made my reaction to the prank that much more visceral. Besides the obvious, I realized why this egg cracking prank on young children disturbs me so deeply. I believe in respect for children from the day they’re born. I believe in the @rie.org.official approach to parenting, an approach so deeply rooted in respect for children that they are treated as active participants always. I let my children know, as much as humanly possible, before I touch them in any shape or form. I let them know before I wipe their nose, before I changed their diaper, before I’d pick them up, including them in every process that involved them, because they are just as much people as you and I. And yet here we are seeing video after video of parents all over the world smacking an egg on their child, not telling their child they’re about to hit them on the head, and doing so after they are giving their child the impression that they’re about to be active participants in an activity. An activity where they anticipate that they are being treated like a competent human, and then they are given the shock that they actually aren’t. 

Just a reminder that children, no matter how big or small, are people. Somehow, this reminder is needed (kind of mindblowing) because I know that we’d never smash an egg on a grown person and laugh. It’s unclear when, or where or how children became a population to disrespect and it’s one of the reasons I’m here to continuously set that record straight. Infants, babies, toddlers, children, are all worthy of respect and are no less human than any of us reading this.

#respectfulparenting #parentingwithrespect
#parentsofinstagram #eggcrackingprank 
#momsofinstagram #parentingtips

When siblings fight with one another our reflex is to work on getting them to get along. We dive in and try to figure out who’s at fault, who needs to say sorry, who is “wrong” and who is “right.” 

Picture this: our children are trying to be seen by us and we’re busy with life. In different ways they’re trying to get us to connect with them. When we don’t, they turn to their sibling to try to get to us because it gets our attention. Instead of us responding with connection, we respond with scolding and it further disconnects us. Then our child tries harder to get our attention, perhaps with more focus on bothering their sibling to do so, and the whole thing is a toxic cycle.

What if instead we made note of this mentally. We thought “ah ha! My child needs to connect with me! I’m going to respond with connection, I’m going to say - I wonder what’s going on here! Instead of immediately scolding one and defending the other.” 

Today Tess kept nagging Nell on the car ride and I wanted to just scold her. Then I thought about how when I do that, it disconnects us more and the nagging can just get worse. I thought about how Tess does this when she’s looking for more from me - I was preoccupied, on my phone. So I just set boundaries “not gonna let you poke her like that” and then I made more connection points “but I am gonna sit right here, put my phone away and play I spy with you both!” 

It’s like responding by finding ways to reassure our children with one important reminder:

“You know that I am always your parent and love you very much. I am also your sibling’s parent and love them very much too. I am a parent to both of you. Forever and ever.”

I know this seems too simple to matter but the repetition of questions is just the start of it. When we don’t stop to answer or look at our child, they’ll just keep behaving in ways to get us to. 

Also, think of how frustrating it is for us when we ask our child something and they barely respond or acknowledge, doesn’t it make you wanna repeat YOURself? Don’t you want to say “look at me when I’m talking to you?”

Repeated questions are often just our child’s way of saying the same thing. 

The other day Nell asked me something, something like “mom do you remember when we went to that place where they have the fishies in the tank?” and I said “yes, I remember!” She asked again “member mom? member?” I said “yea! I do!” as I was walking around cleaning. Then she asked again - the. same. exact. question. I stopped and looked at her and said “my love, why do you keep asking? I do remember!” and she goes “because you didn’t look at me!” 

Mic Drop. You can thank Nellie for this reel.

We all got this 🫶⁣

I believe that the majority of the battles in the morning relate to one of two things (or a combination of both) 

Our child is stalling because they don’t want to separate from us.

They want to be the decision makers and assert their independence (and power). 

A visual schedule solves both of these challenges. It gives our child time to connect with us even if it’s a few minutes of discussing what photo comes next in their routine; and nus encouraging them to place the photos on the velcro in the right order. It also gives them comfort in seeing themselves in these photos. It’s like fuel to separate. You can even have your child take one or two with them on the way to school (for instance if you have a photo of them in the car, or on their walk and a photo of them arriving at the school door) even a photo of them giving you a hug for them to take in their backpack! 

It also really empowers our child to feel independent and in control of their own routine. I believe a lot of children are resisting when were just giving orders each morning:

“Time to get up!”
“Time to brush teeth!”
“Oh that’s nice honey, but it’s time to get dressed!”
“Let’s go, we’re going to be late, go pee pee!”

I don’t blame them for resisting that in the morning, I’d resist that too! 

Make this schedule, buy the velcro, it’s worth it a million times over. We need to update our photos but we still use this visual schedule from 3 years ago!

*laminate photos or print coasters from @shutterfly

Tess is starting Kindergarten this week and I’m reminded of how much this feels like the start of her “real life.” 

How much starts now. 

How much I know it doesn’t get easier from here. 

But we can change how kids treat one another, because it starts with us. So I wrote this letter to us.

What if we all really tried to do these things? Really made sure not to discredit our child’s feelings, not to pick on them.

Because bullies coerce, intimidate, and threaten those that are more vulnerable than them. 

So I guess above anything else, remember what you’re modeling and what example you’re setting in how you treat your child, it shapes how they treat others including my own. 

I’m taking my own request seriously too, I promise.

As a mom with two kids starting brand new schools and two kids whose drop offs may look very different from the other, this is a reminder I need too. 

The crying, clinging child only feels it’s harder when the adults around them indicate that they aren’t supposed to feel how they feel. That something’s “wrong,” instead of “this is hard, it takes time, you’re safe and I love you.” ⁣
⁣
What’s wrong here is us thinking that whoever our child is doesn’t fit the “they did great” mold. They all do. I promise you. 𝐘𝐨𝐮 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐝𝐨 𝐭𝐨𝐨.⁣

So many of you ask about this so it deserved a reel.⁣
⁣
I know at the end of this week (and next too) we’ll all collapse - we’ve restrained ourselves from doing so all day each day. It’s the emotions of dropping off my baby at Kindergarten, holding it together, restraining from bringing it into all other aspects of life, and then basically letting it all out on Matt when he gets home from work 🙈. But that’s why it’s called 𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘵𝘳𝘢𝘪𝘯𝘵 𝘤𝘰𝘭𝘭𝘢𝘱𝘴𝘦. It’s what our children experience at the end of most (if not all) school days. Some days it’s their energy and the inability to not run off the walls and jump anywhere and everywhere (literally), some days it’s tears, some days it’s seeming “disrespect” and “meanness” other days it’s as if something took over their bodies and it seems like they’re ruined. ⁣
⁣
Some things I do to help them with this is: ⁣
⁣
1️⃣I talk to 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮 about their day instead of asking the teacher, in front of them, how their day was. I immediately include them by addressing both them and their teachers “how was the day!?”⁣
⁣
2️⃣I anticipate it, I don’t show disappointment in it, I remind myself this doesn’t mean that school “broke them.” I know that school is tiring, it’s hard to eat in a new setting, and there’s so many new social interactions that take a lot of bandwidth. ⁣
⁣
3️⃣I bring a snack and water at pick up.⁣
⁣
4️⃣I give them opportunity to let out their sillies - by running down safe streets, jumping, hopping, singing instead of shushing until they’re in the car and have no ability to control this energy. ⁣
⁣
5️⃣I try not to focus only on school by bombarding them with questions.⁣
⁣
6️⃣I try to be mindful to not be on autopilot after school - instead I try to connect and fuel them up after we’ve been apart. ⁣⁣⁣
⁣
7️⃣I try to remember that I am. their. safe. space. I need to remain that, they’ve waited all day to let this out, how can I then tell them they can’t?⁣

8️⃣They can’t apologize for it and shouldn’t, so I’m apologizing for them, they don’t mean what they say or do, they just feel safe to do it all…because they’re with us. So in your mind just think “you don’t have to hold it together anymore, you’re home.”

I asked my girls separately this same question today.

“What makes your heart happy?”

Nell said “being with youuuuu.”
Tess said “mommy and daddy!”

We fill their heart with comfort, warmth and happiness. 
We make their hearts happy. 

Our children will become increasingly more of a teen - moods, attitudes, impatience. They’ll close their eyes and refuse to answer us, they’ll say things that feel like a slap in our face, we’ll be livid inside. This happened to us today - my child refused to get out of the car, respond to me, or open her eyes. But in the 5 second walk out of the car to the trunk, I thought of when my child is actually a teenager, I reminded myself that no child behaves like this unless they are STRUGGLING inside. So I asked Matt to go ahead with my other child and I got into the back seat next to my struggling. child and asked “want a hug?” to which she shook her head yes. 

It will not always be as easy as this story - sometimes we’ll ask if they want a hug and they’ll scream in our face “NO GO AWAY I HATE YOU” and we’ll want to scream right back. But we must find it in us to respond to our child with love. When we don’t, when we punish them for things that are out of their control, we impact our relationship with them. Our child starts to give up and becomes seemingly more defiant because they. can’t. help. it. and. we. aren’t. helping. them. 

Do we want to try to connect through what is happening within our child now or do we want to start a dynamic of toxicity and power struggles because of our ego’s? A relationship that will become increasingly harder to connect in? I choose, as much as I possibly can, to believe that giving my child love, even when they are behaving in ways that hurt my heart, is what they need most in those moments.

Some of us grew up hating our bodies.

Some of us grew up wishing we had different bodies.

Some of us got teased, taunted, picked apart about our bodies.

The number one thing I believe that can immunize our children to keep security around their bodies? Let them hear us sometimes compliment ours, and let them watch us appreciate the diversity of our own bodies.

I got a message back in June I hadn’t seen until last night - it was about what I wore on my birthday. The person shamed me for wearing a revealing dress and asked why I had to be naked on my birthday - she went as far as saying what a poor example I’m setting for my children, sarcastically called me a “class act.” With no idea what my own body journey has been. And the truth is, I didn’t see myself as naked that night, I saw myself just as Nell sees herself here, secure in the body I have and wearing what felt great for MYSELF.

“Use your words!!”

One of the most frequently used lines used that, somehow, became accepted as a way of “connecting” with our children in moments of distress. 

I don’t know about you, but when I’m just overly frustrated, angry, sad, or experiencing a lot of hard feelings, the 𝐥𝐚𝐬𝐭 thing I want to hear while I’m “in it” is:⁣
⁣
“WHAT’S WRONG?! JUST TELL ME WHAT’S WRONG!”⁣
⁣
When asked in that intense way (that we tend to ask of our children) doesn’t it sort of feels like someone is asking “what’s wrong with 𝐲𝐨𝐮?”⁣
⁣
Sometimes I know that “what’s wrong” may sound ridiculous to others. Sometimes it feels like there’s a laundry list of what’s wrong and trying to put that list together in that moment makes it all feel so much worse. Sometimes I don’t even know what’s wrong!⁣
⁣
We all use the phrase “use your words” and these words absolutely can have a place in connecting with our children or encouraging them to use verbal communication. However, when we lean on these words 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘦𝘴 𝘰𝘧 𝘢 𝘵𝘢𝘯𝘵𝘳𝘶𝘮 or in the middle of our child hysterically crying, it can actually feel really disconnecting and frustrating. ⁣Most likely, our child can’t find the words, can’t regulate to say them, and here we are asking them to, almost scolding them to.
⁣
So, how do we help a child feel understood in those moments?

Acknowledge: 
“I see how upset you are right now.”
”You’re really angry about something!”
”It looks like you have A LOT of feelings right now!” 

Connect:
”I’m right here.”
”I’m not going anywhere”
Offer a hug. 

Regulate:
Sing a song.
Hum.
Just be there.

Something I remembered during the emotions of the weekend:⁣
⁣
𝘚𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘵𝘪𝘮𝘦𝘴 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳𝘦’𝘴 𝘯𝘰 𝘴𝘰𝘭𝘶𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘵𝘰 𝘢𝘯 𝘦𝘮𝘰𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯.⁣
⁣
Not only do our children need to know that, but perhaps more importantly, 𝐰𝐞 do.⁣
⁣
Maybe one of the most meaningful things to offer when our child (or any of us!) is overwhelmed with emotions is:⁣
⁣
 “do you need help? or a hug?” ⁣
⁣
𝗪𝐞’𝐫𝐞 often the ones who need to fix our child’s emotions and we don’t think to offer anything else except solutions. Emotions don’t always have solutions. Mine this weekend didn’t. Many of our child’s emotions now and even more so in the future won’t have solutions either (omg their first heartbreak 💔😭). I also think it’s even more comforting to basically say “I’m ok with your emotions and I’m here to offer whatever you need even if it’s not to fix it.”⁣
⁣
So next time try saying “help or a hug?” Just try it.

Hear me out.⁣
⁣
You may think “yea ok Jennie, how do I find glimmers when my child wakes me up the entire night and is officially up at 5 am, refuses to listen, then clings to me at drop off and the day spirals - you expect me to find calm?” ⁣
⁣
But that’s. exactly. it. It’s cyclic. ⁣
⁣
Our children don’t wake up looking for glimmers, they get triggered, then we get triggered into anxiety mode, they get triggered into cling mode, we spiral from there back and forth until bedtime and then it happens all over again.⁣
⁣
I brought this up in moms group, the things that make us spiral, the things we judge ourselves for, get overwhelmed by and how it all consumes our glimmers. But the glimmers are always there and when we can anticipate and look for them, well, guess what? ⁣
⁣
Our. kids. will. too. ⁣
⁣
So here’s what I mean:⁣
You arrive at school 3 minutes late. You could hurriedly whisk your child out of the car seat,⁣stroller, whatever vessel they’re in and basically toss them into their day because you’re triggered you’re the only failure parent whose late OR think “ok we’re late anyway, let’s stop and look at the fish tank today!” That’s a glimmer. It immediately changes the trajectory of your mood, day and 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝’𝐬 𝐭𝐨𝐨.⁣
⁣
If you need more motivation to do this, think of all the times you ask yourself “why is my child making such a big deal out of this?!” ⁣
⁣
Well, hey, why do we?⁣

Tess was almost 4 here. 

This is what I do instead of telling them they’re pretty because there are just so many other more important things to say to them about them. 

I tell them what I see on the inside and ask them what they see on the inside too.

I think this exercise is really powerful not just for us to do with our children, but also to do with ourselves 𝐢𝐧 𝐟𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐭 𝐨𝐟 our children.

When you’re struggling through a week of your daughter’s separation anxiety at every drop off but feel so grateful to another 3 year old who reaches out their hand for your child’s. 🥹⁣
⁣
This is the thing, just like every human, some children have a harder time somewhere new with new people and gain more comfort as they begin 𝐭𝐨 𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐬𝐞 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞. When separating from us, they need someone else to then attach to, without that person(s) its not easy! Imagine showing up to a wedding and not knowing a soul, then imagine showing up and maybe knowing one person, just an acquaintance, then compare that to knowing maybe 2, 3 closer friends, you gain more comfort the more people you know and the better you know them. The teachers matter but so do all the little humans, more than you know. 🥹

Aren’t there people in your life who have a hard time accepting boundaries? Who when you say you can’t make it or it doesn’t work for you, they respond by trying to convince you otherwise? Sometimes relentlessly?⁣
⁣
What I know is this, the more we pressure, bribe, or lie to our kids to get them to do things, the more likely they’ll grow up to do the same to others. ⁣
⁣
We can actually 𝘵𝘦𝘢𝘤𝘩 children the wrong message, without even realizing it. ⁣
⁣
When we force our children to say hi, to hug, to kiss, to say thank you, to say sorry, to do anything that truly should come from their own volition, we communicate “If I am told to do these things before I feel it inside, then other people should do what I want even if they don’t feel it inside.” ⁣
⁣
When we pressure our children and don’t consider their boundaries, over time we are telling them to do the same to others.⁣
⁣
Scroll for adjustments we can make to help undo these tendencies to ignore boundaries our children are messaging to us, and instead to actually consider them.⁣

You all appreciated Part I so much so I made another! 

The reactions to this one may feel very “that’s easier said than done” but the short of this is that we can start out with as simple of a reaction as these examples and that could be enough for your child to feel seen, heard, validated and honored. If we’ve already turned to some of the examples that aren’t the most optimal here, it can be less simple at first, your child may continue to push, resist and need more - the key is to stay confident in the simplicity of some of these responses, to help your child scale back on it being about more than just hearing and understanding them.

Dedicated to all the people on IG who have told me I’m raising snowflakes…

Bravery isn’t what happens when we raise a child who is trained to believe that their feelings don’t matter. Bravery isn’t ignoring our child’s feelings and telling them that “not crying” is brave. Bravery doesn’t come from children who are raised through threats, bribes, and often fear. 

One time the girls got shots at the doctor. Tess didn’t cry and Nell did. When we were leaving we heard another girl crying and coming out of the room. She came into the elevator with us still whimpering.

I looked at her and said “getting shots can feel hard!” and Tess said “I got a shot! I didn’t cry! But Nellie did.”

The girls mom said “wow you are so brave!” 

I didn’t miss a beat before saying to her child “Nellie and you are so brave too! We are still brave if we cry! You all got a shot today!”

The mom said “you’re so right!” 

I know I’ve said this before but it’s a good time to remind us all of it again - Because when we tell a child that they’re brave because they didn’t cry, we don’t know if they didn’t cry because they held it in, because they suppressed how they really feel, or because they didn’t want to seem “weak” or “not brave.”

I think bravery is the ability to face fear, to get through a hard situation and to not to hold in emotion. All of that comes from allowing our child to feel. I’ll tell you right now and here, raising children to feel brave enough to show how they feel will never be the wrong way.

Find your co regulation, its sort of the best secret handshake that ever existed. 

There are so many times lately where Nell is dysregulated and I want to just snap her out of it because it’s over something like a missing toy, a hair out of place, sunglasses she can’t find, and I want to just say “these are materials, stop it!” 

It’s hard to admit, but I have used language I am not proud of. This morning when I was about to walk Tess into her classroom and wanted Tess to have a nice goodbye knowing I wasn’t going to see her until after dinner - Nell starting getting all upset about her hair bow. I whispered “no more crying over a bow” or “you have to stop.” 

Yup. Even I say these things sometimes. Uch. It’s the worst feeling ever. 

The point of this is to say that those moments of “snap TF out of it” never work. When they start to, that’s a dangerous point because we have trained our child to turn off feelings. Wanna know what does work? Co-regulation. 

It can take the shape of whatever works for you and your child but after modeling your own regulation and finding a way that resonates with your child for them to regulate with you - preserve that. 

Here’s an example:
Nell is upset. I am about to get really angry about it and instead I remember what works. “Do you want a hug, I think you need a hug.” to which she usually resists but kind of thinks about. I come closer to her, open my arms or put her head in my shoulder and that usually results in her melting entirely into me. Other times I may say “touch my nose” and then we touch noses and breathe for a second or two. Things like this help a child feel safe again. So, yea, find that co regulation - I call it a secret handshake.

Also, I know some of us haven’t been able to help but show some of our emotions throughout the last 48 hours. I hope something in here helps those who need it. Also, remember, two things can be true, we can be hurting so much but can still let our kids be our glimmers.

It is a complete understatement to say that what has transpired is absolutely devastating. I have felt paralyzed by it at times. Unable to see any way to not focus on it for many parts of the day, and then I have spiraled into “why aren’t people sharing?” or “what has come to humanity?” and so on. Things that have no answer and only lead to a dark place. 

I received a text message from a dear friend yesterday, it was a quote from Mr. Rogers. He used to say that in every horrible situation or circumstance there are always people trying to help. “Look for the helpers” he’d say. 

That’s what we are right now. Those of us speaking out. We’re the helpers. And when you really think about it, it’s overwhelmingly incredible just how many helpers there are. Here, in Israel, in the world. Just knowing that there are always good people present trying to help. That’s the glimmer. There are just always helpers. 

Be a helper. For the world, for the people still missing, for our children. Just be a helper.

“When you ask for peace, you’re asking not to kill a stranger’s child and imagine that you’re accomplishing something.” words said by @sharonstone 

This is for all the parents out there feeling the pain of this war. If you feel this war, no matter your religion, identity, background, beliefs, your heart is breaking. You see images you can’t unsee, you’re juggling deep deep emotions while trying to be the mom you need to be for your children and you feel absolutely helpless. I have had discussions and conversations with people of all backgrounds, some very passionate ones, some that have turned into arguments, and today I thought “these are mothers, I’m a mother, we know and see the suffering of so many, this is all the same fight, we just want this to end but none of us can see how.” I don’t know the answers, I’m not here to pretend I do, or to turn this page into a political platform, I’m here because I share my beliefs, thoughts, parenting and my LIFE with you. 

So I’m going to share a belief of mine right now. I want all of you to know that at our core, if you’re on this page, I believe we’re fighting the same fight, we want the world to be safe for our children. We may differ (deeply) with how this can happen but I want to remind us all what fight we should be having. One that fights for peace.

This reel is a somewhat humorous take on how often our children feel “dragged” through life (poor Nell at the farm last weekend!) I know I talk about this often but this one is from Tess herself.⁣
⁣
I was dressing my 5 year old one morning and she goes:⁣
⁣
“Mom you’re usually so nice, now you’re just 𝘥𝘳𝘢𝘨𝘨𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘮𝘦.” ⁣
⁣
I said “I am so happy you pointed that out. I am distracted and rushing. I never ever want you to feel dragged! I’m sorry.” ⁣
⁣
Right then and there my entire energy shifted and lasted through the day. The biggest road block to this shift, is our expectations. When we 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘦𝘤𝘵 we’ll see everything at the farm, we’re bound to “drag” them, when we 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘦𝘤𝘵 quick and fast dressing each morning, we start to rush and drag too. Set realistic expectations, because when we don’t, as much as we think it’s our child’s fault, ⁣
⁣
𝘪𝘵’𝘴 𝘰𝘯 𝘶𝘴. ⁣
⁣
When you’re actually able to be in the moment with your child, it forces you to put everything else away, it’s like meditating. 𝘛𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘭 𝘸𝘰𝘳𝘵𝘩𝘺. So this is your reminder, despite the world, the distractions, the noise, to be in moments with your child, because 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐰𝐞 𝐬𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐥𝐨𝐯𝐞, 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡 𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐚𝐫𝐞. ⁣

I was cooking dinner last night. All of a sudden the large tub of cous cous fell off the counter and onto the floor. I immediately said “UCH SH*T!” and my body went into automatic, self shame mode “uch Jennie you’re such an idiot. Why didn’t you put the top on the couscous!” ⁣
⁣
On occasion, Matt may jokingly say “Jennn you’re always such a mess in the kitchen” and I thought about how much it bothers me when he says it because I just believe we work differently. I’m the type that makes a mess when I cook (and I clean up after), he’s the type that cleans as he goes. I don’t believe one way is the right way - 𝐢𝐭’𝐬 𝐣𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐝𝐢𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐞𝐧𝐭. ⁣
⁣
Anyway, I thought about how bad that would have felt in that moment if he had brought that up then, if he had said “Jen! See! If you had listened to me and put the top on the cous cous that wouldn’t have happened!” ⁣
⁣
I thought about all the times the girls spill and how much I humanize that and let them know “it happens to all of us!” Even if the spill happens after they didn’t listen to something I said to do, that could’ve avoided the spill or “mistake.”⁣
⁣
Look at the two photos in my stories, the mess was at 5:11 p.m. and the mess was cleaned up by 5:13 p.m. 2 minutes later. Is 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 worth shame? Do I need the shame in order to learn my “lesson?” Had he helped me clean it up (if he were home he would have 🙏) would that have made me 𝐧𝐨𝐭 learn my lesson? ⁣
⁣
Have trust in your child, 𝘪𝘯 𝘩𝘶𝘮𝘢𝘯𝘴, to learn without shame. ⁣
⁣
And never ever forget this:⁣
⁣
𝐒𝐡𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐦𝐚𝐲 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 𝐥𝐨𝐯𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐲𝐨𝐮, 𝐛𝐮𝐭 𝐢𝐭 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐜𝐡𝐚𝐧𝐠𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐢𝐫 𝐥𝐨𝐯𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐯𝐞𝐬. ⁣
⁣
⁣

I have told you all how much I work 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 my children when they are slow to warm up instead of 𝘢𝘨𝘢𝘪𝘯𝘴𝘵 them. How pushing a child to do things they aren’t ready to do, even if it’s a “hi” wont help them to feel comfortable saying “hi” to someone. For years I have honored that about Tess. Knowing this is who she is, preparing her and saying things like “You can say hi when you’re ready to.” I’m all for showing and modeling to our children the way we should behave in the world. That means, yes we greet people, we say “hello,” we smile when we see someone we know, we say “bye,” and “thank you.” ⁣
⁣
Now that she’s almost 6, I do feel that she’s at the age where she knows that she needs to say hello to her friends and teachers, even if it’s hard for her to do. I know that inside, she wants to feel comfortable with these things and just needs tools to access so that she can overcome the initial anxiety or discomfort to muster up the courage to greet people (as an example). ⁣
⁣
Today one of my friends asked me what to do because her child is similar. I started talking to her child and her child didn’t answer me. I said “you don’t have to answer, but if you want to, here’s a game. If you’re having a good time at this party, touch your nose, if you’re not, stomp your feet!” The child slowly smiled and touched her nose. This immediately warmed her up. That’s what a lot of our children need in order to get past that initial “freezing up.” ⁣
⁣
Here are some more tools:⁣
Before going into a place you know is hard for your child to warm up, prepare them for what they can do when they get there “when we walk in, it may feel like a lot of people are there, when everyone comes to say hi, if you’re not ready, you can smile and wave!” ⁣
⁣
Practice beforehand. Role play. “Ok Tess, I’m gonna be Dylan, and then I pretend to be her friend and say “Hi Tessie!!!” This helps to bring Tess to that place before she’s in that actual place, so that when she is, she’s already had a dress rehearsal. ⁣
⁣
And then a similar game to the one I mentioned above - “Tess, Dylan is saying hi. I know you want to say hi back, right? If you want to say hi, give her a high five!”

How do I stay this calm in the face of their discomfort? Practice. ⁣You have to start somewhere. The first time you truly stay calm helps you for the next time. That’s why it feels too hard to even attempt, no one is born good at being calm in the face of not calm feelings! 
⁣
How do I put aside the natural human tendency to want to end their discomfort and crying immediately and sometimes urgently? Foresight. ⁣I think of how the ability to tolerate our own discomfort takes learning and that reaching for quick fixes is something I deeply don’t want them to do, now or later in life.
⁣
I ultimately always think:
“If I don’t practice this how can 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐲? “

“Are they still fighting mommy?”⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“Yes. They are. Hopefully they’ll stop soon.”⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“How do they know when to stop?”⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“When everyone is back together, when everyone feels safe.”⁣⁣
⁣⁣
As I write this, I want to add one last answer to my daughter’s question this morning.⁣⁣
⁣⁣
“The fighting stops when everyone 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘭𝘴 peace.”⁣⁣

How many of us believe that when our child is hesitant to participate or “slow to warm up,” that they miss out on things?⁣
⁣
I think most of us feel deep down that our child would enjoy so many more experiences, if they would just try it or open up. We wanna say “can’t you just 𝘵𝘳𝘺 it? Can’t you just go with your friends? you’re gonna love it, it will make you so happy if you just give it a chance.” That’s probably the most triggering part of having kids like this, we feel they’re missing out on parts of life. ⁣
⁣
This isn’t to say that every slow to warm or shy child is missing out or that it’s a negative personality trait, it’s more to say that we want our child to be able to experience things that we know would make their lives better.⁣
⁣
This is why I use tools and help prepare my girls for experiences, so that when they are faced with an experience that they do want to try or do, they’ll have tools to do so.⁣
⁣
So when I heard Tess practicing in the back seat, it felt like this tool had not only helped her in situations I had been with her for, but in situations when I 𝐜𝐚𝐧’𝐭 𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐧 𝐛𝐞 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐡 𝐡𝐞𝐫 𝐭𝐨 𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰 𝐬𝐡𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝𝐬 𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐩.

That night I asked her if practicing helped, if she raised her hand. She said “yes mommy! I was the first one today!” 

It was first hand evidence that my almost 6 year old had internalized a tool that will help her throughout her entire life.

Today in moms group a mom asked why her child was so challenging when it came to wiping his nose. Another parent brought up challenges with food, another challenges with bedtime.⁣
⁣
When my girls have challenges like this, it always makes me self reflect. Not as if their challenge is 𝘣𝘦𝘤𝘢𝘶𝘴𝘦 of me, but more because there must be something I can adjust to help them. It made me think of this video and how putting myself in my kids shoes almost always helps me to support them better.⁣

⁣I shared this video a few years ago. I wanted to really focus on how sensitive it is to feed someone else. How the goal is to connect with our child but it’s also a process for our child to learn to trust their own body. To tell us when they’re finished, to read their cues and signals for when they’re not, but most importantly to keep this as a process that is about them. ⁣
⁣
We have to ask ourselves: Do we feed our⁣
children with respect or with an agenda? Do we feed them to get it over with? To rush? To get as much food in? To limit the food? Because we don’t trust their own bodily cues? Because we know what their bodies need better than them?⁣
⁣
Does your child throw food? Why? To experiment? For attention? To protest? To assert their independence? Because we’re rushing? Not focused on them? Doing the dishes?⁣
⁣
Basically this video is meant to make us pause and do the following:⁣
⁣
Picture yourself in your child’s chair next time you feed them and think about how it may feel. What is respectful and what may not be? Where can you slow down? What can you adjust?

This is a reel from last year that I’m resharing in honor of Nell’s birthday today.

The one who knocks me off my feet 𝘥𝘢𝘺 𝘢𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘥𝘢𝘺. ⁣
⁣
The reason my life feels like it has to stop just to get through each hill of her emotions. ⁣
⁣
The one who holds on, any way she can, to control her uncontrollable world.⁣

⁣But the highlight, I keep reminding myself, is when she puts me in my place, yells through tears “𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐦𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐲, 𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐦 𝐝𝐨𝐰𝐧!!” ⁣or “look at me mommy!” or “hug me and help me” when she really needs it.
⁣
and who decided to finally use the potty when I said “let’s take our time, let’s just be together and see what happens” - basically 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐜𝐡𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐰𝐡𝐨 𝐥𝐞𝐭 𝐠𝐨 𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐲 𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 𝐝𝐢𝐝 𝐭𝐨𝐨.⁣
⁣
The one who told me one day a few months ago “no more pull ups at night” and despite me warning her she’ll wake up in a pool of pee, actually never needed one ever again.

These children, they’re going to change the world, 𝘸𝘦 𝘫𝘶𝘴𝘵 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘰 𝘭𝘦𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮.⁣
⁣
My advice: stop trying to control them, they’re seeming desire to resist, do it themselves, do it their way, and anything else is actually them screaming out “𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐝, 𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐭𝐨 𝐛𝐞 𝐬𝐞𝐞𝐧….𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐞𝐱𝐚𝐜𝐭𝐥𝐲 𝐦𝐞.”⁣ Now more than ever - I appreciate how important it is to let these children be who they are: unapologetically themselves. They’re the ones who already know how to fight for what is right and scream for what is wrong. 

Happy birthday my Nellie Bellie, my sassy sensitive fireball who lets everyone know that you’ve arrived no matter where you go. Who loves and feels so so deeply. The fiercest girl I know (I really mean that!) My sidekick, my best friend, my love, my soul. I can’t wait to see you change the world. #FOUR
