Our kids will have their feelings hurt, that’s inevitable. But to be their own built-in best friend? To be able to talk to themselves about how someone else’s behavior does not change the way our child should feel about themselves?
That isn’t inevitable, but these are things we can help them with. I remind them that when others do things or say things that don’t feel right, that means that person is having their own hard time. (I even remind them of this when I lose my patience or yell, that’s my own hard time!)

I also remind them over and over that they are their own best friend. This is truly so powerful. This helps them to remember that their self worth does not depend on others feelings, opinions, behaviors or inclusion of our children. Their self worth is always there because they have a voice inside that says: “Hey Tess! I’m right here, I love you just like Mommy and Daddy love you and I am always here for you.”

I think that using these tools is the closest thing to a hurt feelings immunization that we can get. Feelings are gonna get hurt but let’s not let them change how our child feels about themselves (we have all probably been there and the effects can last a very long time).

Hard stop. This video will make every single human parent feel guilt. That is not the point because of course we have all been the “me” in this video in some shape or form. We have an endless list of things to do, things to clean, organize, cross off our list, and to take care of. Anything but multitasking feels unproductive. But, again, that’s not the point here. ⁣
⁣
Here 𝐢𝐬 the point:⁣
⁣
There are so many times we keep asking our child to do something over and over “it’s time to leave the park, its time to go now, we have to go, come on, why aren’t you listening?!” and our child will say “ok one more swing!” or “wait I just need to do this slide one last time!” and they keep going until we explode. ⁣
⁣
But look at me here, I’m representing how we expect our child to cooperate, listen and work with us when we aren’t giving them that same respect. ⁣
⁣
Becoming a parent is building a relationship with someone, our child. We ask of them and they ask of us. The roles are very different, of course, but it’s a mutual relationship. It’s not a training camp. ⁣
⁣
So here’s the reminder, don’t do the dishes during dinner, or just honestly say “I’ll come sit down with you, just have to get a few things cleaned up!” ⁣
⁣
Honesty, respect, and connection will breed cooperation, we just have to remember to be part of that equation too. ⁣
⁣
Your child will more likely want to listen, cooperate, participate, and work with you if you do the same.

More of this: cheering each other on for the good and less knocking each other down. 

There’s something about young children supporting one another. At an age when empathy is still developing, to see children genuinely take on a desire to support another friend is pretty special. 

Today when Nell was nervous to do this specific exercise in gymnastics, her friends started cheering for and encouraging her. I don’t even truly believe she was nervous about this physical move but more nervous to do it in front of her friends and that she wouldn’t get it “right.”

I know that if I were there trying to encourage her it would not have been this effective and that she absolutely needed her friends to help her through it. 

Wanna know how we create kids like this? By modeling positive support for one another. So remember this in your partnerships, marriages, friendships, to cheer each other on. Talk less sh*t about one another. Come together more, life each other up and show obviously happiness for others.

One of the things I knew early on in parenting is that:

“Fair isn’t always equal.” Siblings shouldn’t always have everything the same just to avoid conflict or hard feelings.

That is, until I turned around and realized I became the mom who reflexively DID keep it all equal.

Here’s why: my own guilt. 

I realized that with every conversation I had with one of my girls, I felt guilty when it wasn’t equal. Almost as if things each of them had were an indicator of my amount of love or something. The conversations felt hard to have. For awhile, and often still, they even dress the same because of it. I wanted to avoid “I want her dress! Why did Nell get that dress and I didn’t?”

We all have different reasons for why we may want to keep things “equal” between siblings but I’m your guinea pig, I regret it. You can never keep up with equal. Fair doesn’t always mean equal or having the same exact thing. 

Their birthdays was the first real sign of this. For the last three years I did their birthdays together to avoid one having the spotlight and not the other. Except this year Tess was upset that Nell’s actual birthday is on 11/4 and was always going to come before Tess’s which is 11/30. “Why is Nellie’s birthday before mine? Why every year?”

Jealousy became pervasive. I realized that me keeping things equal wasn’t helping - it was avoiding a very real thing that they need support and tools with NOW for the rest of their lives. Comparing and jealousy.

So I started over. I stopped getting them both the same exact things, I started responding to one’s questions of “why does only she have it?” with “hmmmm let’s try and figure that out together.” I started having conversations with them instead. Asking things like “what feels wrong with her pancake being bigger?“

Today at Nell’s party, Tess was genuinely happy for her. Nell sat in a literal throne the entire time and Tess sat there smiling with her.

Do I blame myself for the roadblocks they’ve had in dealing with jealousy? No. Do I think I was helping them whatsoever by trying to always keep things “equal?” No shot.

When you look into what causes a child to be a perfectionist, it’s having a highly critical parent, who puts pressure on a child, and who sets impossibly high standards for their child. I know, with certainty, that many of us right here have children with perfectionist tendencies and yet we are none of these things as parents. We embrace mistakes, we avoid shame, we give ourselves and our children grace when we make mistakes. So how do we help our child who has a desire for perfection when we are already doing so much to make sure we aren’t creating it? ⁣
⁣
Challenge their unhealthy thinking tendencies. Don’t convince them out of them, that will rarely work and don’t shame them, that will backfire. ⁣
⁣
Start conversations like this:
“I see you ripping out page after page drawing the same circle. What feels wrong about the circle?”⁣
“IT’S SO BAD, IT’S THE WORST CIRCLE EVER!”⁣
𝐀𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐝 𝐬𝐚𝐲𝐢𝐧𝐠: “Oh my goodness sweetie, stop saying that! This circle is BEAUTIFUL! I LOVE IT! IT’S JUST PERFECT THE WAY IT IS!” ⁣
That will most likely exacerbate our child’s hypnotic state their in with one goal in mind: unattainable perfection. ⁣
⁣
Keep talking…⁣
⁣
“Ah ok I see. You think this circle isn’t good. What feels not good about it?”⁣
⁣

It’s 𝘯𝘰𝘵 about the exact questions, it’s about showing curiosity in what our child is feeling to model 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮 to have this own mindfulness in 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘪𝘳 𝘰𝘸𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘴 𝘸𝘦𝘭𝘭. ⁣⁣
⁣
A few other things I’ve done:⁣
-Adjusted my child’s word usage: “it feels like you can’t do it, but I see you doing it!”⁣
-Created a cape: this cape can have any super power, if our child is trying over and over again to make the perfect circle, it can be a “cape of oops” we can stop our child and say “do you need your cape? You know, the cape that gives you the power to make oops’s and that creates other amazing things from it?”⁣
-Used playfulness: “Ok, you don’t have what you call the best circle drawn here, but I bet you can’t draw ten circles that AREN’T perfect?”⁣

A letter to the future Tess and Nell I wrote last year but updated a bit. This explains it all. Why we do the work. 

I could’ve written this reel to be hours long.
There’s so much more to add!

But it comes down to how I sign off:

“I love you exactly for you.”

Imagine how many hours of therapy were saving our children, if this becomes what they tell themselves: 

“I love you for exactly you.”

There are some hugs that we give that are quick and casual and some that just need to be longer. I saw this challenge a few weeks ago and it’s something I have changed and have seen a difference with. I purposely don’t let go first and I can’t tell you how many hugs last longer when I leave it up to them. It’s like I didn’t even realize how much they probably need hugs - don’t we all?

After Tess’s birthday party tonight I wanted to see how long her hug would last. It lasted so long that Matt got sick of filming it and people kept passing by. Whether it’s because birthdays can just feel like a lot, or she was grateful or there were so many people around and we didn’t really hug during the party, whatever it was, it was one of the ones she wanted to last longer.

This simple thing can be the instant shift you make that can make such a difference in your child feeling more connected, something they all need and don’t know how to ask for.

Thanksgiving. Such a warm holiday when family comes together. But holidays can feel hard once you become a parent. You see all these adults interacting with your child, adults that are important people in your and your child’s life. Sometimes it can feel like your child is receiving so many different messages from these important people. 

But when it comes to certain things, we all have our own non negotiables; you know the ones. The things we really can’t stomach our child hearing mixed messages about. 

Well here are mine. Hoping it helps you for your own. 

So many of you ask me “what do I do when I hear someone parenting my child differently than I do? How do I know when I should say something or just let it go?”⁣⁣

My answer: be the louder voice.

Here’s what it turns into:

One night, Tess started crying bc I wouldn’t let her have juice before bed. I overheard my mom go into Tess’s room and try to make Tess laugh, and then I heard my mom said “ok now no more crying.” (She meant this in a loving way)

I cringed for a sec, I so much never put a cap on how much they can cry, I never tell them when to stop… then I heard Tess say loudly “don’t say that! why do so many people say that!” and I walked in smiling and said “that’s right Tess! you don’t have to stop crying!” 

𝐈 𝐰𝐚𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐥𝐨𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐯𝐨𝐢𝐜𝐞. I want to believe that for the rest of her life when anyone tells her to “stop crying, stop being dramatic, stop being so sensitive” that she’ll have the confidence and trust in her emotions (herself!) to remember that voice.

Probably one of my most favorite traditions we created last year. I hope it lasts for generations. 

How you teach empathy is right here: helping your children to think of others in a way that isn’t shaming them or guilting them but supporting them. We have so much to be grateful for and should spread that gratitude. 

Happy Thanksgiving everyone!

I make so many mistakes in parenting. Like every day. 

How do I really know when I make a mistake? Besides when it just feels not right? When I think about how it could play out long term.

When someone says to them “tell me about your parents when you were growing up” I know that I never ever want them to say “my parents were always making me feel bad about…

𝘢𝘯𝘺𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨.”

An example that comes to mind:
When they make a mess, despite how frustrating it can be, I know that making them feel bad won’t necessarily make them more careful, it will just potentially make them remember how bad they felt when they made a mess. 

Basically, I never want my kid to remember me parenting as a bully. And it takes a lot of intention and mindfulness to make sure of that. 

Even when our kids do wrong, the goal is to instill in them how to learn from things, not have them feel bad about things so that they avoid it in the future. 

Thinking backward like this has shaped so much of how I parent. So I loved when I saw @jada_dannielle share a similar reel.

“No one wants to play with me.”⁣
⁣
“You just hate me!”⁣
⁣
Comments like this can feel really hurtful and concerning when they come out of our child’s mouth. Most likely it’s just a sign of their “immature” way of thinking. Black-and-white thinking. For a lot of children, it’s hard to access the gray area of reasoning. They think in all or nothing terms. If we say no to something, they just focus on all the things we say no to. If they aren’t enjoying something, they focus on not enjoying anything. It’s a less mature thinking process, especially when a child is dysregulated or stressed. The area of the brain that is responsible for more reasonable thinking is the last to fully develop, not until our early 20s! ⁣
⁣
How quickly children are able to come out of the black-and-white thinking is related to how supported they were during the emotional reasoning period of development - up to 10 years old. ⁣
⁣
The way to help our child is not to attempt to disagree which would have them just hold these thoughts 𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐧 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐫𝐢𝐠𝐢𝐝𝐥𝐲 (often the response to someone trying to convince them why their way of thinking is wrong). The goal is to encourage 𝐦𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐟𝐥𝐞𝐱𝐢𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 in thinking. ⁣
⁣
Some ways to respond:⁣
⁣
𝐀𝐬𝐤 𝐫𝐞𝐟𝐥𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐪𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬:⁣
“No one likes me!”⁣
“Wow, do you always feel that way? When we walked into your classroom this morning and everyone said hi, how do you think they felt about you?” ⁣
⁣
𝐏𝐥𝐚𝐲𝐟𝐮𝐥𝐧𝐞𝐬𝐬:⁣
Name the black and white thought. “Oh I hear the mean monster - is that him talking?”⁣
I want to remind that mean monster that I saw a lot of people loving you today, can you help me let him know? ⁣
⁣
𝐏𝐫𝐨𝐯𝐞 𝐢𝐧 𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐥 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞:⁣
“You think no one likes you….hmmmm, Daddy what do you think, are you liking Tess?”⁣
⁣
𝐌𝐨𝐝𝐞𝐥:⁣
And lastly, recognize when 𝘺𝘰𝘶 are guilty of black and white thinking, we all do it sometimes⁣
“Uch I can’t cook!”⁣
⁣Stop, recognize, playfully narrate gray thinking out loud for your child to hear:
“Of course I CAN cook, I’m just having trouble cooking THIS! I know the more I cook, the better I’ll probably get!”⁣
⁣

Tess, you’re 6! ⁣
⁣
The best 6 years because a world with you in it is the best kind of world. ⁣
⁣
Let me explain. You feel, not just the regular way, but the way that stops you in your tracks. When you were just a baby, your tears and smiles were sometimes just because you saw one of us smile or because you heard another baby cry. ⁣
⁣
As a toddler, when you’d see or hear an ambulance your reactions made me realize that these sounds and sights would never become background to you the way they do for every other New Yorker in existence. They make you curious and concerned about whose hurt or in trouble.⁣
⁣
As a preschooler, your feelings were the type that when someone in class was upset or cried, it sometimes made you upset too. Your teachers said we should make you a “box of feelings” that you could go to when things felt like too much. You felt so much of what others felt. ⁣
⁣
Now, as a Kindergartener those feelings make you so fierce and strong. Not just for yourself, but for others. You tell me when you feel that someone has made a wrong choice because “it didn’t feel right” you tell your friends “let’s not talk about that” when maybe they say something that doesn’t feel so good. 𝐘𝐨𝐮 comfort Nell even if she’s crying because she feels bad that she’s done something wrong to 𝐲𝐨𝐮! 𝐘𝐨𝐮 comfort 𝐡𝐞𝐫! You tell me when I’m “not being nice” and you also tell me “of course you can cry!” when I apologize the few times you’ve seen me cry.⁣

You stand up for what’s right, you feel for what’s wrong. Imagine a world if everyone was like that?! Anyone watching this can agree that a world with this smile in it, is a brighter one and with people like you in it, it’s a better one.

There’s 2 things at hand here: knowing what’s 𝘣𝘦𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘥 the language and also the 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭 language being used. ⁣
⁣
First, let’s just acknowledge that I knew my child didn’t 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 mean stupid and probably meant:⁣
“You look different!” or “I don’t want you to leave.”⁣
⁣
So I said “Maybe you’re not used to seeing me like this! but you can use a different word to tell me that. The word stupid doesn’t sound like the right word.” What other word can we use? We laughed at all the different words they said “like a vampire!” Then, once it felt light, we talked about how it’s hard to say bye for the night. ⁣
⁣
Imagine how much more effective this is instead of scolding, esp at a time when it was already gonna be tough to say bye.⁣
⁣
If I had more time, I’d have extended the conversation even more. “Where did you hear that word? It’s an interesting word you chose!”⁣
Because as our children socialize more and are exposed to all different families and people, there will inevitably be exposure to things that don’t sit well with us. ⁣How do we handle this? ⁣
How do we tell our children that the word “stupid” is bad when they may hear their friend use this word all the time? So is their friend bad because he said that word?⁣⁣
⁣
I find that the best way to handle this is to talk to our children, even at a young age:⁣⁣
“You know I heard your friend use the word stupid today. I know that we talked about how that isn’t a good word to use. Every family has their own rules and things that are important. In our family it’s important to use words that won’t hurt people. Stupid can be a hurtful word. What are some other words that your friend can use?”⁣⁣
⁣
Children begin to comprehend the concept of their own family’s values and feel confident in creating their own, even when it’s different from those around them.

All jokes aside. I’m ready for the “such a double standard” comments about how my husband sits leisurely at lunch while I am getting what can be assumed to be the “raw end” of the deal. But I challenge that assumption. I actually think our roles in this situation are 𝐛𝐨𝐭𝐡 tough and enjoyable - just like most of parenting tends to be. Matt didn’t say “I’m gonna just sit by myself while you guys sit there.” He 𝘸𝘢𝘯𝘵𝘦𝘥 to sit with our kids but they both wanted to sit with me, not because they love him less than me, but kids are nuanced individuals just like everyone else in the world, they’re just not afraid to express it. ⁣
⁣
They knew I had the activities in my bag and know that I love to do table activities with them. They also know that if I was feeling too depleted to do anything that I’d express those needs. I’d say “today daddy is excited to play tic tac toe with you! I’m feeling too tired and want to relax and drink my coffee.” There may be protests but at their age (and if they were feeling connected) they’d accept that, because of the times my husband and I do set boundaries around our needs. We work as a team as much as possible. ⁣
⁣
Also, some of us prefer to be the one sitting with the kids whether at a restaurant or on an airplane, because it’s sometimes just easier - not because the other partner isn’t capable but because maybe that’s the role that made sense, whereas maybe our partners’ role is doing bath and bedtime. ⁣
⁣
The point is, we have no idea, and we tend to judge, almost attack, videos like this.⁣
⁣
When you go to dinner, don’t you sometimes prefer to sit with one friend over the other?
Long winded way of saying let’s stop judging books by their cover and not take parental preference personally. The real trigger here for me was matt eating off our plates 🤣

“Ok but it’s our secret! Don’t tell your sister. She’ll be upset.”

These words seem so innocent and reflexive. It’s a tactic we use and almost feel good about because it can feel like it brings us closer to one of our kids in a way.

But think of why we use this tool: to avoid one sibling feeling upset. 

Think more about what this tool does each time:
Does it help the child who were keeping this secret from, until when? When do they learn to accept disappointment when their sibling gets something they can’t have if we are always avoiding them feeling it? 

It also tells one child they should be sneaky about getting something the other sibling can’t get, and that they have to keep it a secret because something good for them can make their sibling feel bad. It enmeshes feelings and can make one child feel almost responsible for another’s. Like they’re the protector of their siblings feelings. It’s too much responsibility. And what dynamic are we instilling with encouraging sneakiness like this?

If you’re a parent who uses this tool, maybe even “don’t tell mommy I gave you an extra candy!” We see you dads! Lol but regardless, don’t feel badly after this reel. This is as much for any for you as it is for me. Start small, start by noticing each time you go to use this tool, is it once in a blue moon or is it regularly? 

Also it’s important to note that telling a child to keep any “secret” can be dangerous. We don’t want anyone else telling them something is ok and is “their little secret” so it’s good to avoid getting into this habit. Do we want they to grow up thinking it’s normal for adults to say “don’t tell?”

This came to light for me the other weekend when nell was having a sleepover with a friend and Tess wasn’t. Whenever nell wanted to talk about it - it felt weird to tell her she couldn’t. Or to expect Nell to “keep it a secret.” Inevitably it resulted in a really tough day for Tess, but she got through it, they always do.

There’s no such thing as “too attached.” Attachment is a normal physiological occurrence in our child’s life and development. 

But, if you’re like me, you definitely have thoughts run through your mind “Have I been too involved? Created too much dependence? Why won’t they let anyone else put them to bed?” But then I see Tess, how slowly, gradually but surely, she’s opened up to others. She now tells Nell “mommy is getting ready, daddy is going to read to us tonight, it’s ok!” She got there through secure attachment. I see Nell, whose separation anxiety, at times, seemed debilitating. Whose relentless tears when I’d leave for dinner, have turned into a teary “make sure to give me a hug before you go!” 

Dependence creates independence. They can’t get to security within themselves without security through us first.

If we don’t say bye, if we sneak out, or don’t leave altogether in order to make our children seemingly “happy,” what we’re really doing is manipulating - not intentionally, not maliciously, but we’re trying to control their emotions to not feel anything but “happy.”

Ask yourself is it for their sake or ours? Because the guilt would eat us up while we were out? Because we want to feel like a “good parent?” Or because we truly believe they won’t get through it?

Leaving our child even when they’re upset is ironically one of the most selfless things we can do. One day, when my girls have to go somewhere and their child isn’t happy about it, I hope they know they not only deserves to do it but that they should for the sake of their child.

I share all of this to say to any of you in a similar situation, that you must tell yourself this, no matter how hard it feels:⁣
⁣
“I have to leave, not because it’s that important of a dinner or date, but because I need to show us both that 𝐰𝐞 𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐠𝐞𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬.” ⁣

I always say:
Children don’t CHOOSE to have a hard time.

When your child is on the floor having a tantrum, say this to yourself too.

Here’s why. Children aren’t born with tools. We weren’t born with them either. When you see a child unable to regulate, they are lacking tools. When you see a child who is growing up continuously unable to regulate, this child’s caregivers may be lacking tools to give them (or this child may have specific challenges that continuously make it harder to learn regulation skills). I still don’t believe they’re bad or that they’re choosing to behave this way. 

This is why I see no reason for yelling at or shaming a child. When we are modeling our inability to regulate (yelling and shaming) how do we possibly expect our children to learn how to regulate?

We’re all human and it sometimes happens but children who are the “most difficult” need the most tools. Children who look at you and laugh as they are seemingly “purposely” not listening, are in the need of the most connection. Their laughter is nervousness and awkwardness in how to ask for it. 

No matter what you believe - just know that when you believe there are “no bad kids” you will see that your children become “easier” because you are finally understanding that they are in need.

Even if you aren’t fully convinced of what I’m saying in this post, I hope you’ll remember it.

When your children are seeking your attention - please know they are seeking connection. 

Even if you just pause and say “I know it feels like you want me to stop, I want you to know even though we are rushing to get there on time, I am still here.” 
Even if you stop and just say “I know it’s hard when I’m talking to a lot of grown ups, I’m here and won’t let go of your hand. 
Even if you aren’t fixing the hundreds of things they are asking you to fix, even if you aren’t able to quite get them “unlost” you are helping them to feel found. 

Stop for the lost child. 

If you can truly grasp this concept, you know what to do when your child is whining, clinging, and seemingly “being needy.” When you respond with moments of connection, the whining lessens, your child feels more seen, and they grow up more secure.

This morning, we had Tess’s holiday breakfast at school. It was chaos as usual finding everything we needed to get everyone ready. Tess had just gotten sparkly boots for Hannukah and when she got them last week she said “I can’t wait to wear them for the holiday breakfast!” 

Well this morning, I couldn’t find them. I couldn’t let it go. I couldn’t leave without looking in “one more place.” I didn’t let her know I was looking and looking because she was handling it well. Finally, I had to let it go to get out the door on time. It was hard to do honestly. It wasn’t about the boots, it was about the “plan” and about not disappointing her.  I don’t even know if you’d understand the feeling just by reading this. 

I do know what you would understand -  when you’re feeling off, and you have to drag yourself to a dinner and you want to wear your favorite pair of jeans. But you can’t find them. 

That’s what our children feel each time they fixate on something seemingly small. When they can’t leave the house on time. When they can’t get dressed. When their pancake isn’t the right size. It’s the case of the missing jeans. Something feels very necessary and real and urgent about it even if no one understands why. 

I have had 39 years to grapple with this feeling and I can tell you that if anyone said to me this morning “come on we have to go, it’s not a big deal” I would have wanted to cry lol. What I would have wanted was someone to come over and say “I’m not sure why you want her to have these boots so badly but I see that something about it feels very important to you. Even if we can’t find it, I want you to know I will help you look when we have more time. I’m here to give you a hug if you want it.”

Before you approach your child with the belief that they’re being “silly” or “dramatic,” try to connect with them instead, and tell yourself:

“This is a big deal to my child, even if I don’t understand why.”

*The boots ended up being in the car and she got to wear them after all 🫠

“But I turned out ok.”⁣
“But you turned out ok.”⁣
⁣
Lines we tell ourselves or that our parents tell us - do you want to know why? Because we learn to put aside, suppress or distract from hard truths. One hard truth is to acknowledge where we didn’t turn out ok. That doesn’t necessarily mean we’re not “normal” or that we are not “sane,” it means we are human. No human is perfect or ok in every single area of their life. There’s always a corner that we struggle in. But so many of us never go to that corner, but that corner is always there and when we never go there, we never grow as a person, but also as a parent. We continue to stay away from that corner and then our children grow up to never go to that corner either. What a lot of people have learned to do, over time, is to suppress or distract from really hard emotions, and that turns into something - something that is actually 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘰𝘬.⁣
⁣
The other day, I had a tough moment with Nell. I can tell the whole story here but I’ll skip to the important part - we were both dysregulated, and in the midst of it, she said “I need help to calm down! I need help to calm down!” ⁣
⁣
It stopped me dead in my dysregulated tracks and I was floored that my child, only on this earth for 4 years, was able to, in the midst of emotional chaos, recognize what she needed. Instead of swallowing, suppressing, muscling through - she said what most of us are unable to say even at 30, 40, 50, 60 years old. 𝗪𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐩 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐦 𝐝𝐨𝐰𝐧. We never learned how to help ourselves to calm down. So we yell, we form bad habits, we have constant anxiety, we distract, we ignore, and we let it all pile up. ⁣
⁣
Next time you or your child is having a tough time, use this line out loud “𝐰𝐞 need help to calm down!” ⁣
⁣
Imagine, just imagine, in those moments that feel so out of control as a person, as a couple or as a family, if you could say “hold on! We need help to calm down!” How. Much. Better. We. All. Would. Be.

I gave the girls a gift for the holidays - Tess opened hers first and loved it, til Nell opened hers. Tess went from happy to jealous. It took everything in me not to shut her down as “not being grateful.” I’m sharing it here because I learned something. 

Here’s what happened: Tess got upset her gift wasn’t as “good” as Nellie’s which came with a few extra accessories. Yes this is when the “what a brat” thoughts came into my head too. When I reminded her how much she initially loved her gift she stormed off to her room. I thought “I am just gonna let her stew, so rude of her, so ungrateful.” But something made me go into her room as I said to myself “just be there.” 

I walked in and said “I thought you would like something different than Nellie, if you’re still feeling like you want hers we can exchange it.” After some silence from her and pouting, I said “ok I’m just gonna lay here.” After a little, she turned and said “thank you mommy.” I said “for what?” She said “for being in here with me.” 

We never solved the jealousy tantrum in that moment but she got through it and so did I. The next day we went to the store and I offered to “exchange” her gift. She didn’t want to. She wanted to keep hers. 

Here’s the takeaway: I think a child sometimes feels our love wrapped into things like this. I believe Tess initially thought “mommy must love Nellie more, her gift had more than mine.” Once I gave her the time vs my anger I believe I reassured her that my love has nothing to do with these gifts, and that’s when her jealousy faded. 

Now go through this scenario imagining if I had said “you’re so ungrateful Tess! I went and picked these gifts!” Or anything I initially wanted to say. You may still think she was rude, but I think she’s a child experiencing things for the first time and that I, as the adult, have the opportunity to help her experience them. I’d rather help my child understand gifts are gifts and that the size, shape, or amount has nothing to do with how loved they are and that the solve for wanting something else isn’t to be shamed into “forced gratitude” or to go out and get it.

Resharing the reel that I shared in honor of Matt’s birthday last year because it’s an important one. 

Happy Birthday to the dad and husband who reminds us every single day just how valuable and loved we are, and who truly doesn’t have to raise the game on how to show us. You may not be able to handle a single tool 🔨 or replace the garbage bag, but you’ve taught me about all the things that are so much more important.

I couldn’t ask for a more loving father to show our girls how they deserve to be loved.

A friend said this to me today when I told her how the world lost my Suba two nights ago. She said “to leave this world not sick and on your own terms is pretty special.” 

It’s exceptional just like Suba. 

102 years. 

My earliest memories of you are you pinching my cheeks so hard every time you saw me and talking about me in third person about how I was the most precious thing.

But everything was precious to you Suba. Not just me. All of us were. Every experience, every possession, every bite of food, every single moment. You saved and salvaged everything. 

You most likely saved your entire family’s life when you went to Israel at Tess’s age - to escape anti semitism in Poland - that you were a victim of at the young age of 6. Every day you’ve been alive since October I’ve thought to myself Suba is truly “Am Yisrael Chai.”

You saved the Jcrew hat I got you for only very very special occasions, pointing out so delicately how it “was a real real Panama hat! Made in Panama!” I have it now to wear in your honor. 

Every time you came to visit you stayed in my childhood bedroom and always talked about how gracious I was to give it you and Supta. At the time I just felt like it was nothing, of course I’d give up my room for you to visit! Now I realize how precious you knew that was, but it shows how precious you’ve always been to me.

You’re a part of all of us. 
Especially Supta, she says she feels you in every corner ❤️
I reminded her what you always say, “hasta la vista!”

2023, where do I begin. There’s something really transformative when you experience deep sadness while being the rock of your family. It reminded me that two things must almost always be true. We can go through some of the hardest times in life, we can let our guard down, even as a parent, and also feel so unbelievably grateful in between, making sure to express that too. 2023 taught me that being vulnerable, being honest in how we feel, is how we remain the strongest pillar in our family. There’s nothing heroic about pretending to be a superhero while our kids are young, only for them to feel pressure to be the same until one day they find out it wasn’t true. 2023 taught me that the truest way to parent is by being true to myself and my family. By telling my kids, appropriately, when things feel hard instead of muscling through and leaving them in the dark. 

My girls learned about some of the hardest things that even we as adults struggle to talk about. But I also made sure to tell them and show them during the smallest moments when I was happy. I made sure to radically have fun even when every fiber of my body didn’t think I could. Even if it was just while tying their shoe, taking a second to smile and say “I love being with you.” Or when I’d turn on a song in the car after an epic meltdown before school and we’d start singing. I want my children to look back and think “mom LOVED being with us, she had fun being with us, she was so happy to be with us.” ⁣⁣

Despite 2023 and all it came with, I know they went to bed every night knowing how much I loved them.

Couldn’t do any of it without all of you.

You know those times your kids fight or get really angered, upset or frustrated by something moments before walking into school, going into a party, or when going to a family gathering? And you wanna just tell them to snap out of it because you know they’re going to bring some of that mood with them? But you can’t because how do we just ask a child to “snap out of it?”

The other day we were arriving at our friends house in florida and Tess and nell had just had a “fight.” We validated but Tess was still frustrated. I knew her mood would follow her when we arrived at her friends. So I let matt and nell get out of the car and thought of this and gave it a try. I said

“So I see angry is still here, do you feel her here?” This lightened the mood already. Then I continue, “Ok angry, we see you, we heard you, but we’re gonna leave you in the car because we don’t know if there’s room for you at this play date…” more smiles came.

“Tess wanna politely tell her we’ll see her later if we need to? We’ll call her?”

And then the best was when she gently told her own anger she wanted to leave it behind.

The girls have been off of school for 2 weeks and our mornings have felt so much more relaxed. Thinking about going back to school tomorrow, 𝐈 even started getting anxious - so I imagine they probably are too. I didn’t want to just continue into 2024 feeling like I have no choice but to wake up each day to such a struggle - leaving us all so depleted before even starting our days. ⁣
⁣
As I thought about how to go into the new year in a more optimal way, I realized what I could adjust. Each morning during the week, I’m so consumed with getting us out the door that I am not even giving us a chance to connect in the micro ways that we could be connecting. There’s a lot of these micro connections, we sometimes just wake up consumed that I think we miss them. I haven’t missed them over the last 2 weeks. I’ve noticed them, and it makes such a difference.⁣
⁣
When they wake up earlier than I wanted, I’m not going to snooze and have them watch TV. Maybe we’ll all brush our teeth and help me make my coffee or unload the dishwasher. When they say “mommy look how cool! My yogurt is turning pink from the sprinkles!” I won’t respond with “ok but please eat, we’re going to be late!” Because then a moment later they’ll try again, and again, and again until, of course, I’ll get aggravated that we’re now late and it will spiral. ⁣
⁣
This isn’t unrealistic, this isn’t self sacrificing, it’s actually helping us and our children at the same time. I saw that a simple response adjustment on my part like “oh wow! How do you think the yogurt turned pink like that?!” instead of “eat or we’ll be late!” has been the change that I have seen work wonders over the break. ⁣
⁣
This adjustment could not only get us out the door on time but remind us how we actually should live life with our kids.⁣
⁣

It’s really hard to remain calm and not to evoke stress when we are around babies and children until we become a bit more seasoned. On top of that, all of us have our own stress triggers, some of us can’t handle messy situations, some of us are very safety concerned, some of us are very overwhelmed by big emotions. But let me tell you, when we can find our calm in the face of things that can automatically evoke immediate stress, we are doing something huge for our children. We are expressing trust; not only in our children (that empowers them to trust themselves) but trust in ourselves and our ability to get through any day of parenting (and there are many of them). ⁣
⁣
I could go on and on about how our mentality and attitude is contagious for our children but instead I’ll say to read below for how you can adjust some of your reflexive responses. Some of my favorite ways to respond to seemingly “big deals” that don’t need to be.⁣
⁣
When our child gets hurt - and we know they are ok:⁣
Instead of “OH MY GOD! Are you ok?”⁣
or frantically saying “you’re ok!”⁣
Say: “I saw that!” with genuine care, and then describe what happened so that our child can process WTF just happened. ⁣
Part of the uneasiness is that something happened that they did not expect or want to happen. ⁣
⁣
When our child is feeling something big and we have no idea what it is:⁣
Instead of Instead of frantically saying ⁣
“use your words!!!” ⁣
say “I’m here. You’re feeling something big.”⁣
The most impactful way to help your child calm down enough to communicate isn’t by begging them to communicate but is through co regulation. Saying you are there is the start of a child feeling safe enough to calm down.⁣
⁣
⁣
When our child is doing something that could result in an injury or a mess:⁣
Instead of “be careful!!! Stop!!” which likely could startle them enough to stop exploring or cause an immediate injury (and always conveys a perpetual mistrust in them) we can say “It looks like you’re close the edge of that curb, do you see your feet?” or “I’m going to sit close by to help you use this material) which will help your child build an awareness of sensory exploration, their body and space.⁣

“You’re not listening to me.” 
Yes, I want to say it 800 times a day.

But why is it that “not obeying” is every parent’s perception of “not listening?”

Listening means hearing. When our children don’t do what we say that does not equate that they “aren’t listening.” 

Ways to rethink “not listening” include:

Talk about what it means to “listen.” Both to your child, to yourself and other caregivers. 

Every time you reflexively think “my child isn’t listening” remember that you’re really saying “my child isn’t obeying” and it will force you to reapproach the situation more productively. 

Start to adjust your responses when your child is having a hard time cooperating, see your child and tell them you see them “you really want to keep watching tv, I can see that, you have 2 more minutes and then i’m going to turn it off” instead of “come to brush your teeth, no more tv” and then saying our child “isnt’ listening” when they don’t just obey that. 

Think about what it takes to get on the same page with any human when there is a consistent challenge in a relationship - it takes connection and problem solving. When something isn’t working (example: your child consistently has a hard time cooperating in the morning or before bedtime) change the routine and include your child. Diffuse the prior wiring that your child had. 

When my child “isn’t listening,” I imagine my child is subconsciously thinking something like “I wake up, this is when mommy orders me to do things and I don’t want to do them because I’m nervous for school and this is when I assert myself and don’t cooperate” and then I think of how that can be replaced with something like: “Mommy and I made a new routine plan last night, I’m gonna wake up and do it with her! We said we’d wake up, pick one of the outfits we laid out together last night and then I’m going to brush my teeth all by myself while she does! This is fun to do this with mommy and to feel like I’m helping us both. It makes me feel proud of myself!”

Waiting is part of life and we all know the grown ups who have a very hard time in traffic, in long lines, when they ask for something and it doesn’t. happen. immediately. 

Building that tolerance, patience and tools to wait in life, well It starts right here👆

Yesterday we had to wait for our friends to go into the museum and Nell had a hard time. Matt kept asking “should we just go in instead of waiting?” and something made me create this tool that somehow worked. I picked up Nell, asked her to touch my nose (she likes doing this because she knows I’m focused on her - doesn’t mean you have to do this to) and I said “repeat what I say.” Each thing I said, seemed fo bring her more calm and somehow extended her tolerance for waiting. 

We can’t possibly never have our child wait - and when we try to avoid it at all costs - we’re not really helping them. Try to find small ways to build in waiting when it’s NOT a heated moment. Don’t just drop everything when you can help it, because that’s not the way the world works. We need to be a good waiting model. Sing songs in traffic, play games in lines, and model patience. Say out loud “it feels so hard to wait right now! What can I do to help this feel easier?!” 

Because we don’t want our children to always have such a hard time when other people can’t just drop everything for them or to become those grown ups who just can’t tolerate it either.

We all want our child to be “good” - I get it. It’s easier, it reflects well for us, and it’s less stressful. But here’s the thing with “good” kids - they need an outlet. All kids do. They need space to “stretch” and to do some things that are “bad” because if they aren’t given this, if they aren’t urged and invited to draw outside societal lines sometimes, they stay in their safe corner until they explode. The exploding may take years or decades but every “good” child cracks at some point in their life - been there! 

My suggestion? For every child? Lead them to “safe - bad” behavior sometimes. Back off when you realize “what’s the big deal?” - stop reflexively controlling or saying no when it may actually be ok to let it go. Give them a few inches even if your reflex is telling you otherwise. Letting them jump on a bed safely vs giving no “outlet” doesn’t do anyone good, I know from trying to manage 25 four year olds in a classroom. Sometimes saying “ok let’s all jump down the hallway and see what the other students think when they see us!” I truly like encouraging some rebellious behavior safely has no downside. It lets a child know you trust them vs want to control them 24/7. We’d go back to the classroom and children could manage their bodies that much better. 

One of the main reasons I wanted to offer a messy play class at USP was to give parents and caregivers no choice but to let their children participate in something that was entirely up to them - it forces the grown up to let the child be.

You can apply this to any area when we try to overly restrict: food, moving, behaving, running, wearing, expressing, behaving, all of it. 

I can guarantee if you don’t allow this, if you don’t laugh with your child blowing bubbles once in awhile instead of scolding and controlling them - let them jump in a puddle or two - if you don’t let them create, explore, climb or run - even when the safer, less annoying option is to tell them not to - they will do it on their own in some shape or form at some point - so why not be part of the exposure to healthy, happy, fun self expression and volition. 

#Nellsmiddlefingertho 🙈

This is a true story and a really important reminder.

When siblings fight with one another our reflex is to work on getting them to get along. We dive in and try to figure out who’s at fault, who needs to say sorry, who is “wrong” and who is “right.” 

Picture this: our children are trying to be seen by us and we’re busy with life. In different ways they’re trying to get us to connect with them. When we don’t, they turn to their sibling to try to get to us because it gets our attention. Instead of us responding with connection, we respond with scolding and it further disconnects us. Then our child tries harder to get our attention, perhaps with more focus on bothering their sibling to do so, and the whole thing is a toxic cycle.

What if instead we made note of this mentally. We thought “ah ha! My child needs to connect with me! I’m going to respond with connection, I’m going to say - I wonder what’s going on here! Instead of immediately scolding one and defending the other.” 

The other day Tess kept nagging Nell on the car ride and I wanted to just scold her. Then I thought about how when I do that, it disconnects us more and the nagging can just get worse. I thought about how Tess does this when she’s looking for more from me - I was preoccupied. So I just set boundaries “not gonna let you poke her like that” and then I made more connection points “but I am gonna sit right here, put my phone away and play I spy with you both!” 

It’s like responding by finding ways to reassure our children with one important reminder:

“You know that I am always your parent and love you very much. I am also your sibling’s parent and love them very much too. I am a parent to both of you. Forever and ever.”

Parent/Child Educator  
Co-founder of @unionsquareplay
